A fantastic game that was great to play with friends. Progression felt great and the world was nice to explore and interact with. Carving through every new biome was fantastic and felt very similar to Terraria in that way. 

Despite the game being simple graphically, it has the most beautiful boating I’ve ever seen in a game. The way the water moves is just mesmerizing. The art direction allows for the game to look quite beautiful in other areas as well. 

Complaints I have with the game all revolve around two mechanics, the stamina and the death system. Stamina takes way too long to regen. It’s fine in the early game, but it’d be really nice if there was a late game item that makes stamina regen triple or something. (maybe introduce it around the Plains Biome) The problem is that everything requires stamina, so I’d be stuck in some fights just walking around waiting for my stamina to regen. That’s not fun. 

My other complaint is with the death system, it’s too punishing. Yeah death should have consequences, but when you get to the mid game dying is waaay too harsh. You lose experience AND your items. This isn’t like Minecraft where experience and new weapons are easy to grind out. In Valheim, losing your gear permanently is game ending since new gear is incredibly hard to make. I would’ve rage quit if I lost my gear. Also because I kept losing exp on death, my levels never went higher than 40. If you can’t reasonably make it to level 100, the level cap should simply be level 50 because you will die, a lot.

Despite all this I had a great time with Valheim and am excited for a final boss to be added eventually. (hopefully)

Like most games of such genre it has enormous potential. It may devour thousands of hours easily, but not currently. Right now it needs a reason implemented. Like a lore says: it's a world of ghosts and willpower is their fuel. Player's willpower is strictly linked with game's features. Right now we have a few biomes (zones with different environmental conditions, wildlife and reasources), typical grinding for better gear and rather humble building system.

Spended almost seven hundred hours in this game which in my case is enough. I'm not finding most games interesting. "Valheim" is nothing new - basicially ugly version of "Skyrim" without quests and reasons but with building menu. All there is is one big grind against world which only knows how to steal effort; Time is an enemy, boundaries are hostile and most npcs will kill on sight just for the hell of it. No escape from this valhallic purgatory by any means. Game is not new and its updates are very slow - much like "DayZ", but "DayZ" is a lot more ancient. I won't bother with saying what's good, because that's for people to find out. Will only speak about things that bothered me throughout all my time with "Valheim". To help others avoid problems.

- I truly recommend to play on PVE servers only. Vanilla or hardcore. Simply because people are too toxic. They're the main reason why mentioned "DayZ" is evil and stressful game. People are constantly trying to destroy each other if such option is available. Game is not fun anymore when that happens.
- Mists are everywhere; each biome has its own version and even buildings won't stop them from taking over player's monitor. Especially annoying during snowstorms, while sailing, exploring plains and deep inside mistlands. Some of the mists cannot be blown away, even with wisplights. Particularly a bluish one inside mistlands. Fighting inside that is a needless challenge.
- Npcs are omnipotent and are seeing through walls and mists. Being detected from seemingly nowhere is a common thing.
- Swimming and sneaking are both fueled by stamina. If one runs dry then either health will be lost or stealth effect will be gone. Swimming penalty scales with amount of health.
- Npcs don't have stamina and can chase -in ideal scenario- forever. They only have cooldowns on some of their skills and patterns. Learning that is the only way to win seemingly unwinnable battles. Which in the long run makes every combat situation predictable.
- Everything is based on items. Without items there is no chance to go against anything outside meadows (starting) biome. Npcs in this game have no fear and are fighting to the death so without constant gear upgrades game turns into one sided slaughter. The main problem here is that avatar is not getting stronger by training with items but because of using them. That makes our hero a paper one.
- Not enough skills that could cultivate innate characteristics (strength, durability, memory...). No reason to actually train. The best skill currently is "blocking". It's a life saving skill imho, especially in tight spaces. But getting that to sufficient level is too much of a hassle. Amount of damage received has nothing to do with it. Players are abusing swarms of "weak" npcs to get it done.
- Limited creation menu. Player can't even fully use resources found in vanilla, either architectural or environmental. Can't even plant everything that can be normally harvested.
- Npcs's bows are heavily bugged. Their arrows have no range and never fall. Arrow just vanish after flying outside of rendering zone. The only thing that makes arrows weaker from "stalker" series gauss rifle's load is the speed of flight. Its relatively slow. Still, fighting a few common archers (mostly undead) is not a pleasant experience. No armor will help with that. Enemy archers of bigger rank (star or two stars) are pretty much the biggest threat in the game.
- Npcs's animations not fitting their actual position. You can see that enemy archer is not even aiming at ya, but he is. And not only archers. Every npc is having that problem. Calculating that mistake while fighting can save a lot of time.
- Npcs's range is way beyond their physical (model) capabilities and also ignoring walls while at it. Seeker is a grand example of dealing damage through any obstacle.
- Some npcs are so strong that can destroy stone or metal objects with their bare hands/teeth. Common wolf will do as an example here.
- Death penalty attacks only devoted players. The more hours you put into the game, the more you lose when "dying". This kind of penalty doesn't do anything to majority of casual players for they have no skills on their characters to lose. It's kinda unfair, especially on higher levels. One slip costs 5% of each skill. If you have 1 level with swimming, you will lose pretty much nothing. But 5% on level 80 means 4 levels down. To gain single high level player needs to devote A LOT of time. All of that is wasted very easily. The main problem here is mostly how unbalanced it feels.
- Some events are without sense (eg. wolves spawning in the middle of the ocean).
- Combat with white weaponry is seriously flawed. Spear is a prime example of making one step of progress and then doing two steps back. Before recent updates there was a problem with their attack ranges. Spear is a weapon with great range. But not in this game. Here you can only make a quick stab or throw. There is a big chance that thrown spear will just slip through the middle of a target without doing any damage. An easy way to lose weapon while fighting. There is still a problem with trajectories. If an enemy is standing a bit lower, then it doesn't matter if distance is point blank. Some weapons (spear once again) will never do any damage when that happens. Avatar will just stab nothing. Hence its important to fight in a right place. Enemies don't have a problem with dealing damage at all.
- A lack of real choice. Being a plaything for some myth-like "gods" isn't fun. Kill boss to progress further? Hang its head on the altar to unlock some silly and time limited power? Where's the option to defy those "gods"?
- Food is too overpowered. Mostly because the lower limits of health/stamina pools are strict. No skill is making them greater which doesn't make any sense. Through training one can become healthier - its a common knowledge. But here we can only eat. This system exists solely to force players into farming and cooking constantly. These two are not bad at all but too imbalanced at the same time.
- Stamina is too linear. Constant running, working or fighting is burning same amount of food as doing nothing. Everything is based on pre-designed timers.
- Npcs are immune towards physics that could easily kill any player - falling damage for example. I've seen a wolf falling from over 50 meteres and that did nothing to him. Same hight will kill a player unless special items are involved. Checked with different kind of npcs.
- Missing secondary object manipulation mode - full rotation for example. That would open a whole new world for construction purposes. Some mods are giving that feature already, but...
- Mods should NEVER make the game. Vanilla must be solid by itself and mods should only polish it a bit. It's a normal thing.
- Not available lycanthropy for players, which i see as a big flaw, especially when werewolves (npcs) are already implemented. Love werewolves.

I understand that this game is still being developed. But time waits for nobody and personally, i don't believe in early access games anymore. Seen too many failures. If it wasn't for the people i know i would not give it a try. But they've recommended it and we have spended some time together. Overall not bad, not bad at all. Time consuming though. This post is a shorter version (steam's limit on letters).

Valheim took the gaming world by storm, offering a rich, Viking-themed PVE survival crafting experience that encourages both solitary and cooperative play. 

Players embark on their posthumous journey, deemed worthy by Odin himself; they find themselves tasked with eradicating forsaken beings across the 10th realm. Since its release, it has distinguished itself with its engaging survival crafting loop, intuitive gathering, and building mechanics that allow players to progress from humble shacks to grand Viking halls. The integration of realistic physics adds a layer of depth and enjoyment to tasks as simple as chopping wood, enhancing the overall gameplay experience.

Valheim has an innovative base-building system, combat mechanics, and exploration of its vast, procedurally generated world. The building system allows for both precision and creativity, catering to a wide range of architectural preferences. If you go looking for creative base designs from players, you will find no shortage of entertainment and hours of time lost in the blink of an eye.

With regards to Valheim's combat, it is easily compared to action RPGs, with a focus on stamina management and a variety of weapons and armor to suit different playstyles. Unique world bosses add challenging milestones for players, with each victory unlocking new tiers of equipment. 

In combination with well-executed survival crafting elements, compelling combat, and exploration, Valheim is recommended for both veterans and newcomers to the survival genre. 

For a deeper dive into the game's features be sure to read our full review here: https://www.corrosionhour.com/valheim-review/

Valheim is a different flavor of survival crafting games.  I find it refreshing coming back after some time away.  As with all games, if you're not challenging yourself enough in the game, and you've gotten bored with it, keep your games revolving a bit.  And eventually you'll come back, and there might be another update that's come out.  The Mistlands this round just got released, an they've got plans for the Ashlands, so they're still in development as of this review.  As with all survival crafting games, you'll find some things you love, and some things you won't.  I find it fun every time I come back around to it regardless of updates.

Valheim’s success is, I think, more about an unmet demand for games like these than it is about Vaheim itself being anything like a completed work, much less the masterpiece that its overwhelmingly positive review score might lead you to believe.

There’s a lot of good here: Combat is snappy and responsive, base-building mechanics are fantastic, and the art direction, music, and minimalist graphics are all wonderful. The game has charm. But that charm was lost, for me, by the uninspired procedurally generated map, punishing death mechanics, and grind.

– 

In detail:

The procedurally-generated map is far too big for a solo player, and far too uninteresting to justify its size. The only human design in the game is the biomes themselves, but there’s only six of them. Once you’ve seen them all, you’ve explored the whole game. The computer repeats what little human-designed content there is a million times across a world the size of Azeroth. This doesn’t have a hand-designed world like Subnautica or Satisfactory.

To justify its size, the game offers a grind unlike any I’ve seen in games of this genre. At its default settings, you’d have to mine out an entire island to complete a suit of armor, and you’ll have to spend even more time lugging them back to base, then more time still refining all those materials. To put it clearly, this is the game: Mining resources on a relatively uninteresting map, and bringing them back to base.

I enjoyed building bases, particularly emergency shelters out in the wild, but sadly, there’s little gameplay reason to build a cool base like those in the trailer. The optimal base is a single room, stuffed with storage lockers, with all crafting stations crammed together. Crafting doesn’t automatically take resources out of nearby crates, so you’ll want those resources close at hand. Other games give you a reason to build multiple rooms, or solve other problems. And you can’t build anything on your Longship! 

While the combat system is wonderful, it’s marred by a punishing death and save system. When you die, you respawn with nothing, and must find your corpse to regain your lost loot. It’s especially punishing when this happens across oceans. The save system is more like an emergency backup system (for things like power outages or file corruption), and does not allow you to easily undo mistakes. This system serves to punish limit testing and experimentation. Purists will tell you it increases the tension, but I think the design is more to encourage multiplayer interaction, which is lost on solo players.

–

All that said, there’s a ton of promise in this game. Could the developers give us a reason to build more interesting bases? Can they make the world itself more interesting, perhaps by hand-designing a map?  Could they just add in a regular save system? Could they lessen the grind, and add in more bosses instead?

Part of my problem, I think, is that I have played Subnautica, Outer Wilds, and other small indie games with fantastic single-player journeys. I wasn’t going in with the expectation that this could be anything like those giants, but still, my brain can’t help but hope I’ll have experiences like those again. Valheim, with some changes, could be that game, and it’s not. It’s not trying to be. It’s a multiplayer sandbox game. And that’s okay. It’s just not what I want.

No words, the best game in its genre.The game has a very large and beautiful world, which is a pleasure to explore; a huge number of different interesting mobs, and each plays a role in survival; different locations that will take tens of hours to explore. In the game you can do anything, from cooking to building your own city. Valheim is one of the best games I've played and I 100% recommend it.

Just beat the final boss solo, took me under 300 days to complete. It has been quite the journey. I have died many times, although less than I would have expected. It is funny to think that it wasn't too long ago that 2 skeletons that kept killing me over and over as I tried to retrieve my loot. I went from fearing the mountains to them becoming trivial. 
I died many times on every biome and my takeaway is that no matter how powerful you are, no matter how large your health and stamina pools are or how lethal your weapons are, never get cocky. Over half my deaths were me getting comfortable and taking dumb risks. For the 12 bucks I spent on this game, Id say its one of the best fun for your money games out there. Definitely not for everyone though

After playing a few looter/crafter titles, this strikes a balance between fun adventures and material grinding, and it's not terribly complicated. This is sort of an "intro to looter/crafter games" title, but isn't so simple that you won't ever struggle - you will, you will die, and you will get frustrated. Bull plop will happen to you. And you'll feel accomplishment after besting every challenge, not sheer hatred like in some looter/crafters.

The concept is great, the gameplay is excellent, comparatively the execution is very clean, and it's extremely fun - especially with friends. There's a reason I've stayed up until 3am on several work nights, and dumped almost 800 hours and counting into it. And I'm far from the only person to do so.
Such an absolute joy to play. I couldn't recommend this game enough.

A couple of quick observations:
========================
-Can not teleport copper/ Halfwit developers don't want you doing fast travel with specific items!
-Bows in this  game are pathetic. Point blank or don't bother!
-How about a warning (more than just an occasional one), if you are in a place full of smoke that will kill you!
-if fighting on something near any building. You will do damage to that building. So, you may create more problems, if you need  to build a crafting station where there is no room for it. To continue your exploration of the building!
-The game does not allow for uneven ground level. So if the enemy is higher or lower. It will be able to hit you. But you will not hit them. Meaning, you die more than you should!!
-Game seems to crash a lot. Also as it apparently wants to be connected to the internet at all times, even when playing solo. It seems to stall a lot, if your connection lags!
-The first boss is immune to almost everything. Normal arrows do no damage at all and using a melee weapon is never going to be an option. Also, once you activate it. It will chase you forever. Which means after spending many hours building a basic base and house. If you make the mistake of running back to your house in the hopes of escaping it. It WILL smash your house down in less than 30 seconds. It is then restart time [ALT + F4]. Try fire arrows, but I wont be back. Game is pathetic!
-Make it more obvious how to repair items!
-How about turning the lights on, so we can see what we are doing. Are the gfx that bad. At least you could give us a gamma slider, so we can adjust the setting and keep playing, rather than just stopping play!
-Walking around, bashing trees and bushes, collecting food, or killing things that decide to attack you is fun for about 30 seconds.
-Why the F, do we suddenly get attacked non stop. If the respawn spot is where you get killed. Every time after that, you will respawn with no items to defend your self from further attacks!. Pathetic! [ALT + F4] time for me!
-When using a hoe to lower the ground. What keys do we use to switch between raise and lower. I accidentally found the raise key (no idea which one it was). It raised the ground too high and now I can't lower it again. This makes my building unfinishable! 
-Make building simpler. While in build mode, let us fly. While on the subject of building. Display a message telling us why we can not build. Simply making the part RED, is nowhere near enough information. Especially when we try moving the part around and no matter where we put it. It remains RED. Imbeciles made this build system!!!



My main gripe:
============
Why is building anything so hard?

I look at the key bindings, I see keys for specific things, such as build. I go back to game and press key. Nothing happens. Display a message on screen when we press the build key with out having a hammer equipped!

Why can we not interact with doors etc, while we are in building mode. Having to press several keys to exit building mode, open the door, then press several keys to go back in to building mode, is pathetic!

Rather pointless, pressing other keys, for the most part, does not do much either!

One of my all-time favorites. Great to play alone; even better with a group of friends. The base game stuck with me as one of the most memorable journeys to progress through in gaming. The graphical theme works so well in this game, every frame is gorgeous. After your first play-through, you can go check out the extensive modding community and change the game completely (ValheimRaft is my suggestion). This game has my all time favorite building system, you can see by some of my screenshots that it has inspired me to construct some pretty major projects over time. And I regret none of it. 

2024 EDIT: While I still recommend this game, I have to include that mods are a MUST for the full experience nowadays. The devs have reallyyyyy slowed down their work on the game over time sadly, so there's RARELY new content. Mistlands update itself was rather disappointing, but here's to hoping Ashlands will be better. I suggest to anyone wanting to give this game a shot and play it to its full potential, use r2modman mod loader and load up on any mod that interests you. The modded community of this game FAR exceeds the content scarcely put out by the developers.

Valheim is not without its flaws, though. it still has some bugs and glitches that can affect the gameplay and performance. the game can also become grindy, especially in the later stages  as you have to gather a lot of resources and travel long distances to progress. the game also lacks some features that could enhance the experience, such as a map editor, a quest system, and more customization options.
Despite these issues, Valheim is a highly enjoyable and addictive game that offers a lot of content and potential for a reasonable price. It is a game that will keep you hooked for hours, as you discover new things, overcome new challenges, and create your own Viking saga. If you are looking for a challenging and rewarding survival adventure, Valheim is a game you should definitely check out.  Trust me i have 360 hours in this game. It's worth all the money.

Valheim is certainly one of the open world survival crafting games of all time.

Overall, I like Valheim. I played through it up to the end of the current content with two friends of mine, and we created a good number of memories doing so. We've agreed to come back for the next major update, having ended on a rather good note.

Of the things I like about the game, I'm rather impressed with the scale of the world and the variety of encounters to be found. The procedural generation of lands and dungeons lends itself well to emergent experiences, and while there were some disappointments to be had as a result of the system, the successes are left echoing in my mind far stronger than the failures. Some high points specifically were complex adventures to retrieve lost items which forced innovative or just desperate strategies, The current last boss is by far and away the best of the selection in the game, with varied threats yet appropriate measures to combat them. Interesting gear with special effects near the end was a delight to discover. Some enemies are absolutely terrifying and a thrill to encounter.

There are a few things I can criticize. The number of items to be discovered is somewhat low, and the realistic amount of solid "content" to be found is on the low side. This leads into by far my biggest sense of distaste for the game: the grind. To be perfectly honest, the amount of engagement to be found in Valheim is likely in the 20-30 hour range, but it's stretched to far longer by the level of material grind required at sections of the game, and most of our sessions were centered around resolving this. The fast travel system, a series of interconnected portals built and linked by the player, is a good one, but prohibits transportation of many materials - primarily metal - that are required to progress the game. This means the game's exceptionally lengthy sailing times are necessary not just for exploration, but the repeated shipping of materials for processing. Combined with an inane level of these materials - especially iron - required, the length of the game is artificially inflated as much as 5 times, and is the only real reason my hours are left above 100 at the end of the playthrough.

Largely for this reason, I would [i]never[/i] play Valheim alone. Were I not alongside friends to elevate the experience, this time sink would have left such a sour taste in my mouth that the game would never have been able to redeem itself in my mind.

I leave Valheim, for the time being, with a positive impression, yet the dangerously low amount of engaging content sets a tone that prevents me from really calling it "great".

**MINOR EDITS SINCE '22**

Valheim is perhaps one of the best survival crafting games out there, and is without question the most immersive, especially when played with friends. Like many games of this genre you start out naked in the woods, and you must craft items and build a base. But, it has some unique twists that can cause the player(s) to organically behave in a "realistic" way, such as:

- When building a house, you have considerations I haven't seen in other games. For instance, you will need a fire to keep you warm. But, that fire generates smoke, so it needs a chimney. But, rain can put out your fire, so you also need that chimney to be covered. Furthermore, you want to add comfort items and decorations in your house so you get a better rested buff.

- Food doesn't heal you, rather it gives you a health/energy bar to begin with. Additionally, different foods give you different amounts of health or stamina, so you have to have a balanced diet with multiple food sources. No farming the "best food", you have to diversify, and some cannot be farmed but must be hunted.

- Wood and stone is heavy, so you may want to build a cart to move large quantities. But, that cart can be sluggish when loaded with cargo, so you will want to build roads throughout to make it a smooth and easy journey. Ditto with sailing ships and docks - will make your life easier, and not in a "5% improvement to X" way.

- When playing multiplayer, you are indirectly encouraged to build together and share resources/labor. Yes, other games do this as well to varying degrees. But here, many otherwise expensive items can be shared by the community, attacks are more easily repealed, and tasks divided so you can get more done in less time. 

Now, I have not at all talked about the amazing sailing, the sound combat mechanics, the impressive art style/graphics that both looks stunning while being able to run on almost anything. There is a lot of wonderful things to say about this game, and a reason why myself and my friend-group have spent over 1000 hours collectively in it.

But, this is the internet, so I do need to make some complaints:

- Lackluster character customization, and what customization options exist are quickly hidden from view. You can choose between male and female player models, along with some hair, beard, and color options. The problem is that as soon as you put on armor, it's hard to tell the difference between any players. There are very few "purely cosmetic" items in the game, and it's always smarter to have the "newest armor" as it's a linear progression. When you and all your friends look the same as you are wearing the same armor, it sure makes customization feel unimportant. If players were given broader freedom in customizing the player model, if the body types were more distinct in appearance, and if there were more armors that were either side-grades or just cosmetic re-skins of other armors, this could be easily fixed.

- I previously wrote that the stealth path felt lackluster. I have since replayed the game, limiting myself to light armor and daggers. I no longer think that the stealth path is as bad as I once did, but it could still use some work. While enjoyable to use in the Black Forrest and slowly thinning out goblin villages, stealth is completely impractical within swamp crypts and infested mines. The mistlands-teir duel-wield daggers are frankly a downgrade due to the lower blocking ability, and this isn't even getting into the fact that it's hard to justify not keeping to the cultist armor as soon as you get it. Lots of little things to fix or otherwise address - or maybe making it easier to divest into a wider range of combat skills over a playthrough - but not as bad as I once wrote.

- There are a number of quality-of-life improvements that this game could enjoy. Looking at some of the more popular mods for this game would be a great starting place, but I know for sure that better granulation in building placement as well as smoothing the process of planting farms would be both well welcomed improvements to the game. 

Overall, I very much enjoy this game. My friends love it. And I suspect we will continue to keep playing this game so long as there are more things for us to do in it.

Edit: 980 hours of gameplay later, this is my favorite survival game even as the market is saturated by new and exciting versions of this now familiar format.

I like how building and surviving go hand-in-hand here. You need to take into account the structure to support its weight, how well it can handle smoke, rain/water, and whatever else. Resource gathering feels interesting and not completely. If I want to gather a lot of logs from a nearby forest, or perhaps specific ore and other items, I can build a path and load up a cart with the goods. Though, you better hope the road was built well and doesn't make it hard to lug around a lot of weight! 

Exploring feels like a quest all its own. Whether by land or sea, things can go south real quick with monsters and environmental hazards! Working the sails on your boat is fun as heck. 

The devs know how to make a lot of the systems work together in a fun way while avoiding the edge where it feels like tedious work(imo, but I haven't wanted to go past the Swamp tier of progression). Masterfully done so far, and Valheim holds its own among the plethora of survival-builder - both fully released and early access. Can't wait for the updates!

P.S. I love knocking down trees into other trees! It's so [i]satisfying![/i]

Valheim is a great game, but is not one I would feel comfortable recommending to a friend. The grind for iron is a bit much. Boats are unintuitive, wind angles are too punishing, and there is too much fog. In Mistlands the wisp reveal radius is too small, and eitr refinery shouldn't cost black cores because it makes it so you're incentivized to build black forge -> destroy black forge -> build eitr refinery -> craft ref eitr -> destroy eitr refinery -> build black forge multiple times. Boss difficulty felt weird, some bosses are insanely easy while others are quite challenging. The merchant is too hard to find. The "new" merchant is disappointing -- it could have been an epic adventure quest across the world but the rewards are merely cosmetic. I don't understand the decision to make you kill friendly npcs in order to progress, it doesn't add anything to the game.

All you should know about this game is that you need to install over 50 mods to make it playable in 2024.
Unity for a seamless open world game with so many elements is absolutely not suitable, because the optimization is terrible, which will lead to regular crashes or freezes due to lack of RAM (not less than 16gb is must have for the game).
The graphics... well, it's crap, that's all I can say... It's not a great visual or anything worth having in 2024. And I would understand it as a price for good optimization and adaptability for low performance computers, but that's not the case, as you just get zero of both.
Bosses are simple as fck and without some mods the combat system isn't even close to be enjoyable or convenient.
If you still want to try it out, consider playing with modpacks installed.

Great game. Unlike so many games of this genre, most of the survival aspects feel more fun than tedious, exploration is rewarded with new materials across the board for more tools or better gear.

PEOPLE LOOKING TO JUST BUILD BEWARE!!

Most of those impressive structures you see on youtube or community page are through dev commands and/or mods (so your stuff will break when game updates and mod doesn't). While the option to build at no material cost in the game is appreciated if you just want to build there are many annoyances where something SHOULD work but game says no. Building needs to be way less restrictive (especially with stone/glass). Support requirements vary from material to material and generally detracts from creative expression where you have to conform to the dev's arbitrary "no because" (and their army of sycophants). A world option to toggle this like the existing "no cost building" option would be great. 

What constitutes an enjoyable experience changes from person to person and from time to time; its a game at the end of the day. The more options people are given to customize their experience the better. Tired of the trite "no cause realism", "no cause I had to do it the hard way it shouldn't be made easier", "no cause I dislike the idea of the existence of preferences different than mine", or "no cause it is the bible incarnate and should not be changed or altered in any way you sacrilegious cunt".

This ain't your average survival crafting sandbox. While most may say "probably not for everyone", I find this game really has a lil something for almost everyone & can be thoroughly enjoyed with some friends and/or  mods, creativity, and bit of dedication, Its very rewarding unlike so many other games. It's a difficult hardcore game by default but now can be configured with settings. Played as "intended", it's unforgiving and challenging which makes the world feel more real and alive and leads to many good times and "learning experiences" (especially with friends).

  It's still in early access, managed by a small team who are now reshaping development with new funds and the modding community is updating mods all the time because the Dev's keep breaking them with game updates. This has to be the biggest flaw of this game IMO so far. Some may complain that "This game is only difficult *because* it's punishing" but I believe this kinda only applies to people who are cracked at gaming because the different forms of combat are not easy to master either. Neither are the systems in the game; mining, terraforming, building and exploration etc. all take finesse and experience, and other systems (culinary, smithing, building, crafting, exploration, etc.) are all exploratory like the first time you played Minecraft or Terraria (This game doesn't hold your hand or spoil things) and has great replayability.

This game didn't blow up for no reason. It has a solid & original sandbox foundation and simple yet robust game systems and mechanics. With game settings and mods you can tweak your experience to your liking and even host your own modded servers. This game supports crossplay & servers between Xbox *GamePass, PC *GP and Steam but almost all mods are not compatible with xbox/vanilla. 

TLDR: A great little hand crafted gem of a sandbox that many people can enjoy with the right tweaks as its in Early Access and while feeling polished there are limitless opportunities for fun/world building with mods.

Positives:
- Graphics: The game's stylised graphics are really beautiful and immersive, both outdoors and in dungeons and crypts.

- Sound: The music in this game isn't Dark Souls boss music quality, but it still sounds pleasant when traversing the land. Boss music is pretty nice also.

- Area variability: Though I don't like some of the areas in the game, the game still manages to keep every new area fresh and original. My favourite areas are (Meadows,Black Forest and Plains, and the Giant Turtle's back).My least favourite area was the Mist Lands. I don't need to explain why this area is bad, if you have played the game. The swamps and Mountains look great and are fun when you are slightly higher level, but the enemies slightly ruin the area when you go there with low level gear.

- Fun with Friends: This may be a negative thing, but this game is only really worth it with friends (But really fun to play with friends). Playing by yourself in my opinion, would suck.

Negatives:
- Bad (Boring) Grind: Grind isn't always bad, however for it to not be bad, it needs to be fun grind. The grind in this game is mostly mining ores and bringing them back to the base to smelt. This was probably the most annoying and boring aspect of the game (The worst thing is, its majority of the game). It's saddening because it definitely could have been made more fun. The only fun grinding aspect of the game was invading plains camps for wheat and flax. Why in a viking game is raiding done only during a small part of the game, but mining ore is done throughout the whole game? It doesn't make sense, Vikings in media raid, not spend most of their time mining.

- The combat: The Witcher 3 has this same issue, you fight most of the enemies the same way. You either dodge an attack, then hit or you shoot an enemy down with arrows. That's it. Even most of the bosses are fought the same way. You can parry, but most of the time its easier and safer to dodge and hit an enemy, especially when dealing with 2 star enemies.

- Wolves:.

- Lack of content: The game without the grind is very small, the devs are still adding to the game, but times between updates are very long.

- Building system: The building system in this game is very janky and it's almost impossible to not get stuff clipping through each other, for somebody who likes things to look perfect, its a real annoyance. Additionally some of the different building sets you get in the game, are missing things that the starting wood set contains (Like their own doors, roofs, or stairs). Why?

Ending comment: The games really fun with friends, it means you need to do a bit less grinding with certain things and even during grind, you can interact and talk to your friends. If you are looking for a basic survival game to play with friends, this game is something to consider getting. If you are looking for something to play by yourself, best look for something else.

[u] Positives [/u] 
• The music is excellent and creates a immersive vibe.
• The graphics are beautiful and creative.
• The procedural generation of the map is excellent.
• The building feature is the best in any game i've ever played.
• Game play overall is extremely fun.

[u] Negatives [/u] 
• Difficulty level between biomes.
• Enemies spawn next to player and swarm the player constantly.
• Dying over and over to recover items dropped on death with no other way to recover them.
• Stamina mechanic is absolutely broken. Very limited stamina causes the player to just stand in place unable to attack or run while getting hit by enemies.
• Mining and digging needs to be overhauled. You should be able to dig deeper and find ore. The way various ores are obtained in the game is terrible. They should all be mined underground in their respective biomes as small nodes. 
• Stone structures are far too weak. 
• Fishing is impossibly difficult. I'm never able to reel fish in successfully.
• No diving/underwater swimming mechanic.

[u] Suggested improvements [/u] 
• Add more music.
• Stamina and health shouldn't be solely based on what they player eats. These stats should improve with some sort of leveling up system.
• Reduce/Prevent enemies from constantly spawning and swarming player. Enemies should be standing around the world.
• Add the ability to build/design custom ships. Allow player to build on the ship.
• Overhaul mining Ore as mentioned before. 
• Allow for deeper mining and add the ability to dig tunnels or caves. Allow for mine shafts, underground bases, and underground ore mining.
• Increase the strength of stone structures significantly.
• Implement a way for the player to retrieve/call back their items lost on death at the world stones/Spawn.
• Add more building pieces.
• Fish need to be reeled in easier.
• Add a diving/swimming underwater mechanic.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. I love the building system; the art style and the game look great. I love the combat and the wide variety of monsters. Each biome is unique and beautiful. Although the game isn't technically "finished", it is a complete and utter masterpiece.

It's been a while, and I could not be happier with the state of the game. Ashlands is almost here and I am very excited. Back when I first made this review, I already said this was one of my favorite games of all time. I would like to recant that statement... It DEFINITELY IS my favorite game of all time. With every update, new biome, and patch, the game has just gotten better and better. I genuinely cannot express how much I love this game. Even if the game gets forgotten by most, I will never tire of playing.

Awesome game! If you're into open world survival, this is one of the best I've played. Started out a little slow cause some of then mechanics are a little unique (but this is a strong point once you get the hang of it). Probably my favorite and most open building that I've seen in any game other than Minecraft. Love the food mechanics and biome/boss progression as well. If I had to say one thing bad, it would gathering metal feels a bit grindy mid game. But other than gear and armor, you can get back all of the valuable resources you use when you destroy your structures, so this problem goes away after a while.

I enjoy the gameplay loop of this game a lot. Every area looks and plays a different way, combat (although clunky at times) hits that sweet spot between boring simplicity and overwhelming complexity, the metroidvania elements make exploration more interesting and streamlined, and the building mechanics spice things up quite well without severely hindering creativity; all of that without mentioning the excellently executed lo-fi artstyle and very fitting soundtrack which bring a lot of life to the game. The crafting system, item variety and survival mechanics are not groundbreaking but provide some extra depth.

However, it doesn't have that much playable content in the grand scheme of things and it's not long before you run out of things to discover after you reach a new area, at which point it turns into a tedious, repetitive grind that is unreasonably time-consuming. 
Getting a new material requires doing the same, very slow thing over and over again. These materials are not only very annoying to carry around due to the inventory system, but also force you to make repeated trips back and forth with the boat and deal with the way too annoying wind mechanics. You are eventually able to acquire upgrades and new tools, but they are nowhere near enough to ease the grind even in previous zones.
A way of alerting the player when they are approaching an area they should not be exploring yet would be helpful too, especially considering enemies can chase you between biomes. Currently the only way of learning about it is to either go to the wiki or getting one-hit killed by a random enemy which often looks way less menacing than what you were actually supposed to be fighting. Since dying can be very punishing, the game encourages an overly cautious and grindy playstyle that can eventually become unfun.

When it comes to base building, the bare bones raid system quickly goes from a challenge to a constant annoyance that keeps you from what you'd rather be doing by throwing the same things at you over and over again. Farming is very janky and very slow, and shaping terrain is an unintuitive pain.
The variety of building materials is still far too limited as well, and I don't see that changing any time soon.

And then there's the elephant in the room: performance and especially the netcode are pretty lacking in areas with a big amount of player-built structures, which can lead to really bad desync when multiple people are around and makes raids an even more frustrating mechanic in multiplayer. It is also missing basic options such as an FoV slider, forcing you to mod the game if you want to change it. All of this despite having sold a ton of copies and been in early access for a long time. 

With that said, it's not an expensive game for what it has to offer and the atmosphere and world there's to explore are definitely an experience worth having.

[h1][b] TLDR: It’s been 3 years since I played Valheim and it feels just as janky as it did before. What even changed in early access since its release??[/b] [/h1]

[b]Genre/Similar Games: Survival base building (Palworld)[/b]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
✅Viking/Nordic aesthetic

[h1]CONS: [/h1]
➖Combat is frustratingly janky
➖You are constantly attacked when doing anything

THIS IS A QUICK EARLY ACCESS REVIEW. NO RELEASE, NO SCORES
I figured I would let Palworld cook a while and revisit a game that’s probably near the end of its early access journey. I bought Valheim in 2021 and played 20 hours of it before I got a bit bored. I return 3 years later and to my disappointment, I cannot find a single meaningful new thing about this game. Sure, the food values have changed. That’s the only thing I notice. 
[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative/Lore/Length/P2W/Mods) – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
A randomly generated world – so besides RNG, your experience could be good or bad here. I do enjoy the terraforming and viking-esque world here. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Controls/Mechanics/Loop/Difficulty/Bugs) – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
Awful. The combat is just bad. Why the heck do I have to be 1 foot away from an enemy to hit them with my spear?? The movement is janky, the combat is constant. I just really find the gameplay unfun. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Art style/Animations/UI/Performance) – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
Subpar, but its to be expected when you have terraforming, i.e voxel graphics. 
Performance is good on my desktop though, no issues there. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | installed on SSD
[h1] [b] Audio (Sound Effects/Music/Voice Acting/Ambient) – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
Audio is great, I love the meadows music. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Side quests/NG+/Player Choice) – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
I feel like once you progress past a certain point, there is no real reason to ever return. Like if you’re using metal armor, why would you ever get leather? 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict – [EA/10] [/b] [/h1]
There are better alternatives out there. I recommend Palworld. I can’t believe after 3 years that I struggle to find a meaningful change. It really feels like the devs took the popularity of Valheim to the bank. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1] No[/h1]

Venturing into the realm of Valheim is akin to stepping into a vividly realized Norse saga, where every tree, mountain, and creature pulsates with life and mystery. Developed by Iron Gate Studio, this indie gem seamlessly blends survival, exploration, and adventure into a captivating experience that resonates with both casual players and seasoned gamers alike.

From the moment you awaken amidst the ethereal mist of Valheim's procedurally generated world, you're thrust into a realm teeming with possibilities. The first rays of dawn bathe the landscape in a warm, golden hue, inviting you to chart your own course amidst towering forests, sprawling meadows, and treacherous mountains.

Valheim's greatest triumph lies in its dynamic and immersive world-building. Every corner of the map beckons with untold secrets, whether it's uncovering the ruins of ancient civilizations, braving the depths of murky swamps, or battling ferocious denizens of the wilderness. The game's procedural generation ensures that no two adventures are alike, fostering a sense of discovery and wonder with each new journey.

But Valheim isn't just about exploration; it's about survival in its purest form. As a lowly Viking spirit, you must scavenge, hunt, and craft your way to dominance in a harsh and unforgiving land. Gathering resources, constructing shelter, and mastering the art of combat are essential to your survival, and the game strikes a perfect balance between challenge and accessibility, ensuring that even newcomers can find their footing without feeling overwhelmed.

One of Valheim's standout features is its emphasis on cooperative gameplay. Whether teaming up with friends or venturing solo, the game offers a deeply satisfying multiplayer experience that encourages camaraderie and collaboration. Working together to build mighty fortresses, conquer formidable foes, and sail the high seas aboard majestic longships is where Valheim truly shines, fostering bonds that endure long after the final boss is vanquished.

Visually, Valheim may not boast the hyper-realistic graphics of AAA titles, but its charming low-poly aesthetic imbues the world with a timeless appeal, reminiscent of classic adventure games. Coupled with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that evokes the grandeur of Norse mythology, the game creates an atmosphere that is as enchanting as it is immersive.

In conclusion, Valheim is a triumph of indie game development, offering a rich and rewarding experience that transcends its modest origins. With its captivating world, deep gameplay mechanics, and emphasis on cooperative play, it stands as a shining example of what can be achieved when passion and creativity collide. Whether you're a fan of survival games, Norse mythology, or simply crave adventure, Valheim is an odyssey you won't soon forget.

Old review around 2021: 

Awesome game first of all. The lure is interesting. The graphical style is beautiful. The generated world (maps) are always well "generated". The sense of progression even though its fully free roam is super satisfying, which is quite hard to achieve so that's a big win for the developers. The building systems are awesome you can make some really nice stuff in the game. The combat and survival mechanics are also decent. All in all its a great game. But two things make this game hard to recommend. The first and most important is the grind. Overly grindy. Collecting metals is ok cause you only need to do it once and never again as long as you don't lose your tool which is difficult, but the trees OH the FUcking trees. If I didn't use console commands to get around the tree cutting I would've not enjoyed the game as much as I did, especially with such a well made building system you can't help but to build massive forts and towns. The tree cutting needs to stop being so grindy for real, its a problem in all survival games and its only worse here. Second thing is play-ability with one player only. You know it and I know it, whoever you're playing with now they'll stop playing midway and you'll be left to finish alone. It feels made to be played with more than one player and makes it sometimes harder to play alone, until b-it-ch like behaviour is eradicated the game should allow better play ability for solo plays.

The bad things here are:
Optimization. The game runs like trash. It's hard to get a good frame rate no matter what you do if your computer is not the best.

Building and crafting. All the little rules that you have to follow to do certain things can get sooo annoying. Building is a real pain in the ass because of how the terrain works and how the pieces of structures work together as well. It's so stressful for no reason.

Everything else I would say has been a pleasant experience, though. The combat is very hard a lot of the time, but it's fun that way. You will die a lot. But the gods are merciful. You'll come back.

Getting the resources for better equipment and exploring the world while doing so is really fun. The bosses are fun.

Love the game.

Overall, Valheim is a solid game.  It's a fun survival game with clear progression, interesting base building, and some decent combat options.  Unfortunately I'd only give it a 6/10 because of one very massive flaw - the stamina system.  I don't know what they were thinking with the absolutely ridiculous stamina drain / regen system.  I'd say that 90-95% of the times I've died in the game were not because the enemy was too hard.  It was because I ran out of stamina. Once you run out of stamina, especially in a swamp or other wet coastal area, you're SOL. Your strong veteran warrior instantly turns into a floppy armed fool who can barely walk. One of the other mind boggling decisions they made was that your stamina doesn't regen any faster if you have 50 stamina or 150.  The farther I got in the game, the more I was standing around waiting for stamina to regen. I can't even use any of the other boss buffs in the game, because the stamina buff is needed more often than not. You can eventually brew stamina potions and such. However, I hate having to grind out crafting materials simply to do something as basic as running around or fighting.

I usually quit Valheim from annoyance rather than boredom.  If they fixed the stupid stamina system the game would be an easy 8 or 9/10.  As it is right now, it's a 6 at best.

I'm almost 60 hours deep, and it feels like I've not even touched the sides! I never thought I'd enjoy PvE again after the surge in PvP games in recent years but I was incredibly wrong. This game for me, is a masterpiece. And as good as this game is and as much as this game has to offer, what is my favourite thing to do in Valheim? Cutting down trees. I can do it for hours and not get bored. It is extremely satisfying. I play anything between 2-5 hours  per day and the only reason I stop there is because my buttocks starts to get numb! 
Get this game - You won't regret it.

If an early access game is put together this well, I can only imagine what it'll be like when it's finished over the next two years.

Right now, this doesn't feel like an early access game, it feels complete. I mean I'm sure it has no "end" point, no finale, but it has a ton of stuff and a progression system that makes it all very satisfying to earn.

It's a survival game, but you don't have things like "hunger" or "thirst". Instead, food is tied to your max health and stamina. Meaning eating is essential but not urgent. If you're safely in your base behind tons of fortifications, you can risk not eating and having a small pool of health for a while. It's not amazing, and if there were one thing I'd change it'd be this (I'd rather just treat it as a way to gain more health and stamina regen rather than increasing the capacity).

You slowly build your way up towards the heavier, more durable metals by picking wood off the corpses of dwarflings (trees and moss wrapped around the souls of murderers, fun bit of lore for you) and stone off the ground and crafting yourself and workbench and some basic stone tools, as well as a hut. It's like Minecraft in that sense instead the only trees you can punch down are the really tiny ones. You need an axe of varying strength for the different trees you'll encounter. Same for pickaxes and so forth.

You'll start in the meadows, work your way to the black forest for metals after you've conquered your first boss and proven you're prepared enough, then make your way to the swamp once you've defeated the second boss and gathered yourself a key needed to get your next metal and so on. It takes a while, but with a friend it can be very fun and rewarding. Just setting up your base will take hours of your time and the bit-by-bit construction really serves the game well to allow you to make your own custom homes and fortresses. When you unlock the next sort of base material and accompanying constructions, you'll feel like you've actually earned it.

Not to mention this game is deceptively beautiful. You'll understand when you've actually played it, but the lighting and skyboxes fit in incredibly well with the pixelated 3D art style, the latter of which was a very bold choice, but definitely paid off in my eyes.

I hope the developers keep at this pace. I'm excited to see what's in the upcoming updates. The roadmap looks very good.

Oh and did I mention that as I type this the game is only 1GB (randomly generated and a pixelated art style saves tremendously on space) and it costs just $20? The price is likely to increase as more content is implemented so I can't recommend enough people get in while they can if the game sounds interesting to them. The game's grown up to 5 million players for a reason.

Really, though, get a friend or two to play with and slowly work your way up. Even if you have to make new friends to play it with, it'll be worth it.

------------

It also can't be overstated how good the build system in this game is. It's quick, easy and simple. As opposed to a game like Conan Exiles where it feels immensely clunky.

Everything's attached to your hammer for building and quickly destroying buildings, and while the stability system can get annoying, it's more or less quite sensible and can even be used to your advantage (destroying all supports under something will cause it to slowly break apart as nothing is holding it up anymore; even working for nearly all kinds of rocks and ore found in the game right now, excluding silver, which for some reason resists gravity's force).

You can easily disable snapping by holding down a button (shift) if you need to make some more creative designs or to place something the snapping system won't help with (like a more stable platform by connecting two areas).

It's excellent. I can't imagine ever going back to another 3D game's piece-by-piece building system and not seeing it as a downgrade. Indie developers have more passion and foresight in their pinkies than a hundred triple A gaming developers have in their whole bodies, including the likes of Bethesda.

---------

EDIT 1: Post-Mistlands, I'd just like to say I didn't enjoy that zone. The mist just isn't a fun mechanic to work around. Look, it's hard enough to survive in each new zone when you progress because of how powerful enemies are, but do the developers really need to make it worse by making the mist just so... so... EXTREME?

I'd really rather just not play the zone at all, sadly. Pushing the mist out with tools is really ineffective, otherwise it could have been fun. I mean what good is clearing mist like 5 feet in front of you going to do? Nothing.

Doesn't ruin the game itself, but I hope they think things through better for future zones. Some irritations don't get a pass, I'm sorry.

I love challenging games, and being a gamer of 39 years now I have conquered some of the hardest twitch reflex games ever created, with some extra love to the Dark Souls series. One thing all of these games had in common was FAIRNESS!!! yeah you COULD SEE THE ENEMIES COMING!!! and after they died THEY STAYED DEAD (usually). Let me explain, at one point in this game I was in the starter biome by the safe coast line and looking to start another base so I cleared out the area of the 3 boars and 2 grey dwarfs and started building. 40 Seconds later 5 more grey dwarfs showed up and the 3 boars I killed less than a minute ago respawned right on top of me. So in the last 46 seconds I had to deal with a total of 11 enemies, 3 of which magically appeared behind me so I had no tactical options or chance of defending myself. This isn't challenge or fair, this is janky crap game design that breaks convention to inflict misery and pain. To add insult to injury the default controls are sluggish and unwieldy, with none of the tight responsiveness of the aforementioned souls likes. I understand there is a ton of people that love this type of thing and this game is very popular, but I like a challenge I can see and fairly engage where I have only myself to blame for failure, not magically teleporting enemies that have no restrictions on frequency or number.

The amount of time it takes to kill a simple mob is just tedious, not even hard.... just takes up a lot of time and that's it.

We found that in case someone dies, all except one of us will leave the area.... This way all the mobs scale down to 1 player HP and DMG. That player clears the area until the dead people can return to loot their bodies.
depends on how many allies/friends are in the proximity. 

All in all the developers have done too little considering how many funds they got at the release.
The community does waaaaay more.
Maybe in 10 years we will have the next 2 bioms as well.

3 years of 'early access'.  As responsible gamers, we really need to stop the practice of giving software companies our hard earned dollars so that we can beta test games for them.    I couldn't be more disappointed in what this team has 'accomplished' in 3 years.  Not only do I feel I deserve a refund, I feel they should have been paying me to suffer through their beta testing (with no clear plan or date for actual release).  WE HAVE BEEN SCAMMED.

I love the game very much. Gorgeous and super fun. However updates are too slow in light of the MASSIVE success of this game and I'm salty about it. 

The devs also seem to have a specific version of fun in mind which is not compatible with my own. Had to add mods to do the following:

-Rebind the dodge key (otherwise you must hold down the mouse wheel + space bar)
-Allow you to keep loot on death (server setting max out at keeping equipped gear only)
-Sort loot into nearby chests (recently removed to... encourage engagement with the inventory system)
-Sort my inventory at all

To the devs: if players are not engaging with your systems to a degree you deem appropriate, the systems are *not fun enough to engage with*. Instead of removing a QOL feature, perhaps make the underlying system better. 

Without modding I would not recommend. With mods it's the best survival game currently available and it's not close.

OPINION OBVIOUSLY  (since everyone seems to love this game).
This feels more like a concept for a good game rather than an actual good game (as of early 2024 when i played it). I want to like it, because there seems to be a very good core in it, but it feels unfinished and poorly executed in its mechanics. Of the top of my head:

-Inventory management is terrible. Building a ton of chest and then having to find and put to your inventory materials every time you want to craft anything, is tedious and annoying. And i assume that annoyance increases exponentially as you progress and gather more mats/find more crafting recipes. And then if you change/move your main base, gather everything and do 10 trips from old base to new (portals save time, but mats such as minerals can't go through)
-Constantly draining stamina when exploring/gathering is almost never fun, especially in a big map 
-Building is almost good, but it ends up being frustrating cause almost nothing seem to snap into place when you want it to in seemingly obvious build paths (flooring, roofing etc). Also the game doesnt seem prepared to let you build on anything other than flat surfaces, but provides little of them. flattening and and raising ground to create a base area are pure exercises in frustration
-Combat is honestly a boring wait your stamina to fill again game, the enemies behave like 4 year old morons, and the combat mechanics are clanky at best, not working at worst. Even a small elevation fucks up hit boxes
-The progression is tedious af, especially if you have a bad rng map seed and resources/key areas are badly dispersed. Also tons of boring material farming is constantly required
-Meh art style, poor graphics. I dont really care for good graphics for the sake of good graphics, and I am of the opinion that an art style that fits the game matters much much more than fidelity. That being said, i think the game looks like a unity asset flip rather than uniquely designed. 

TLDR: In my opinion, good core concept and base design, badly executed mechanics and gameplay. It seems like a game I would love to play when it's actually done. For now, it feels like an alpha/early beta version.

I will change my rating if the game feels like its evolving, but it has been on early access for years so I unfortunately feel somewhat pessimistic about that

Edit: I know the game is on early access, but it been out on steam for 3 years now, so I think my critiques are fair.

There are sooooooo many survival crafters out there right now. Valheim still stands tall. The building system might throw you off at the start, but it is substantially more rewarding than other builders once you are hip to it. The trees having physics seems minor but it cannot be overstated how much this separates the game from all the others where you spend time punching wood. The biome progression is really great. If I have to pick a nit, then it is that the most fun combat systems are heavily backloaded. If you don't enjoy survival crafting/base building, you won't enjoy Valheim, but if you do enjoy those things, this game will probably make you reconsider your favorite of the genre

[b]Rating:[/b] ★★★★☆ - Great
[b]Time Played:[/b] 29 hours (Meadows & Black Forest Completed)
[b]Difficulty:[/b] Normal

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
	- Engagingly brutal survival mechanics keep you constantly on your toes, from gathering resources to building small Viking towns.
	- Seamless integration of exploration and combat, with each procedurally generated biome offering unique challenges and rewards.
	- Co-op multiplayer is almost mandatory and adds a whole new layer of enjoyment, fostering camaraderie and epic adventures with friends.

[b]Story\Dialogue:[/b]
	- No traditional narrative, the lore-rich world and environmental storytelling immerse you in Norse mythology.
	- Minimal dialogue emphasizes the game's focus on progression, exploration and player-driven experiences, allowing your journey to unfold organically.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
	- Surprisingly charming low-poly visuals blend seamlessly with the game's atmospheric lighting and environmental effects.
	- Despite its simplicity, Valheim's art style effectively conveys the game's immersive Nordic setting, evoking a sense of every frame a painting.

[b]Before you Play:[/b]
	- Recommend playing this game with friends where possible.
	- Use a guide to progress otherwise can quickly find yourself aimless and bored. 
[url=https://www.ign.com/wikis/valheim/Progression_Guide] IGN Progression Guide [/url]
	- Look around for Map Seeds suited to what you're looking for (eg. Optimisation, Beauty, House Building, Dungeon, Bosses). A mix of all I would recommend is seed: lE0bxYKtaR
	- Character you create and migrate across multiple different campaigns so you don't have to restart progression.
	- Meat focuses on Health (Combat focused), Berries focus on Stamina (Exploration\Mining focused).
	- Different weapons will be better for different enemies.

Even though early access has dragged on forever and a day or two, this is an absolutely excellent game, even pre-Firelands update.  Although not as graphically pleasing as many other survival-crafting titles, there's something to be said about the cumulative effect of the music, dreamlike aesthetic, and ease of building in this game.  While some crafting aspects are not straightforward (expect to reference the net for how/what items are needed for crafting), once you get the gist, this is an extremely enjoyable experience that will keep you and your group coming back every so often to reconquer the procedurally generated world, full of its twists, turns, and unexpected (but equally funny) mashups throughout the years.

Basically you're a guy that gets dropped in the woods, and you have to survive and become good enough to kill the bosses. You've got all your best stuff with you (weapons, armour, potions, whatever else). You finally get off your boat and are immediately killed by 2 Lox, 2 Deatthsquitoes, and 10 Fullings at the same time. You drop all your stuff and wake up in your bed 25 minutes away. The only way to get all your stuff back is to go to where you just died and try to get it without being killed again, but now without any of your stuff. You try this 10 times for 5 hours before you manage to get it back. GREAT!

[h1]A Viking's Quest for Glory: A Valheim Review[/h1]
[h3]Rating: 9/10[/h3]

From the moment my Viking feet touched Valheim's mystical shores, I knew I was in for an epic adventure. This survival sandbox game, developed by Iron Gate AB, offers a beautifully crafted world inspired by Norse mythology, teeming with dangerous beasts, breathtaking landscapes, and the promise of glorious battles.

[h3]Gameplay Mechanics:[/h3]
Valheim strikes a perfect balance between survival and exploration. The game introduces a unique, non-linear progression system that encourages exploration and combat in equal measure. Crafting feels rewarding, and building your Viking stronghold is as challenging as it is satisfying. The game's PvE combat is thrilling, with a variety of weapons and tactics to master against formidable foes.

[h3]Multiplayer Experience:[/h3]
Valheim shines brightly in its multiplayer aspect. Teaming up with friends to raid dungeons, conquer bosses, and build settlements adds an immensely enjoyable layer to the gameplay. The sense of camaraderie in overcoming Valheim's challenges is unmatched. However, occasional lag and server issues can mar the experience, though these are minor setbacks in an otherwise smooth multiplayer setup.

[h3]Visual and Audio Design:[/h3]
The game's visual style is a blend of simplicity and elegance, with a low-poly aesthetic that captivates. The environments are diverse, from dense forests to snow-capped mountains, each with its own unique atmosphere and challenges. The soundtrack complements the visuals perfectly, enhancing the immersive experience of the game.

[h3]Performance and Stability:[/h3]
For an early access title, Valheim is surprisingly polished. The game runs smoothly on a range of hardware, though optimization could be improved for higher-end systems to fully utilize their capabilities. Updates from the developers have been consistent, addressing bugs and adding new content to keep the game fresh.

[h3]Final Thoughts:[/h3]
Valheim is a testament to what indie games can achieve. It offers a compelling, immersive experience that combines survival, exploration, and combat in a way that feels both fresh and familiar. Whether you're a solo adventurer or part of a Viking clan, Valheim promises an adventure worth embarking on. Its minor flaws are easily overshadowed by the vast, beautiful world waiting to be explored. I wholeheartedly recommend Valheim to anyone looking for their next great gaming adventure.

Kinda sad to leave a negative review for this game...I really tried to like it, but the gameplay loop becomes an absolute, unrewarding grind.

First, the pros: 
    - The art style of Valheim is absolutely beautiful. You don't need any 4k texture mods or anything to see that.
    - Base building is actually useful and a necessary thing to do in order to advance through the game. The vanilla game already has tons of variety in base building that allows you to spend many hours building.
    - Tons of mods that can help fix some of the quality of life issues in-game.

Cons: TLDR - boring, linear combat. Long grind times to craft/upgrade equipment.

    - After the first boss, the game becomes an absolute grind. You need to collect a ridiculous amount of raw materials in order to craft, then upgrade new weapons. This gets even worse after the second boss.
    - For a game with somewhat soulslike combat, the combat is very unrewarding. Parrying is very easy, and as a solo player, parrying then attacking is essentially the entire name of the game.
    - You can dodge in combat, but there's little to no benefit of doing so. You use about as much stamina as a parry would and don't get the benefit of staggering your enemy and getting a damage boost for a few seconds.
    - Stamina feels like an absolute chore in this game. Your stamina is VERY limited unless you gather/cook and eat certain types of food to boost it. However, even with good food "equipped" (3 food slots, hp/staming boost, can only eat one of a food item until it wears out), running out of stamina doesn't feel like a tactical decision/blunder. Unlike other souls-likes, it just feels like an artificial block, especially so against the large mob enemies (troll, abomination). Battling them essentially is: parry, strike x3, parry, strike x3, run out of stamina? Abuse the enemies' poor pathfinding and walk around obstacles trying to regain stamina so you can parry, strike x3 again. To be fair, this gameplay mechanic would be less annoying when playing coop. However, as a solo player, it is devastatingly painful. You can eventually craft stamina recovery potions, but that doesn't change the fact that stamina is so annoying.
    - There is no weapon choice variety in this game. There's three types of non-status damage: pierce, blunt, slash. Pierce are spears/arrows, blunt is for clubs/maces, slash is for swords/axes. Enemies have resistance against certain damage types, so you need to bring all the different damage types to fight against them. However, that's about as complicated as it gets. Bring a blunt type against skeletons/blobs. Bring a pierce type against trolls. Two-handed weapons exist, but are not very useful as a solo player except for AoE attacks. Bows and arrows are essentially useless in solo gameplay except to hunt.
    - Armor variety is nonexistant too. There's either full heavy armor that slows you down, or lighter armor (troll, vine) that protects against certain status effects, or gives a bonus to a certain skill. For context though, by the time you fight the third boss (and that's going to be after dozens of hours of gameplay), there's only three different armor sets to choose from. For different encounters, there's a very obvious and clear choice of which armor to equip.
    - Boss design, while initially interesting, becomes very boring. They're not very interesting gameplay-wise. The first boss, Eikthyr has a somewhat interesting mix of parry-able attacks, charge attacks that need to be dodged, and AoE attacks. Second boss, Elder, is slightly less interesting. Summon normal enemies, summon static enemies, ranged attack, parry-able attack. Third boss, Bonemass, I found to be absolutely bland. Parry-able attack, summon normal enemies attack, AoE poison attack. That's it. Just a bigger HP tank that has both close-up and ranged atacks and can summon other enemies. A very obvious choice of armor to protect against poison status effect. This unrewarding fight after a very long grind for equipment was what made me quit.
    - Lack of vanilla farming. Yes there's mods that you can and I did use to plant and farm berries, but the vanilla version does not. What's the point of spending all this time building up a base if you still have to go on time-consuming scavenging runs for berries (used in stamina-boost foods)? Yes, you can farm some foods like carrots, but many crafting recipes call for consumables that must be scavenged.

This is a nice survival game with friends. I definitely recommend you play on a server with your fellow vikings, it makes raiding some of the biomes easier and it is easier to gather materials. It is good for a variety of gamer types too because it has a touch of Minecraft-esque building features for those that only want to build a nice home and it has massively huge oceans and continents to explore with danger at the start of every biome. I became so engrossed in the game I started looking at the green light on my ceiling from the fire alarm as a greyling eye. Oddly enough, living in the meadows and wandering at night has helped my real life fear of the dark because I only have the greylings to fear (and they are not scary). There aren't any jump scares yet, but when meandering in a new biome you can run across some bigger creatures that can creep up on you.

This game is in a genre of its own.  Yes, it is a survival game but it's surprisingly unique and intense.

Challenging enemies, awesome bosses, excellent building mechanics, solid soundtrack...  It kind of makes me want to go outside and start chopping down my trees to build a raft.

I was surprised to see that this game is old-school. Old school in the way it is a solid 10/10. 

[h3]Pros[/h3]
- Simplicity was chosen for a lot of things to keep the gameplay an absolute banger. 
- Feels really well designed on all levels
- Not repetitive
- Really fun to play with a friend
- Graphics simply work, kept simple and pixely for that old-school feel. 
- Really appreciate that it is possible to turn off the raven tips. I prefer to play by discovery, trial and error.
- Sea-faring very realistic!

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- Not a huge fan of the music. 
- There are not enough keys to remap for lefties, I had to download a mod to be able to play. That's a huge downturn for me. Game also doesn't allow key remapping programs.
- Had to get used to the mirrored steering. Officially, the boat goes the wrong way, I wish I could flip that.
