Okay, here's the thing...

I fucking love this game. I got hooked from day one and got a decent amount of my friends to play alongside with me. Building a main settlement with the boys, going out and exploring the procedurally generated landscapes to see what cool sights there are to see and where to set up more settlements in wicked cool areas. Working together to take down big baddies and bosses.
Obviously we know that with early access games, we expect an unfinished product that should hopefully continue to progress and include even more stellar content held to the same standard as to what the game currently has to offer. And yes, I expected there to be a long amount of time needed to polish the rough edges and to fill the game with more riveting content.

But game devs, guys... I know you're probably overwhelmed with the massive amount of praise and players that poured into the game from release, but the speed in which content is coming out is so... soooo... SOOOO unbelievably slow. Remember that 2021 roadmap that was posted like 500 days ago? Ya know, showcasing their planned updates:
Update 1: Hearth and Home
Update 2: Cult of the Wolf
Update 3: Ships and Sea
Update 4: Mistlands
Now of course this isn't paramount, but it's what they decided to present to the players and fans for this game back then.

I'd generally consider myself a pretty patient guy, but dude... Hearth and Home came out literally over a year ago at the time of writing this. And then Cult of the Wolf sort of dropped, I guess? But it was small, forgettable, and not at all up to the same volume of content H&H gave us, so I'm not really sure what to think there. But what I can tell you, is that this game has gone from a sprint, to a walk, and then ultimately to an immeasurably slow crawl. I don't want to burn myself out on this really fun game, so I like to start a new world and character every time one of these major updates come out to experience the game again with more content included to sweeten up every new journey through the game more and more. I've been really itching to play through again, but I have no real reason to until there are some significant additions/changes that will make my next playthrough more magical than all of my previous playthroughs, like the Mistlands update, or the Ships and the Sea update, which has apparently been skipped in preference for Mistlands. Which would be fine, if we weren't all still sitting here, over a year later, waiting for SOMETHING significant to be added to the game after they very clearly have the budget at this point after the huge success of the game from launch, and even after expanding their team to "speed up" the development.

I'm probably coming across as overly salty or being unreasonable, and I don't want to deter anybody from playing the game in it's current state if you have yet to experience Valheim. You'll probably love it. But for those of us who have sunk hundreds of hours into it eager for more, the progression of the game is just not satisfying that thirst for more. Like, at all. I understand these things take time, but holy hell... This is a LOOOOT of time to not even come close to delivering on not even half of the roadmap's content.

So yes, I recommend it for the people who haven't played it yet. But for those who have played it and want to get back into it? Buckle up, because we're gonna be waiting an extraordinarily long amount of time for anything significant to release at this sluggish pace that it's going.

So for now, I'm gonna continue to wait and hopefully not completely forget and/or lose interest in the game by the time something new actually does come out, which will probably be months at this point. I'll rescind my negative review when the game devs give us something worth coming back to.

=Edit: *11/13/2022* - I've been really itching to play again, and I've been holding off until Mistlands comes out, but after a long enough hiatus a couple friends of mine wanted to boot it up again, so I finally caved and started up another new save and world. Gotta say, I've actually been having a blast and I've started to remember how I got hooked so easily to the game. I knew I'd start to enjoy it again once firing it up, I've just been hesitant because I don't wanna find myself burning out again before the update we've been waiting so extraordinarily long for finally drops and I look at Mistlands like "... eh." Ya know? I'll probably switch this over to a positive review in the near future, because I do genuinely love the game and think people who've yet to play it should play it, I've just been very upset with the sluggish pace in which the game's development has been on top of the game devs silencing negative feedback and keeping pretty mute during this process.

=Edit: *01/09/2023* - Mistlands was a pretty extraordinary update. New biome is challenging and rewarding, more available playstyles, added building variety and crafting stations, just simply put we've finally gotten a sizable update. As you can tell from my review from a couple months ago I was pretty sour with what felt like a hiatus in the game's development. But now here we are with Mistlands making me eat my own words on the quality of the game. It's one of those things where it really does just needs lots of time to curate, and while the time to get refreshing new content does take longer than I'd like it to, the content that DOES drop is pretty fulfilling. After once again completing just about everything you can do in the game, I find myself taking on ambitious building projects and mapping neat sights and biome generations while I now wait for what will probably be the "Ships and Sea" update. Which I'm pretty excited for, ngl, and I imagine after a few months I'll grow impatient again seeing how much time I put into the game, but realistically I should be grateful for the game we do have seeing as it's pretty stellar for an incomplete game and just be a bit more patient. Great work on this update, Iron Gate! I hope we can expect another quality update and development progress for the next big one, and I selfishly hope it arrives within the new year; I don't wanna wait another year and a half for it, lol

=Edit: *02/14/2024* - We're waiting another year and a half for it

Fun game but playing solo it is very grindy.  You will have to do multiple resource runs over multiple in-game days to gather the materials you need to upgrade weapons, armour etc, as well as gathering building materials.  This is due to the short time of day, your weight capacity (which fills up quickly when carrying metal ore etc), your tools breaking and needing repairing, the amount of materials required and the distance you have to travel to get to said materials.

I would imagine playing in a group of 10 people you could achieve this so much faster, and the game feels designed more to be played this way.

Not that you can't play it solo, just be prepared to invest a lot of time into the game due to the slow progression of gathering the materials you need.  I would say this game is probably more worth it if you are into the building aspect of the game, if that isn't something that interests you, you might lose interest pretty fast due to the time investment required to progress through the game.

I strongly believe this is a game best experienced with friends. Unfortunately I don't have said friends so I played by myself and here are my thoughts. Certainly a fresh breath of air in the gaming industry. It solved my ever lasting craving for games like minecraft but I don't think its fair to compare them two as this is good enough to be recognized as its own game. It dwells in mythology which I enjoy but to be honest I don't recall what the goal of the game was, if there was even one. The game is a quite difficult one where it takes many deaths to get a grip on the mechanic and realize just what exactly you are playing. I did really enjoy the combat system and found it was nicely balanced. But many times you are just running because you came across a monster you aren't quite ready to face. Building my base was quite fun also. Exploration felt fulfilling and there were unique items for each biome. But here are my complaints. The game is insanely grindy. I mean in the beginning its not as bad but once you get to the ore stage, Jesus Christ it becomes a chore. I had to install mods that let me increase my carrying compacity because the amount of running back and forth from the ores to your base was ridiculous. I genuinely was shocked at how much time I was wasting just being on the boat going back n forth. Which is why I say its best played with friends because grinding by yourself just isn't that fun and like all things, games are more fun with friends, which is especially this case. Overall its a great game, I would've gone more into detail but its been a while between writing this review and when I played this game so my memory is quite foggy. But yea I mean the hours speak for themselves so while I did enjoy this game, the grinding got to me and made me lose interest. But I can see myself picking this up again with friends.

I had to change my review.  Initially, I recommended this game.  I don't recommend it currently, for solo players like myself.  In 3 years, the developers have not done much.  There's no official creative mode, and the bosses don't scale to the size of your group.  So, if you're a solo player like me, the endgame bosses are ridiculous.  Mistlands is just annoying to navigate even with the appropriate gear/items to clear the mist.  The mist is just annoying.  It makes things more challenging, but not in a fun way.  And, on top of having to deal with the mist, the terrain is challenging with the jagged features and the constant need to jump, rest for stamina, and climb further up a misty cliff face only to find more mist.  It's annoying because it's constant and you can't ever see a large area of the Mistlands from anywhere, and it's a pretty interesting zone.  Less mist would be great or maybe a larger area of effect for the items that enable you to "see" through the mist.  Bosses should scale to the size of the group/solo players.  And, put in creative mode already.

Open world sandbox game that has probably my favorite building system (besides a few quirks). Playing it with my two friends this has been the best experience I've had playing a game in a while. The game has world options so you could customize however you want it, though it is recommended to leave it on default. That being said while I love the building system, the combat and more specifically the death penalty is something I wish was easier or at least more forgiving on default as right now whenever I die I lose some of my skills. The game has a simple skill system 1-100 that increases the skill the more you do it, but dying takes away some of it. By the end of the day most of my skills barely increase and it makes the game very frustrating, specially exploring. Dying means going all the way back naked and having to build more ships or rafts, using your precious time or materials. Other than that the game is amazing. The graffics make the game's atmosphere one of the best I've seen while still looking like a runescape upgrade. Looks good, better than what I've seen from videos. The gameplay itself is intuitive for anyone who's versed in game knowledge, yet there are parts you can get stuck on if unlucky. It's not permanent, but walking around aimlessly gets tedious after a while. All in all I'd recommend the game if you like a challenge, customizable world setting and a nice building mechanic with buildings looking like actual houses and not random boxes.

Well, slap my ass and call me Sally, after a series of middling games I have been playing through lately, this one blows them all out of the water. Do you know how you recognize a great game? When you think about that game and what you want to do in the game when you are going to sleep or doing something else. That is what happened to me here. It is a classic survival crafting simulation situated in northern mythology, the graphics are stylized, the music is inoffensive in large doses, all of these are a hallmark of a good game. That said there are a few design decisions I do not agree with.

First of all the constant enemy spawns. When you go into higher tier biomes in your progression to do your resource gathering, enemies will constantly spawn while you are doing that. The spawn rate is ridiculous, for example why cannot I clear the area for my resource gathering at least for a day? There are ways to circumvent the spawns like building campfires/workbenches, but if that is the intended mechanic by the developers, it is horrible I would say.

Second of all the game has a lot of Wurm unlimited/online vibes for those who played those games. Yet you quickly realize that the freedom offered within those game was much bigger, especially while building or aligning surface, Valheim clearly works on a grid system as well as Minecraft or Wurm do, but tries to hide it. It can sometimes get annoying when you are flattening some surface.

Third of all the tutorial. It offers some basic information, but it really does not tell you a lot of things and if I had no background in these types of game, I would have been lost. That said I ended killing first boss while still in my rag tunic with stone axe and ended in Black Forest, where my first base was instantly destroyed by a night raid I had no idea could happen. If this happened to a new player I can imagine they would have quit the game there and then.

EDIT: After playing for a while I have to add to my review that I find skill loss upon death horrible and outdated mechanic. There are two main arguments among people that defend it and I will try to explain why these arguments are mostly self-defeating:
1) You do not want to take risks, because deaths have meaning.
2) You do not need high skill level to finish the game.

Ad 1) First of all it is an exploration survival game, this kills all my excitement about exploration. There is no reason to explore. And second of all deaths already have a meaning, you just wasted however long doing something before you died and then you have to waste 5 minutes or more to get to your corpse. I am sorry, but this already has a meaning, the game just wasted minutes of your time already, what more of a punishment do you want?

Ad 2) Ok, if the game designed around low skill, why have the skills in the game in the first place? If they are not neccessary for progression, they are pointless, right? And if you are saying that people would not feel progression otherwise, then you are basically saying the skills are not pointless.

It's a great and fun game but Mistlands biome is a disaster. The biggest issue is the mist. The tool that is supposed to clear the fog around the player isn't working well. Whenever you move your camera or you try to run, mostly during combat, the wisplight does not follow you around and as a result, you can't see your surroundings and enemies nearby. Another question are Greydwarf spawning in your base in a workbench radius. Furthermore specific of Mistlands biome where we've got big ground level differences is that you can't deal damage to a creature that is higer or lower than you, but if this creature attacks you, you get damage. The same situation is when we're fighting against Seeker Soldiers, when they do their second attack and you can be clearly hit even if you're behind them. Another problem is cape when a player sits on krave, because some lower parts of the cape are in the water which looks weird.  
In overall Valheim is a great and fun game but these problems that take away the pleasure from playing and are little but important elements that should be resolved before the release of the biom, espescially when it comes to the wisplight. Most of my deaths in the game are related to the malfunction of the wisplight: often, when you move the camera, your angle is covered by a wall of mist because of it. On top of it the optimalisation of the game since last updates has worsened a lot.
It is very beautiful but at the same time hard, demanding and fun, it even works in a microwave. It is configurable, adaptable, modifiable, it only needs to be able to climb.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Was having a great time playing Valheim, it's honestly really fun and I would absolutely recommend it. But they've had a massive game-destroying bug going on for 8 months now. 8 months. Basically what it does is revert your world to some prior state, wiping out hours and hours of work you've put into building and shaping everything. Loading up prior saves (which isn't exactly intuitive to begin with) doesn't work. Your world progress is permanently altered. You can bring up the console and enter some godmode commands to help you rebuild everything much more quickly, but it just sapped all the joy out of the game entirely. It's just yet ANOTHER bugged out game where you have to do endless work-arounds to get it to function. All the while you're sitting in dev's discord or their website just hoping for improvements. I'm not doing that anymore. I don't recommend you get sucked into such a fun game only to have everything you worked on be wiped out, unless you have a ton of extra time on your hands.

Update: 02-11-24 - After letting the game sit and get updates for quite a long time,  my kids and I have been playing for dozens of hours and have had no issues with world ending bugs. No noticeable bugs at all for that matter. I'm changing my review to Yes for recommended. Game good.

I've changed my mind about this game since its release.

Pros: The game is charming, the world is unique and has an interesting basis for its lore. The music and atmosphere are superb. The combat is actually deep and has varied animations, hitboxes, and dodging/parrying mechanics. Each of the weapons feels unique and has different types of damage based upon the type of strike the weapon deals. The enemies and objects all have varying damage resistances and immunities that make different weapons/tools applicable to use. The bosses are cool and use a great slew of mechanics to keep the player on their toes. The resources and progression systems overall have a great linear feel, but the player can certainly skip along this line at multiple points with skill.

Cons: The game is tedious and too punishing. It was bad enough at launch back in February 2021 and holy crap has it only gotten worse. For example, crafting the first club turns 6 lbs. of wood into a 4 lbs. club, ok that's understandable. Later on you have to turn 45 lbs of metal ingots into a 3 lbs. sword, this is absolutely ridiculous. Upgrading these items (especially late game) is even more egregious, in total it takes 120 lbs. of metal ingots to upgrade said sword after the initial 45 lbs to craft it whilst the sword stays 3 lbs., this is beyond arbitrary to the point of being bad game design. The punishment for death in all cases is the dropping of ALL OF YOUR ITEMS every time plus PERMANENT STAT LOSS (unless you have died in the last 10 minutes which incurs a protection from this stat loss, you also get a massive boost to your stats when you retrieve your corpse which makes it plainly obvious that the mechanic is too punishing without some magical bonus being handed out for such a mundane thing). I always contemplate or outright stop playing the game when I die now (since understanding the game mechanics better). The game world is massive to a fault and I wouldn't have a problem with this if you could traverse it quickly and/or it was more fleshed out, but it is not really either. You have to go on sailing trips often that are only really fun for like the first 10 minutes and after that are just you wishing you had a tailwind when you often don't and you just wait for ~20 minutes until you creep along to the destination. This wait is compounded by the fact that some items are arbitrarily prevented from being teleported unlike others (all heavy progression items like ore, metals, and heavy quest items are this way) so you effectively have to go on these tedious sailing trips often until you have totally progressed beyond the reasons that you would even visit the biome (resource collection). Most biomes are difficult enough that setting up a home/retrieving your corpse are difficult to outright impossible to do given the ai's programming to destroy buildings and swarm the player without friendly firing each other. The boss fights are often difficult to locate and start due to the player needing to find the bosses location and often times there will be many biomes in a row where the corresponding boss simply does not exist (Defeating the boss is necessary for progression to the next biome). The devs also have made these systems much more tedious with updates for some reason, Hearth and Home genuinely is a 2/10 update to me, it added some new recipes which are nice but all of the other mechanics it changed just add more tedium/nerfed existing mechanics the player can use. The Mistlands update is the only other major update released so far and it is a 6/10, it's interesting to have in the game but the zone and progression within is bound to an obscuring vision mechanic so you can't adequately progress unless you farm up a certain item to be able to literally see in the biome (and you often times will just be totally blind specifically looking for these materials).

Overall i think this is a great idea executed poorly over time, the devs need to either flesh out the game so that there aren't constant grind/tedium points or work to remove them altogether. The game has sold millions of copies and has had 2 major updates in 3 years, I get that they have a small dev team but cmon, this is a pretty poor performance for the possibility you guys have available to you.

Why does every viking fantasy game require mods for them to be fun?
This game controls like I'm moving a fighting through molasses at all times, if you just sped up the animations it would feel about 10x more responsive.
How slow this game is and how tedious it is are really what kills it. Not only does building a house take you 3 hours longer than it does in minecraft, terraria, the forest (any open world crafting game) but after you build your house you have to maintain it every 2 or 3 days. Is this game a viking exploration game or is it stardew valley where I have to do f'cking chores every day and make sure I pet my cows? Is this game about slaying dragons and sailing ships and finding sea serpents or is it about maintaining a fence around my garden and making sure my little baby viking skin isn't exposed to the elements for too long or else he wont' be able to swing his sword because his hands are too cold and he's whining?
I'm not saying you can't have mundane survival mechanics in a game with open world exploration and grand adventure, but when all I'm working on is trying to fix my house for the 20th time and it actually takes a full hour to repair all of it, that's a full hour that I'm not playing the "good" and "exciting" parts of the game. Even if I experienced the best parts of this game all the time, the movement, the combat, the tools, the building, everything in this game is in slow motion. I said it's molasses but maybe I should say it's thick honey and your viking is always drunk with mead because 1 weapon swing takes 3 full seconds, drawing and firing a bow takes feels more like firing a musket and takes just as long,  every time you stop or start sprinting there is this weird in between animation that always feels wrong, this game just controls at a glacial pace and much like in any game it's one of those things you just have to experience for yourself. The best way I can put it is that it feels like the game actually has input delay. When I press left click, my axe swings a full second later, that might not be literally true but that's how it feels. When I jump, the game has to process that command, and then the game jumps.
Seriously how do you make an open world survival craft VIKING game, and I don't like it. I don't think you understand how massively you f'cked this game up if I don't like it, by every conceivable metric I should love this game but it's just so poorly made that SOMEHOW a superfan of minecraft and skyrim with thousands of hours in both games thinks this game sucks, because it does, this game isn't for the people who it should be for and that's just sad.

Typically, I do not leave long reviews. Today I will make an exception.. THIS game right here is a must play, only if you like survival / crafty games. Actually no... even if you're not a fan, at least try this one out. It's got a beautiful art style and the game play is so fun. I wouldn't change a thing about this game. The music is amazing (some cello + clarinet hits the spot) and most of the boss fights are fairly interesting / challenging. I've almost poured 600 hours into this game and I cannot wait for it to be my most played. Play it by yourself (with server modifications if you want, the game is balanced for groups) Play it with your partner, play it with 10 of your friends. It settles well no matter how you play it. I can guarantee though you will make lasting memories and laugh to tears if you play with friends. I already am nostalgic for this game and will make my future kids play it. Congrats Devs, you nailed it. PLAY THIS GAME ALREADY!!

Your brain will be very confused while playing this.. it will go from looking like Minecraft graphics to then somehow being the most beautiful game you've ever seen.... like the god rays come through the fog and it's just like... what?! It truly is a pleasure to look at and the soundtrack is beautiful. Just a perfect amount of ambiance without it ever looping and then when fights get intense it has a reactive soundtrack and it just sounds amazing. 

Then out of all the survival crafting games, I find this game's combat to be the most rewarding. It feels like a stamina-based combat system, but it feels really well implemented in this type of game and also the old school Morrowind vibes of anything you do actually levels up your character in that specific skill that reminds me of the fun times in Morrowind. Just jumping everywhere to my next destination to level that up. It's actually amazing LOL. The very first time you punch a goblin it says fists have leveled up and then the first time you chop a tree it says wood cutting leveled up.... Then it dawned on me...my life is over ☠️

This game is absolutely amazing. The interplay between beautiful music, charming graphics, quite possibly the best lighting of any video game ever, and a geography that is as intriguing as it is broad results in a sense of exploration that is nigh on unmatched. The combat takes some getting used to, and it isn't particularly deep, but it suffices; and in any case, it plays more of a supporting role to the main star, adventure. 

Valheim is a game about delving into the unknown and then slowly but surely conquering it, making use of the tools, gear, and goods you gather along the way. It rewards you for taking things slow. Case in point: I've played for nearly 250 hours and I still haven't even beaten the 5th boss (I'm getting there, okay?). It was an amazing experience when it first released, it's even better today, and there's still more to come. 

Oh, and the building is like something out of a dream. Everything looks so good, from the most slapdash little fishing shack to a castle forged from iron and stone. Every outpost you create is bound to be unique in some way, whether it be the design of the building itself or the picturesque vista around it. It's just fantastic.

Seriously, buy this game. It is a bargain and then some. It's great with friends and it's great solo as well. It isn't perfect, but it's pretty damn close.

Clearly people love this game but I suppose it depends on the person, do your research before purchasing.

7/10 This game is very enjoyable. Building your home or castle adds to the game's interest, and your character grows nicely as you expand your base and create better food, armour, and weapons. The combat is also good. I deducted 2 points out of 10 because I couldn't find the ability to bind weapons and tools from the 1-8 keys to other keys. I'm used to a different layout for ages when playing games, and this is a big problem for me. It might even prevent me from finishing the game because I'm not going to change my playing style. I also deducted 1 point for the monsters attacking the base and trying to destroy it. It's annoying to constantly defend my base It feels like a step back. However, I still find the game excellent, despite its outdated graphics. It seems like I might just be unlucky with the key binding.

Valheim. Very minecraft-y.
Graphics are "good enough", but if you play games like minecraft, you're not that bothered about graphics are you?
Gameplay is satisfying. Cathartic, even.
Starting off in a little wooden shack (often one you stumble across), and building up to a massive stone castle (complete with towers, ramparts, defences) surrounded by farmland and livestock.
Exploring different areas, with different things to find, different challenges to overcome.
Murdering all manner of creatures for resources, or simply for fun.

About my only 'gripe' with the game so far, is the digging. You can't dig 'under' the surface - you can only pull the surface down to your level - and you can only lower the surface so far (it remembers where it 'was') before it stops you.
Hours speak for themselves, one of the best craft survivals out period.

Don't get me wrong. Valheim is a great game. When I first got the game 3 years ago I sailed the treacherous seas, seeing all that was available to me. Eventually though, the map turned from beautiful completed biomes to vast empty plateaus promising future content to fill the zones of fire, ice and mist. I sailed those seas 3 years later, saw the same biomes, saw the same enemies, and still see the same vast empty plateaus promising more content to come later. In the 3 years since early access launch there has been 1 major content update. The mistlands. It's an interesting and unique biome with plenty to explore. But it is the weakest biome in the game in terms of depth and content. 3 years with a single major update is not enough in my opinion. I understand the small team working on the game are putting in the effort, but it's just coming far too slowly for it to matter. At the rate current development is going we'll likely see the next major patch in early 2025 at best presumably bringing a single new biome and a single new boss along with possibly some new tech to unlock. It to me seems like the developer is struggling to find ways to fit more in and make it seem meaningful. It's reasonable but I hope that we see more sooner. Until then my review stays a negative. It's a great game, but it NEEDS a faster development schedule.

After spending a few hours with this game, I found it quite underwhelming. Despite the hype surrounding it, it didn't seem to bring anything new to the table. I would advise potential players to thoroughly check out reviews and gameplay information before making a purchase, as it might not appeal to everyone

This has quickly become one of my favorite games. It's got great pacing, and is largely self-directed. There's no world level timer you're racing against, you can proceed through everything (or not) at your comfort level. It's got a great balance of base "chores" you can do when you don't feel like fighting, but easy to access exploration and combat. With the default settings you're never quite "safe" because raids can happen at your base any time, but you can adjust those settings as well if you just feel like building something.

If you're just starting, there are a couple mechanics that are easy to miss, most critically that food is a mechanic. You can't starve, but you can't heal without eating. Your available HP and stamina are tied to your foods, so it can actually be more critical to have better food than it is to have better armor and weapons. The other one that often catches people is that progress is biome-based. If you haven't beaten the boss of the biome you're in, you're likely not ready to head to the next one. The hints for what the next biome to go to are a little thin as well, but if you pay attention to what the bosses drop you can usually figure out where you should head next.

At the end of the day, I'd describe it as a viking-themed Minecraft with better combat mechanics, and an amazing atmosphere. There's nothing quite like raiding an enemy village, bringing the spoils back and then just watching the sunset as they process in your smelter.

It's too grindy right now. Yes, the game is beautiful, the combat and building are both fun, but there is this thing where you need *way* too much metal for equipment and upgrades, can't use portals while carrying it, and the world map is so very expansive that it's days of hard work, in real life, to get equipped. I am aware that you can use carts, but then you have to build roads, which is *also* very hard work. And very tedious.

If you're okay with this, then you should get it. If you're not, you should wait for the numbers to get adjusted as the game matures.

What a nice idea for a survival game, but huge problems in game mechanics, balancing and consistency.
First the good stuff: Simple (minecrafty), yet somehow still nice graphics, very good athmosphere, weather is beautifully implemented graphically, good sounds. And the building engine offers many possibilities and is quite comfortable.
The basic game idea is Tribes of Midgard in a 3D engine, which is nice

Unfortunately this game also has massive bugs and problems, that desperately need addressing, but I'm afraid the developers don't intend fixing them. Here are the worst of these:
- Food: In a hungry state you have only 20-30% of your normal hit points and stamina, which is absurd. Imagine soldiers or athletes being unable to perform when they skip a meal once.
- Stamina: Theres too much focus on stamina. Every move decreases your stamina and for the whole gaming experience you are on a shortage of stamina, pausing every couple of seconds. Even with good food, you cannot do continuous tasks without taking breaks all the time. Annoying and doesn't add to fun playing.
- Melting metals: In other survival games you can fill the furnace with enough ingredients, so it will melt on itself for a while and you can go on adventures in the meantime. But in Valheim, you have to resupply the furnace with metals or coal every couple of seconds, which results in a huge amount of time wasted on uninsteresting stuff like carrying coal to the furnace..
- Weather: It is raining 50% of the time. I know of no place on earth, where this is the case. Not even in the northern european regions, where this is supposed to take place. It is just annoying, because it reduces your stamina regen and without stamina you can't really do anything useful.
- Fighting: In melee it's impossible to hit a foe when he is standing slighty above or below you in spite of distance. The hit area of your weapon seems te be almost exactly in front of your avatar, looking up or down doesn't change that. That's an ugly bug in the engine.
- Monster spawning: When you make noise at night, it not only attracts monsters, they literally and magically spawn right beside or behind you. I really miss the consistency of other games like ark, where all monsters have some kind of life cycle with a certain amount of consistency where they move and what they do.
- Monster nests: There are nests, where monsters are spawning. When you kill those, the nest spawns the same number of new monsters that you just killed. So the more monsters you kill, the more spawn. Not only is this some kind of weird game logic, it also displays a lack of any kind of consistency when unlimited spawns in a short amount of time are possible.
- Monster AI: Monsters attack you relentlessly even when they cannot damage you because of your armor. Also very annoying and doesn't add to the experience.

Those are my personal top 8 weaknesses or design flaws. They could be fixed easily with an update or some by more world settings, but overall I have the impression that the developers put a ton of effort into making the game really inconvenient, but they forgot to give the fun aspect of gaming the proper attention.

Back for a new review after nearly 3 years and the next major biome added recently last year...

TL:DR - it's great, already feels mostly complete for an EA game and TOTALLY worth the money

This game is - in all honesty and experience of the many games I have played - the greatest Early Access game I have ever purchased and played. Even when I got it mid-2021, I felt it was almost entirely bug-free for my many hours put in originally, and had a lot of replayability even for an unfinished EA game.

Now, years later, they have made a lot of improvements and finished one of the 3 major unfinished biomes, with boss included. I am currently on a 150hr playthrough with a friend who never really got into it and only made it to the swamp. We have had a blast and still trying to conquer the Mistlands now. I think the devs have done an excellent job. A lot of people still complain about the game being unfinished in only 3 years times, or the original roadmap being quickly changed to represent the huge influx of players, but they don't really deserve the hate. They have continuously worked on the game and been clear and open about their vision and team. Most of the promised content was not removed, but rather pushed back to do the many bugfixes and QoL changes that was required from a game going expectantly viral. And now the next major biome is half way to being complete and hopefully ready to play.

If you ever wanted to play a challenging open-world survival-builder game, this should top your list. Also, the graphic and sound design in the Mistlands and of the Gjall are TOP tier

I love Valheim, both for its world and its mechanics. Some have been complaining about the steep difficulty curve when going into harder biomes, but I think it's great for the longevity of the game. Every biome is a new challenge, and even after you've "mastered" the latest one (Mistlands), it's still no breeze visiting there. The base building is a lot of fun, crafting has a feel of progress, and the UI is easy to use. I would recommend modding a bit for improved quality of life, but it's not mandatory.

Se dovessi descriverlo con poche parole potrei ridurre il tutto (male) a "minecraft coi vichinghi". Se dovessi essere un pò più onesto e dettagliato di così, probabilmente dovrei scrivere "Minecraft, coi vichinghi e le bestemmie". Tante. Perchè Valheim ti mette a contatto con la mitologia norrena, e dopo un pò il P***o Odino ci scappa. E anche Thor, che non vogliamo che il padre si senta solo, senza il figlio.
A metterlo sulla carta, non è nulla di nuovo: una serie di biomi diversi, con difficoltà crescente ed un sistema di crafting molto articolato. Un boss per ogni bioma, tirato giù uno, si cambia bioma e si procede migliorando equip, costruendo una base, nutrendosi di bacche e schifezze fino al boss successivo.
Il punto è che Valheim è un capolavoro.
Nel tempo ho sentito molta gente criticare la grafica, le musiche, mia nonna e tutta la nazionale di curling canadese del 1987.
Le critiche rivolte a questo gioco andrebbero considerate come supposte e quindi lasciate dove solo le supposte devono stare. 
Mi sono sempre definito come una escort dei titoli di crafting, non appena ne esce uno anche solo vagamente definibile come "decente" la mia compulsività prende il sopravvento sul mio conto corrente ed ecco che qualche centinaia di ore della mia vita se ne va per scegliere quale materiale sta meglio in cucina.
Se poi, nel processo mi trovo di fronte un titolo veramente bello, ne resto rapito e Valheim lo è davvero, davvero tanto.

For those who have a tendency to addiction, this game is contraindicated. It's a real drug, i immersed into the game like a little schoolboy. Amazing visual, great ambience, giant open world that you want to explore and, of course, construction. All these factors make time to go by unnoticeably.

★★★★★

I'm playing computer games since 1980s - and lately not as much, obviously.

This game's design is almost perfect. Progression is almost perfect and makes perfect sense. I honestly don't remember a game where design and progressions are thought out almost as good. 

A piece of advice: get to wiki, youtube videos, etc. only when you're out of options completely or completely lost. A huge chunk of the game fun is discovering / experiencing game yourself.

Valheim can be challenging, but it's never boring. Building / farming / taming animals is nice activity that compliments major gameplay nicely. Building stuff is one of favorite aspects of this game. You can create pretty amazing things with quite limited tools you're given - and as a result you get attached to your creations way more than one'd expect. Also, ability to attach almost anything to walls / horizontal spaces - I'm talking about weapons / armor and especially trophies collected from killed monsters give this construction additional layer of personalization and connection to the world. Just pop a troll head to some unexpected area and you'll have a nice memory every time you pass it ;) 

'Raids' can be quite a fun challenge if you're not prepared; when mobs destroy your tamed animals farms you feel devastated and experience emotions you'd never thought you can experience from a videogame. You get attached to this world, to your home / bases in a very special way. Not a lot of games can achieve that.

The most amazing feature of this game is ability to generate stories. You'll get your own stories in no time, but here are couple of mine:

1) Went to find a first swamp which was absent on my home continent and saw some tall trees in water from a distance; decided to park in nearest 'meadows nice-looking abandonded village' nearby. Once disembarked I ran across 'abandoned' house and faced draugr archer with his friends - this village as I later figured had 3 draugr spawns in houses. Killed in 2 shots (first meeting with draugr) - and it was quite a challenge to swim back to that spot almost naked on a raft for 2 in game days (and in the middle of the night) (!) and get my stuff back.

2) First swamp visit is quite memorable, but it was especially memorable for me: got into a first crypt and crypt spawned 2-star archer out of pile which I didn't spot in time. He killed me almost instantly. 2-star archer is very OP - it took me quite a time to get my bronze-age top-tier stuff back.

3) First fight with Bonemass was quite a memory. I've died too close to my 'house' right next to swamp; my favorite base at that point of the game and waking up naked to blobs and skeletons running around your bed while Bonemass is destroying half your house while you try to hysterically get some of your stuff from your grave is one of the things I'll never forget.

....

There are few more stories like that; but without a doubt this game captured something special for me. It's not a game, it's an experience. You might find something similar in another game, but for me, honestly it's unprecedented. I don't know for how long I'll be playing that but it's amazing deep experience like no other no one should miss. Will be interesting to see what they'll do with a game once it's fully done.

Still chipping away at it, but a very good impression so far. My actual playtime without sitting in the pause menu is probably closer to 30 hours at this point.

Great building system, good soundtrack, wonderful atmosphere. Combat is simple but rewards skilled play. It's no Dark Souls, but it's still fun. Gameplay naturally alternates between exploration, tense combat, and relaxing building. Game lets you move more or less at your own pace and there's plentiful resources for basic building so you can really get lost in the building part of it.

It's also refreshing to play a survivabuilder game that has meaningful hunger mechanics that isn't just a "hunger bar" and meaningful shelter mechanics that isn't just "need to sleep under a roof."

I've heard the release rate of updates is pretty slow for an EA game, but I haven't got near the end of the content yet so this isn't an issue for me so far. Got the game on a deep sale at $13 but I would still recommend it at full price.

An over-the-shoulder 3D first person survival crafting game. You play the role of a viking preparing for the afterlife. Supports multiplayer.

THE GOOD:
- Great learning curve allows a beginner to gracefully build up their skills and knowledge. Especially impressive for an indie title!
- Resource gathering activities, like tree chopping and hunting, are detailed in their execution and consequently much more interesting than is typical for a resource-gathering game.
- Making buildings is fun and intuitive. You encounter lots of derelict buildings, which give you ideas on how to build. Your choice of location and how you build has a huge influence on defendability. It also looks really cool.
- Super fun to play with friends! This reduces grind and creates fun experiences. Like that time my friend wanted to save time by not bringing the raft back to base. I ran to base, being chased by a troll the whole time, and I returned to my friends in time to see the raft get destroyed and both friends killed! Hilarious!
- Or that time we hurried to sail away due to perfect winds and accidentally escaped an ambush by seconds, sailing away with a horde of enemies chasing us in the water.
- Combat is interesting and tough--requiring skill. 
- Beautiful graphics, low polygon count and textures notwithstanding. Sunsets, and sailing on the sea are particularly breathtaking.
- The weather is amazing. It feels really primal!
- The Viking theme is well-researched and well-executed. It really feels like being in a magical Viking afterlife!

THE BAD:
- Grind, especially those boars are a bore (can be mitigated with world settings and multiplayer)
- It wasn't immediately obvious to me that you "pick up" stuff by interacting first, then walking over it to pick it up. I find it kind of annoying. It's a bit of friction in an otherwise smooth resource gathering process.
- Death comes easily, and by default it's quite punishing on your skill gain (again, this can be mitigated somewhat by your world settings).

THE UGLY:
- We've had occasional network issues when playing multiplayer, with being unable to connect to a friend or a friend being disconnected often.
- The Depth of Field setting makes the game very blurry. It gives a kind of surreal feeling, but at the cost of causing me headaches. Fortunately, you can disable this in the game's graphics settings.

Creative and very atmospheric game with a soothing pace. I'm just 3 hours in, but it starts off great!

Update:

After 200 hours in, I still love this game. Yes, it is quite a lot of grinding. Especially if you're like me and like to take your time and level up so you don't die that much. I think that most people make it through the game in 40 hours, but I'm still just at (latter part of the) the swamp. I did re-start at the last time I reached the swamp, so now I'm at least past that.

The game would really benefit from the development team growing by a few people. Not multiplying, but at least 20-50% (I've heard they're less than 10 people) so the development progress can speed up a bit, without losing the feeling of being a small, indie developer. 

Pros:
* The atmosphere is amazing.
* Great music (I still have it enabled).
* Nice and effective graphics, they really contribute to the atmosphere.
* Fun building mechanics
* Food and recipes
* Good fiends and foes

Cons:
* Repetitive and "too empty".
* Needs more varied enemies. A lot of grinding and killing non-threatening enemies when harvesting and gathering. There more of a nuisance than a threat.
* Clothes/armor really needs separate slots (you're not carrying what you're wearing)
* Textures and models could be a bit more detailed and "beautiful", while still retaining the atmosphere and retro-feel.
* Extremely slow pace of development.
* Bugs aren't getting fixed (especially performance bugs) at the pace it needs.

Previously played this game on heavily modded version with friend and after quite some time playing got me to decide getting it for myself on steam. At that moment I realised my mistake playing this game vanilla.

The early game was fun up to Eikhtyr bossfight, and after which the pacing of the game massively halted on the copper grind, which not only takes a long time to mine a node, it also takes a long of time to transport and process. Having to haul ores bit by bit is not really fun and a good way to spend your playing/relaxing time.

Inventory system is not that much better either in my opinion for two main reasons: weight limit and dedicated slots. Having previously played on a modded client, it quite surprised me that armors don't have a dedicated slot, instead they take your inventory slot as normal, and reduces the variety of items in the inventory at once. Having inventory limit although encourages the use of other transporting method, but with it being static limit and the amount of ores you have to haul and how tedious the entire transporting process is, I'm not a fan of, it doesn't scale very well to the late game.

Having first couple of worlds I played got a very far elder spawn, I'm not really a fan of spending 20-30 minutes of just travelling and sailing, and probably die later on and losing everything you have. Portal could be nice as a shortcut, but evidently falls from being a permanent travel solution whenever you start needing to haul more ores, it feels just like a band aid solution for travelling very far distances (granted they're not being destroyed by some enemies around there).

Dying in this game induces a lot more stress than what's necessary, losing your items is a very common trope for this kind of genre, but when losing everything, including equipments and gained levels it really feels too harsh just for sake of it. This effectively makes secondary/backup equimpents important and thus increases the amount of grind required.

Progression, outside the scope of equipments, really lags down compared to what you encounter later on. Having character getting better solely on food system, although interesting at the long run seems just an unnecessary chore to source a good food just to be able to survive the later encounter. This also ties to character's stamina bar where it just takes forever to get back up and drains super fast especially when encountering a slight bumpy hills.

Having said that, I do like some stuffs on valheim, mainly its relaxing scenery at the early games with dynamic weather adds to the feel for enjoying resting time after a day worth of work (exclude the grinding part from here). The building system is also fun to mess around, creating a beautiful houses and places with its smoke system something to bear in mind, adding flavour on top of the basic build mechanics. The combat, outside of stamina draining super fast, is very fun to mess around, with a satisfying parrying mechanic and feedback as well to spice it up even more.

In conclusion, for me Valheim is very tedious to play and that really is a massive killjoy on my part. It has a good basis for a good game, but issues I mentioned earlier prevented it to be one, if you want to play Valheim for a relaxing time I heavily suggest using some QoL mods (and just mod it to oblivion because why not) and probably get some friend to accompany you on your journey too.

I can not award Valheim my [b]DANGEROUS GAMES, DO NOT PLAY[/b] category, as at the end Valheim doesn't make me don't want to play it because it'll make me lose the sense of time, but because I kept being reminded on how tedious it is.

So, I've played Valheim solo for a total of 354 hours.

While I love exploring the vast open world; I find it to be pretty much empty. Outside of finding some neat landmarks for base building. Each biome offers little incentive to spend much time in it. Basically, grab what you need to progress and move on... With occasional trips back to restock certain items used in new crafting recipes. 

Crafting is pure grind. Nothing more. I while I don't overall mind grinding; I do find it excessive in specific areas like metal working. Everything past Bronze requires too much. Farming is just painful. Both the planting and harvesting are tedious as they have to be manually done each time. I usually find myself hating the whole process; which is not what you want from a core game mechanic.

Combat is passable. However, not being able to hit anything on a level above/below you is trash. 
This also plays into movement where your character can't even step over a slight bump... You literally have to jump over everything; which can cause you to get stuck if too close to an object.

The enemies are nice and varied from a design perspective. However, they are swarmy and might as well be laser guided. Their aggro range feels way to big. This wouldn't be a problem if your movement was more dynamic and sneaking was a thing... You won't notice this in the Meadows, but starting from the Black Forest on you will be hunted endlessly. It's extremely tiresome. 

I think my biggest gripe is the Inventory system. To survive you need equipment, gear, and consumables (3 types of food, potions, etc...). All of these take up an inventory slot; outside of whats placed on the hotbar. At least armor and accessories should be worn... At least allow the crafting of bags to add space... but nope. This crap system negative impacts the exploration & survival angle of the game. 

I want to explore... but 2 minutes of doing so means my inventory is packed. Especially, after getting swarmed by enemies. Limited inventory space also negates weight limits. It even nullifies the strength belt bought from Haldor. Because you can either carry heavy stuff or lots of stuff; not both.

I just keep finding negative cycles like this in Valheim... which makes it feel overall tedious and un-fun.
Despite my reservations, I will probably continue forward till I reach the Mistlands... But from what I've read it won't be enjoyable.
Who ever came up with the mistlands, making the biome so mountainous, with movement so sluggish should seriously reconsider their job as a game designer.

One of the best open world games I've played. Really polished with hundreds of hours of content, even in the current unfinished state. The dev's deep love of their game really shows with slow but consistent updates and development blogs. (I think some of the reviews here fail to recognize how small the dev team is.) 

As a traditionally "cozy gamer", I wasn't sure about it at first, but it's proven to be one of my favorite co-op titles. I've been coming back to Valheim for years now, and my friends and I start a new play session every time there is an update. It feels just as exciting every time. If viking lore, open world games, and crafting appeal to you, I'd definitely recommend giving it a shot.
Good.

The game is a good concept, but it has a lot of quirky restrictions, like not being able to fast travel with ore. Maps do not have the higher level ore spread out across the biomes. You can find biomes with no ore at all or worse no mines. You can waste plenty of time searching these areas to come away with nothing. 
There is a slight work around. You can get a new map. But I have found that most maps have a feature you may like and switching to a new map will not have that feature. For me it is the land. You can work a land and start to set up a base only to find that the map is missing runestones or mines. The inconsistency of resources is most upsetting especially if you run into problems at the higher levels. There are some work around such as playing 2 or more maps. Any resources on your person you can carry over to the other maps. For stronger mobs that come and destroy your base, you can build up or dig your ground level around your camp. I do use this, but I dont like that I have to rely on this. If you dont, there is no real defense other than you and you can have a good portion of your base destroyed after spending hours building it. 
So the game is a good concept but the dynamics of the game make it difficult to stick it out. I have stopped often and tried coming back later. The updates seem to improve some things and then introduce more difficult things making those improvements meaningless. 
Lastly, if you want advice on the community boards be prepared to have your post closed due to rude responses. Then you may have one of your posts deleted due to your pointing out the rudeness. Meanwhile, those rude posters continue to post. I am in the game, hoping it improves, but I cannot recommend it to someone else. If you try it, beware.

I really wanted to like this game, but there are a few too many draw backs for me. 

The building system is extremely frustrating. Why is placing items and deleting misplaced blocks tied to my stamina, it makes the whole experience more frustrating than it should be. Also good luck trying to make a flat plot of land if you don't want to spend 20 minutes walking around with the hoe attempting to smooth out little holes that just wont go away, and yes of course this takes my stamina too.

Honestly the whole stamina system is frustrating, I feel that all I do is stare at the little bar waiting for it too fill up (even after getting level 30+ on most skills) no matter where or what i'm doing. 

Then there's the progression. I feel like just as soon as a finish a set of armour, or make myself a new level of tool, it's outdated. This wouldn't be so bad, but the fact that I cant teleport with ores makes the whole process of upgrading to the new cool material feel like a complete slog. I'm on my first play-through and the idea of upgrading my gear just feels like a massive chore instead of a goal to progress towards. Shouldn't players be excited to see what comes next?

Could be a really good game, but everything you do takes twice as long as it probably should, and there are some very frustrating game mechanics (looking at you Haldor).

I've been playing for a couple of months now, sometimes solo, but mostly with a couple of my friends on a weekly basis on a private dedicated server. We've been having a blast! The game is lots of fun! And with the world modifiers, we've managed to dial the difficulty settings to the perfect experience that doesn't feel too punishing or grindy (at least so far) but is still challenging and makes exploration, discovery, combat, gathering, and building all fun! 

I love how the game's requirements are so low that most of my non-gaming friends with their ancient potato computers can still run it without massive performance issues (a problem I'm finding with a lot of these newer games.)  I also found that the controls are simple and intuitive enough that my non-gamer friends are picking it up without too much frustration. 

Despite the low-poly graphics, there are certain times I'm playing the game that all the graphical effects come together just perfectly to make for amazingly stunning views. I sometimes find myself standing next to the shoreline with a lightning storm in full swing just taking it all in.

For the price tag of $20, this game is a fantastic bargain!  I highly recommend giving it a try, preferably with a friend or two, as multiplayer is when I've had the most fun.

A very unique and chill game, with a great atmosphere and style.

You can either relax and collect materials/build a base or go into more challenging areas to fight some enemies or biome bosses. Combat is very simplistic, but not too bad.

It is a grindy game of course; you need to collect different materials and upgrade your equipment to progress in the tech tree; but the atmosphere of the game makes the task enjoyable. 

Props to the developers for (mostly) respecting the player's time and not creating too many mechanics that result in useless busy work (e.g. you recover 100% of building materials when disassembling stuff, instead of being taxed for changing plans).

This one's a pretty decent game. Valheim is a really great coop survival experience, and it most notably is only about 1GB in size despite its seemingly enormous game world and content. It owes that fact to its timeless, low-poly, yet amazingly beautiful graphics and really good game optimization. It also has a really nice soundtrack, so you'll probably appreciate a lot of the aesthetics if you try out this game.

Something to note however, is that the developers' intended experience actually hurts the game in my opinion. You drop your entire inventory and lose a lot of skill progress on death. Anytime that you go mining for ores, you're forced to transport it by boat travel or by cart, and not through any portal system that you create for yourself. Luckily, there are a lot of world options you can change to mitigate or turn off restrictions that make the game feel overly punishing. The only problem that sort of persists is the fact that metal requirements and craftables get really expensive as you start upgrading them.

Other than that stuff, this game is really fun. There's a very rewarding sort of dodge and parry type of combat, and there are 6 bosses and main biomes for each of them, and there's a great base building element to the game that makes all of your progress feel really substantial in comparison to games like Minecraft where you could be the richest man in the world, and yet your only mark on the world is the two shulker boxes in your ender chest and a dirt hovel you built on Day 1. 

Also note: a lot of players are pretty frustrated about what this game COULD be, and they let that discount what this game actually is at the moment. This game is an early access game that started several years ago, and it has a fairly large amount of content that even I haven't gotten around to with the people I play this game with. The developers manage this game across two platforms, Xbox and PC, and add a major update semi-annually. I won't lie and say that the progress on the game is all they could be managing, but I don't think the heavy criticism of the developers is really fair. If you don't want to buy this game when its on sale, check back in a year or two if you can remember this game and try it out. It's fun right now, and I promise you it will be fun if you pick up sometime later.

I have so many smaller gripes with this game that it's annoying I'm giving it a thumbs up.

I played on default settings starting out and played purely by myself because games like this I do solo.
So I'll just make a list
- Stamina usage for mining/chopping trees (Really? Is this really needed?)
- SLOOOOOOOOOOOOW AS FUCK progression, which in part is due to the weight system and logistical limitations with not being able to teleport ingots. (Low key fuck you developers, Yes I know the cart exists but sure people like choosing the inferior option only via force) 
- The annoying food system that if you have time still on an item eaten, it degrades the benefits with time per the scale it's gone down. Some times of which you can't eat again and refresh your bonuses.
- inconsistent feelings of peace around base, you'll get annoying raids early on but then no raids for weeks? (in-game time) Does it have shit to do with killing the area boss? 
- Slightly annoying slow health tick system even if you have good food in your system, but Wet! and Cold! bullshit. Yeah I'm cold with a leather cap, Bronze Chest plate and troll leather pants, and a new addition the deer skin cape!

If you have an interest in survival games but not too hardcore, I strongly recommend Valheim.

Pros : Devs are constantly working on the product, observing and taking feedbacks.
 World settings can be adjusted to change the difficulty / experience.
 Large world to explore by land or by sea in a awesome atmosphere. ( Wish it would be possible to harness the storm and use it at will, it would be a nice ( team ) combo with some other power ... )
 Each biomes bring some challenges and unique dungeons, be ready to die often if you are not well equipped and well fed.
 Buff from comfort and food, no starving to death. Tho you'll probably end up breaking your legs more often than not.

Cons : Magic is still being developed. Could use more things to spice it up, like runes and more wards of some sort.
 No ways of searching for a tool in the list / no sorting order in the tool list.
 No tunneling - playing with the lay of the land can be clunky.
 Building is satisfying but can be tricky when it is related to being stable and height /  type of material used.
 Can't load the chariot on to the large boat as to make the travel more efficient ( due to collision dmg. )

 After many hours of grinding and defying death to conquer the lands beyond our farmland, friends and I have found a second wind in the game by building a fighting arena, a maze and some jumping puzzles. This is a gem.

I think this has to be the most tedious game I've ever played. It started out as a fun challenge, but as of today it turned into, well...hatred. The current final biome called Mistlands, is, simply put, a headache and not worth the time sink of effort the game requires just to explore it. You work the whole game through to this point, and I do mean work as that's how it'll feel at that point, while exploring beautifully detailed and sweeping landscapes, only to find yourself in the final biome where you can hardly see ten feet in front of you and constantly being one step away from falling to your death -- even after obtaining the Wisplight. 

The default exp penalty for dying is truly punishing, guaranteeing excessive amounts of play for little to diminishing rewards. Bad corpse runs, even with the buffs, can lead to great loss of skill that will take hours of play to replace the further you progress. Even turned down, it still hurts to die.

And as to the crafting system, there is no consistency...at all. They can't decide on spelling, nor the organization of items either by alphabetical order, biome, or type. Get ready to hunt down new recipes in the long list of craftables. You will receive a heads up when you acquire new recipes, but if you're in the heat of battle you'll be combing through lists later trying to find them all.

Should you still be intrigued to play, here are a few tips: 
 - Turn down the exp penalty, you can turn it back up later even on your current map. Like, turn it way down....
 - Make a lot of trunks, for everything. I mean it, make so many trunks you get a headache. Between the pile of backup gear you'll need and the sheer amount of resources you'll obtain, make lots and lots.
 - Build your base by water so you have a rubbish pile spot that you and everyone else won't be running over and recollecting them because there is so much garbage in this game it takes the cake.
 - If your mining and you get attacked, don't think you'll be switching to your weapon quick, it will take a couple seconds of inaction before you can make the switch.
 - Check that the split stack you make actually split the way you want and you didn't just get 1 instead of 10.
 - To ensure your whole farm field is plantable and you're not missing an unseen spot that will later frustrate you, go over your chosen space multiple times with the Cultivar. Oh, and the headlamp item as you'll find yourself planting in the dark 90% of the time.
 - Be careful chopping trees, when the one comes down it can take half the forest with it, along with any berry bushes that will not grow back.
 - Do a food check on yourself often as you start with 25hps and that's all you'll have unless you eat, which the food bonus diminishes over time leaving you with 25hps in high level areas. Corpse run!
 - Good luck, you're gonna need it.

I remember buying this game for my sister a few years back. Didn't think much of it at the time, but I thought it would be a nice gift for her. I remember seeing her playing it from time to time, the message indicating that she'd started playing it popping up on the corner of my screen. There was always a certain small pride in seeing that, because to me it meant that she was enjoying my gift.
Last September she committed suicide.

After everything had more or less settled down from that, I sat down and booted up her computer. All that was on there was Chrome, Steam, Word, and a few games. One of them, of course, was Valheim
She had played this game to pieces, clocking over 170 hours and owning practically everything the game had to offer. She had used every square inch to its maximum potential, and was making ridiculous amounts of loot. It was only then did I see just how much she loved my present. No other game she played quite captured her affection as much as this one. None of her friends really knew about it, however; it seems like she preferred to keep it to herself. Like it was her own little bit of heaven she could turn to whenever she wanted.

And because of that, I can't help but smile whenever I play this game.

I cannot recommend it enough; every bit of hard work the developer put into this masterpiece shows in every single aspect. The music is catchy and memorable (I'll often find myself humming certain tunes from it), the world feels lived-in and natural, and the gameplay is incredibly laid back and enjoyable. It's hard to stop once I get invested in the game; minutes can easily turn into several hours. And now, I play for even longer with my friends, each of us dedicated to our desired jobs. Most of all, however, we're all just happy to be together.

I wanted to write a complete review of why you should try this game, but you probably wouldn't read it anyways.
The game itself is a Open World Base-building Survival type game set in a Viking Fantasy setting, where the player starts with nothing and crafts the basic items by finding sticks and stones laying on the ground. 

The player eventually scrounge enough mats to craft a workbench which enables crafting more advanced tools and weapons and then, when player has crafted and upgraded their armor and weapons, proceed to beat several Boss entities in each of their respective Biomes.
You might want to craft a second pair of each, when you die, you drop all your equipment and need to go get it back, and kill whatever killed you when you were possibly fully equipped.

Still a pretty neat game, very immersive environment and gameplay, the music is the best you could hope for, it really sets the mood right. 
Game is Much better with friends.

Cons: Game Crashes often (about 1 every 30-60 mins), most of my friends went on to play other games.

All this to say it's worth a try, at least.

I played a lot of Valheim before posting this review for curiosity sake, thinking "maybe it gets better later on?". I actually like some parts of the gameplay, specifically building, but the "souls like" inspiration feels half baked at best, because most souls like games have a plethora of complementary mechanics to ensure combat feels dynamic and fair, while still brutal. 

 In Valheim, or as I call it, "Watch the Stamina Gauge Fill Simulator", everything demands stamina: building, running, jumping, attacking, blocking, archery, gardening, etc. But for some reason, instead of making this vital resource replenish fast enough to keep the action going, the devs moved much of its regeneration rate to buffs: food, potions and a rested bonus. Since the stamina gauge starts at a measly 50 points, this means the player will constantly stop what they are doing because big tough viking is tired. While not necessarily something game breaking, it was annoying enough to me that I installed some mods to make it less impactful.

 Another turnoff for me were the instakills. Valheim has a knack for killing the player intantly even if they are being careful and planning ahead (looking at you deathsquitoes), due to how some enemy spawns work and the lack of balancing for their attacks and attack patterns in singleplayer mode. The boss Yagluth is a prime example of this: there is almost no time frame between his attacks, all of which deal heinous area and overtime damage, making melee builds impossible to use even with good armor and fire resistance.

The above problems are further compounded by enemy detection that works via GPS. If the player tries to build, mine, chop wood or is engaging an enemy, others will spawn nearby and 
 join the fight, potentially leading to a snowball situation in which the odds are so stacked against them their only options left are to run or die. This happens ALL THE TIME, so something as simple as setting a basic shelter or gathering wood takes way longer than it should. 

 All in all, I don't dislike Valheim but I wouldnt reccomend it to anyone looking for a fair, balanced game. It can be very engrossing at times with its beautiful visuals and lands to explore, but absolutely infuriating due to poorly designed combat and resource mechanics. I'll return to it after it's been updated some more.

Valheim: Where My Viking Dreams and Wood Chopping Skills Collide!

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Oh, Valheim, you magnificent Norse masterpiece! This game has turned my living room into a Viking saga filled with hilarity and unexpected tree-related accidents. Let me just say, if I were a Viking, I'd be the one known for building a majestic log cabin... on top of myself.

First off, the graphics are so good that even Odin would be jealous. I mean, who wouldn't want to embark on a perilous journey across a beautiful, procedurally generated world filled with stunning landscapes and low-poly deer that just want to boogie?

The crafting system is so intuitive that I'm convinced my character is secretly a master chef. Forget battling mythical creatures; I'm out here creating culinary masterpieces with the precision of a Michelin-star chef. Move over, Gordon Ramsay, there's a new Viking in the kitchen!

Now, let's talk about the combat system. I've never felt more like a Viking warrior than when I accidentally threw my weapon into the ocean while trying to impress some sea serpents. Who needs weapons anyway? My fists are my truest companions on this wild journey!

But let's not forget the real star of the show – wood chopping. I've chopped down more trees than a beaver on a caffeine high, and I've got the deforested landscapes to prove it. If tree-felling was an Olympic sport, I'd be the undisputed champion with my gold medal made from recycled wood.

In conclusion, Valheim has become the epic saga of my virtual Viking life. From accidental drownings to tree-chopping escapades, every moment is an adventure filled with laughter and unexpected mishaps. So, grab your mead, don your finest loincloth, and join me in the world of Valheim – where even the most tragic mishaps turn into legendary tales! Skål! 🍻

Despite this being a negative review I recommend this game only for those who have never played anything like it before and have a ton of time on their hands For 3 main reasons:

1. The game is extremely padded to make up for its small amount of content without using console commands thanks to its heavy handed grind for the same reasons everyone else brings up.

2. The gameplay loop gets stale after the black forest. The gameplay loot consists of 15 minutes preparing everything for a journey to another island, 20 minutes to an hour of sailing to new biome, setting up a base, looking for a node and mining resources for 20+ minutes, another 20 mins to an hour sailing back to the base with your upgraded crafting tables so you can craft new stuff, doing the previous 2 things multiple times so that you can get the armor necessary to fight the biome's boss, and then doing the same thing over again for the next biome.

3. This game is the quintessential definition of wide as the ocean deep as a puddle. No, early access doesn't mmatter since the finished biomes are finished and that is the end of it. A game being in early access doesn't necessarily mean it gets magical abilities that allow it to transform its entire formula whenever, especially when the devs take a whole year to release one new biome.

In conclusion, if you're thinking about buying this game and haven't played Terraria or Minecraft, but have played games similar to it, I highly recommend the latter two. If you're younger and/or have a bunch of time to waste, and haven't played anything similar, I recommend this game.

Valheim is worth Every Penny. 
Started out as an Early Access game with just a few bosses, but endless amounts of opportunity for enjoyment. Now its a mostly complete game with tons of items and recipes to discover, a full slew of bosses and biomes, and endless building fun. 
My friend and I put around 200 hours into it in the first few weeks.
You can easily get carried away with the building system and forget that there are other activities to do and enemies to fight.
Dont knock the graphics until you play it. They seem simple, but simple is often a good thing. The lower poly graphics allow the game to run smoothly, and lighting effects make the game feel beautiful and immersive.

The game captures a grand sense of adventure and exploration not seen in many modern video games today. Sailing into the unknown and encountering mysterious creatures, venturing into harsh climates with enemies that can quickly dispatch you, summoning massive bosses for the first time, not knowing what to expect. Each new area you encounter has a very distinct "feel" to it. The devs did a remarkable job crafting the music, lighting and weather for each of them to give a diverse life to the world. Cant wait for Ashlands!

My main personal recommendations for first time players: 
1. Dont google anything. Have fun figuring the game out and adapting to the unknown. The first playthrough is always better without spoilers. 
2. You can never be under-prepared. Bring extra food, pickaxe, camp supplies on your journeys.
