Valheim has something for every player, an immersive world with detailed back story and player paced plot development. A world in which a player can build detailed structures, forges, armour, weapons, decorations and magical  portals. Woodwork/Metalwork and cookery are all important in the scheme of advancement. 
The differing biomes, increasing in difficulty are vastly different environments with their own varied materials to harvest but also  obstacles, foes and  bosses that require a player to adapt their style of combat play. 
As a sandbox game there is a unique procedure generated world for each player/co-op team and it is possible to spend many hours enjoying sailing/exploring/hunting and foraging without it ever feeling boring.
I'm over a 1000+ hours in and in no hurry to finish up, kill the last boss and leave!

[b]Absolutely amazing game![/b]

Me and some friends got this game in a moment where we had no idea what to play, but we wanted something that: [i]will be fun, won't feel like a second job, and will have a purpose[/i] (as in something to do in order to progress). And boy, oh, boy... does this game tick all the boxes!

Valheim is a survival game that is [b]fun[/b]! We can fight mobs, we can build things, we can explore the map, we can discover new and better items or we can simply fool around laughing. 

And guess what? We can do that [b]at our own pace[/b]! Can't play today? No worries, the vikings world will be there tomorrow or next week and it won't feel like you're left behind. If one of us wants to play alone he can do that just fine, [u]as long as he doesn't fight the next boss[/u] (that's "leveling up" the whole map for all of us). We mainly like to explore, build, level up our skills, or even grind materials when we play solo.

Also the [b]game progression[/b] is an excellent element that [b]keeps you motivated to play[/b], in case you're getting bored easily by just building nice stuff. The mechanic is quite simple: farm materials -> build better gear -> kill next boss -> boss unlocks new materials -> repeat. The great stuff is that you can take your sweet time at each progression and just explore or build. There's absolutely no hurry to advance fast if you don't want to. Maybe the new building materials.

I'm only 30 hours in the game so far, and at this pace I think I will easily reach 200 before I even finish the progression, and then just build new stuff and explore what I may have missed indefinitely, until I eventually get bored.
nice peaceful atmosphere with fun game play

An absolute gem.
However it has to be said co-op online is still a god awful desync mess, mainly due to the low send/receive limit that is hard coded into the server.
This means that when you do something like take your character to a populated area on the server it has to send all that information about all the buildings/players through an artificially limited very narrow pipe.
Here's hoping they fix this and the constant stuttering outside of world saving, as it's such a let down for players trying to group with friends.
Until then its a thumbs down for those like myself wanting to stabley enjoy co-op.
This game is phenomenal, from the graphics to the combat and progression, every part of this game is perfect for any looking to play a well structured survival game (especially with friends)

Valheim is a great game to play with friends or even alone. The game offers a really good variety of accessibility options so you can customize your experience to be as difficult or relaxing as you want it to be. My favorite part about the game is that it offers a skill based leveling system, where you level up the skills that you are actually using. I love this kind of system as it offers me a unique gameplay experience based on how I want to play. Whether you're looking for a challenge or a sandbox to relax in, Valheim is the game for you.

This game just loves to waste your time.

There is not enough settings for your world. I wish we could adjust more than just death penalty and portal settings.

I really like the music and art style of this game. Getting that immersion early on felt great but it all fell apart after the 1st boss.

There is no character progression like XP or atributes which is interesting. All of you HP and Stamina (and othe stats) is determined by food you eat.

Getting resources is tedious as you are constantly over the small weight limit (this is even worse later as your armor gets heavier as well). Trying to use the cart to get the resources to your base is extremely hard and you will get stuck on small obstacles (like bushes or branches) or end up in air.

The building system is actually pretty decent and building your base is fun.
Crafting is missing some quality of life like pulling resources from nearby chests.

The combat is pretty bare bones but it gets the job done. You have a light attack, heavy attack, block and a dodge (which is awkwardly bound to shift + some key by default). Perfect blocking can lead to counter blows for extra damage which is always nice. 

Enemies are varied and have weaknesses to specific damage types which is pretty cool (though again you are limited by weight so you can't carry many weapons).

Exploration is okay-ish. There are some dungeons (in Black Forest) but they usually have like 1-3 rooms with same loot and few skeletons.
I never managed to find a swamp after 5+ hours and just gave up on the game.

games concept is great and has a lot of potential. However, it has many glaring issues and bugs that are just unacceptable. On top of that many tedious and annoying "features". I've played this game with a group of friends in a server and we're all extremely fatigued from the many problems we encounter daily and only dragging on since we're almost done with the game(currently mistlands). I'm so over a lot of the issues we've encounter including items such as refined eitr, iron etc. getting voided by their respected forge or forge equivalent machines as well as the dreadful lag. I hope the game improves, I like it fundamentally and as a concept as well as bits and pieces of it but this shit is tiring.

Edit 1: after talking with some of the friends in the group a few glaring issues mentioned above would be:
1. Hill combat is dreadful. Without the combat mod this is the worse, too often are there times where you're fighting a seeker on a hilly terrain or it's wedged into the small space on the side of a giant skull in a dvergr excavation site. We had one of our friends die to that.
2. Stamina regen rate. They feel strongly that stamina system sucks. I partially agree with them. I do feel that stamina regen rate should be a percent based on your total stamina. It sucks when you pop 2 or 3 stam food and have 200+ stamina and it takes a few minutes to regen. It should regen based on your total stamina. 
3. Apparently the community feels similar but I did not bother looking at their sentiment(going off of what friends said). The mistlands is not fun. It has many cool elements such as gjall being an intimidating enemy to encounter in the early exploration as well the mystery the mistlands presents. Sadly the terrain navigation is annoying one because of point 2 above and two because of point 1 above lol. The entire biome could work but not within the premise of the current game. Consider the changes above and this biome could blossom more as a great early endgame environment. Also wisp torches should completely clear the area around it, not just a sphere but more like a cylinder because while I do agree with the mist being so high above the mistlands I dont agree with being un-removable because you cant put torches floating in the air or provide other options to remove the mist. Maybe a larger temporary option that is costly for temporary usage for exploration.

Valheim is an incredibly beautiful and immersive survival experience, but it is not respectful of your time. Progress can be blocked by powerful enemies or bosses camping on fast travel portals, and because upon death you are reborn without any of your items, you face the prospect of a fully naked corpse run where the environment or enemies might kill you in seconds. The only way I can see around this is would be to have multiple armour and weapon sets ready to go, which would necessitate hours of farming, which is not without its own risks.

In my case - and the straw that broke the camel's back - the Elder boss appeared miles away, across the ocean, and right on the beach. I sailed to a spit of land away from his summon spot and left a portal nearby so that I could reclaim my boat or re-attempt killing him easily if I was stomped. Ofc I was smashed into next week despite wearing a full set of upgraded bronze armour, but the Elder also eventually noticed where my portal was upon subsequent attempts and finally destroyed it. I face rebuilding that boat and all sets of armour, new weapons, the lot, and honestly I can't be bothered.

I get that it's meant to be a challenge and I'm a guy that has beaten every From Soulsbourne game, I like a challenge, I just hate stubborn game mechanics wasting my time. Maybe there should be the ability to permanently raise your health and stamina to a reasonable level to give you a better chance of surviving corpse runs so that you can stand a chance at reclaiming your items.

I don't know, I think I'm just not cut out for the grind atm as a solo gamer. It's still an excellent game, if a little shallow mechanically. If you like survival games, it's about the most atmospheric I've played and extremely immersive. The thrill of sailing in a vulnerable little boat when a storm whips up and sea beasts start attacking is very hard to beat, just maybe bring a crew to even the odds a little.

I think I’m done with open-world, survival, crafting, base-building games. Valheim does so many things right and I still do not like the formula. I find the gameplay mind-numbing, repetitive, exhausting, the list goes on… On the other hand, Valheim is absolutely beautiful, it’s a unique low-poly, almost voxel graphical style and I really like it. The building mechanics are streamlined and fun while still being very customizable and unique. The combat is really well tuned as well. Not too complex while still having depth and variety. Exploration is pretty good. The biomes have distinct atmospheres and are meaningfully different mechanically. However, in a 20-hour run, I only saw two maybe three biomes. I really wish I could enjoy this game more and totally see why other people do. It’s just too much of a time commitment without satisfying progress and gameplay in the short term.

A neat game with a very unique colourful pastel-like visual style. It has a decent exploration and some great ideas as well as a fun base building all underpinned with that viking touch. 

Unfortunately it is mechanically flawed and quickly turns into actual work. I suppose this is where the "Brutal" in the description comes form. If you are not ready for a marathon this game will end up feeling like a 9 to 5 full time job. 

Just to be clear, if you do not intent on playing this for a hundred hours or more you will not fully enjoy it. This game is a slow burn, and even with a group it will take a long time to go through it's progression. This is multiplied by the harsh death consequences that result from quite difficult combat as well as the need to travel on foot or by boat for all exploration. The map is gigantic, segmented into islands and even with portals the risk of losing an entire hour of exploration/progression because you died in a bad spot is ever-present. 

Ultimatively I ended up not liking it. Every idea I had and every exploration intent I mustered was immediately dampened by the fact that it would take hours to get to that point. Every tree felled, every arrow crafted just became work to get to the fun parts, exploration, combat and building.

These may be symptoms of my solo experience, but even in a group this work would simply have to be divided and the boring downtime of sailing and walking endlessly would be the same, so I don't know. 

Buy this if you have hundreds of hours to spare and a friends group that you can play for hours with every week. 
If you play solo, only buy it if you REALLY do not care about your time or think that the first 3 hours of a Rust server wipe are the best thing ever.

Whilst I adore the aesthetics of the game as well as the bosses, exploration, and freedom it allows.. I severely dislike quite a few things about this game and some things I absolutely despise. Also, to be honest, building is my favorite thing to do in games and its mainly the genre I like the most so the review is going to be more oriented towards that point of view.

[My Opinion on things I enjoyed, not much to say since I'm sure everyone will have a very pleasant experience with this (: ]

Challenging bosses and reshaping the terrain to suit your needs is so beyond enjoyable. I also loved exploring new areas, finding new mobs, and new crafting recipes which gave a serious sense of progression and development.
As well as building a base to suit your needs and developing it over the course of time as you obtain new production blocks and such gives pleasant memories to look back upon if you happen to take as many screenshots going through the game as I do!

[My opinion on the weapons]
There are tons of weapons and a large variety to choose from which I absolutely love! I think for the most part everyone enjoys them a lot but..

Firstly, who tf uses a spear like a kitchen knife in the hands of an unruly child? Why would you hold it mid shaft and stab only downwards with it?? Its attack pattern should genuinely be a thrust giving you more range than a small stick since some weapons do that when they shouldn't (Like an axe that doesn't even have a poke bit!)
The only thing I can think of is that the devs thought getting extra melee range was too strong so they intentionally prevented you from using the weapon correctly.. and I truly hate it. I don't use spears in this game.

I'll just say this right now, two handed weapons are completely useless to the point its not even funny. With how much stamina cost and time to attack they have, I feel like they should be doing at least 50% more damage than their one handed counterparts. 50% just to make them somewhat competitive. Because two handed weapons take like 3 times the time to swing and use substantially more stamina but only get a measly 5 to 10 extra damage.. like, huh..? Who would ever use them for anything other than gloating rights or fashion? For most enemies, you attack so slowly they see the attack coming from YESTERDAY and casually walk out of range long before you even take a swing. I also do not use two handed weapons.

[My opinions on Terrain Manipulation]

But the things I absolutely hate the most is the building and terrain manipulation. It's arguably one of the worst systems I have ever seen and the 3 years I've waited they hadn't improved it even remotely in the slightest and it genuinely pisses me off.

Not only am I incapable of shaping the terrain to my liking but it will with out a doubt be disfigured and uneven. Not only in elevation but also length and width wise as well. If I want to create a square piece of raised ground and build a wall around it, it will not happen even remotely in the slightest because what I make after hours of literally fighting the terrain will at best be a completely disfigured blob mound.

There is also the slight issue where when your cursor is too far away or too close then the game just affects the ground directly beneath you making it extraordinarily frustrating when trying to raise up an area.

[My opinion on Building]

Next major issue is the actual building of walls, floors, and roofs. It never ceases to amaze me how your character is completely incapable of building underneath a floor. If I want a pillar to connect the floor to the ground and the gap is small enough to where my character can't physically fit under it then it WILL NOT HAPPEN.

It's such a simple adjustment the devs could have implemented day one to reduce the amount of struggle I had to endure with building a slightly raised house but considering it's such a simple issue that hasn't been fixed after 3 years I truly think they're never going to improve the building in the slightest.

You also often come across inconsistencies and misalignment while trying to build anything other than a square box, but so long as you don't care and manually fill in the gaps it'll be relatively fine despite being slightly annoying if you're a perfectionist like me and need everything even.

I rate whether or not a building system is good based off of whether the tools I have at my disposal will allow me to create what I want and based off my dozens of hours of genuinely trying to build in this game I can say without a shadow of a doubt its a complete failure of a system. I never once thought that what I had made was what I wanted and never once was happy with the outcome. Even after dozens of tutorials, trials, and errors.

I basically just ignored it as much as I could and built only very simple structures because that is the only thing I will be happy with. So yeah, I honestly spent way to much time on trying to get things to be even remotely functional for me to honestly enjoy any of these building systems.

[What would improve the experience]
Honestly, if you had the farm tools visual effect be a hard cap to where its at and use mouse wheel to change the elevation of where you would build up to or flatten it would make it a lot easier and the mouse would point to what position the farm tool would bring the terrain to.. within reason of course since you won't be able to completely remove terrain like a pickaxe.

And another idea is to have a highlight that shows where to raise, flatten, or remove terrain in order to make it actually flat. That would help immensely.

[How I played the game]
When I initially played was at the start when the game was a true grindfest. I often would create worlds with specific seeds just to mine the materials nearby or use worlds to transport items through portals because it truly truly took way to long for my liking. And with that strategy, I beat the bosses in about 110 hours although I did build a big base,

Then recently I came back to the game and used Valheim+ mod which made the game far more enjoyable for me to play and I cleared out the bosses in about 40 hours and also had a big base.

[My final thoughts]
Whilst the game is very fun at times, a lot of the time its just very frustrating and I don't recommend it for most people. Some will definitely enjoy it but for people like myself I definitely do not.

I could also go on about how absolutely abysmal the games progress at development is in regards to adding new features and content, I don't actually mind as much since what I truly want is for them to improve the already existing experience because the game has a lot of potential and could be even more fun without all the hindrances.
But I definitely have to make a note and mention about how much money they made to the level of progress that actually happened over the years because it isn't very pleasing. I really hoped they would ramp up updates over time but it did not and will probably never happen.

Title: Valheim - A Viking Saga of Survival and Adventure

Introduction:
Valheim, developed by Iron Gate Studio, takes players on an exhilarating journey into the mystical world of Norse mythology. Released in early 2021, this indie survival game has taken the gaming community by storm, offering a unique blend of exploration, crafting, and intense combat. As a Viking warrior, players find themselves in a procedurally generated purgatorial realm, tasked with defeating powerful bosses and unraveling the secrets of Valheim.

Gameplay (9/10):
Valheim's gameplay mechanics strike a perfect balance between challenging survival elements and the freedom to explore a vast, beautifully crafted open world. From gathering resources and crafting tools to building structures and fending off hostile creatures, the game seamlessly weaves these elements together, providing an immersive experience that keeps players engaged for hours on end.

The highlight of Valheim's gameplay is its cooperative multiplayer feature, allowing up to 10 players to join forces and conquer the Viking afterlife together. The sense of camaraderie as you and your friends build settlements, sail the seas, and face off against towering bosses is truly remarkable.

Graphics and Art Style (8/10):
Valheim adopts a charming low-poly art style that adds to the game's appeal. While the graphics may not boast cutting-edge realism, the visuals are consistent, and the art direction captures the essence of Norse mythology beautifully. The game's atmospheric lighting and weather effects enhance the overall immersion, creating a captivating world that feels both mysterious and inviting.

Sound Design (9/10):
The game's hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, composed by Patrik Jarlestam, perfectly complements the Nordic setting. From the soft melodies during exploration to the thunderous beats during intense battles, the music enhances the overall atmosphere, making every moment in Valheim memorable. The ambient sounds of nature, wind, and crashing waves also contribute to the game's immersive experience.

Exploration and World Building (10/10):
One of Valheim's strongest aspects is its procedurally generated world, featuring diverse biomes, each with its own unique challenges and resources. The thrill of exploration is heightened by the discovery of ancient structures, hidden caves, and mystical landmarks. The game rewards players who venture into the unknown, fostering a sense of wonder and curiosity that is rarely found in survival games.

Performance and Optimization (7/10):
While Valheim generally runs smoothly, some players have reported occasional performance issues and bugs. Iron Gate Studio has been actively addressing these concerns with regular updates, but occasional hiccups may still occur. However, the developer's commitment to improving the game's performance is evident, and future updates are expected to further enhance the overall stability.

Conclusion:
Valheim stands as a shining example of the potential within the indie gaming scene. Its captivating blend of survival, exploration, and cooperative gameplay, set against a backdrop of Norse mythology, creates an experience that is both challenging and rewarding. Despite minor performance concerns, the game's constant updates and responsive development team make Valheim a must-play title for fans of the survival genre and those seeking an epic Viking adventure. Raise your mead horn and embark on the journey of a lifetime in Valheim!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Exceptional, especially from such a small team. I played this extensively upon release to early access. I set up a full time server and played off and on with a dozen or so friends, and it was an absolute blast. The game play is very satisfying overall. I am an exploration-focused player, and the way Valheim is put together just scratches that itch. Sailing, exploration, crafting, building, combat - all are thoughtfully implemented. And there's so much room for creative expression. We actually build a sea serpent marine park, went out in a ship, harpooned a serpent, sailed it back into the lagoon, sealed off the lagoon, and then had a captive sea serpent in the middle of our fortress.

The game is fun to play solo or as a team. I've been waiting, but some day soon plan to create another server and invite my friends back to dive into the world of Valheim again. It will be exciting to see how far the game has progressed since release. Incredible value for the money.

I start asking, increasingly anxiously as to why the music changed to this and if that means anything. After a short while, big yellow text comes up; "THE FOREST IS MOVING" We ended up fighting off about 20 grey buggers of various sizes but lost some boars as they attacked our small ranch. Then I logged out and went to bed. Game seems pretty fun so far, will update this review later.

It was a good game when I first got it in Early Access...like 3 years ago.

The devs took the money and ran, and have since stopped developing content at a meaningful rate.

It was a good game and novel for its time, but it failed (or chose not to) capitalize on that initial momentum, and other games have since filled in the void in the genre. 

Yet another installment of the worrying trend of Early Access games not finding it profitable to actually FINISH their content after getting their bag and calling it quits.

I do not recommend this game and here is why:

If you are casual survival player coming from Minecraft please do not play this game, if you play solo do not play this game. I am writing this review in hope for a dev to read this and take feedback.
First of I liked this game, I have 38 hrs but most of those hours were trying to figure out how to get recipes online and looking for the enemy, locations and items that provide said recipe. I still can not build rock base structures.

Why I mention minecraft before?
If you intend to play, gather materials and build freely like in minecraft you can not do it unless you have a crafting table every 10mts from you, the radio is so small I had to install a mod to freely build without the crafting table/bench. I had to literally build  a crafting bench in a middle of a bridge in order to continue building said bridge.

You want to go mine for 6hrs and after your inventory is full want to come back and melt all of it? You can't. The weight limit is so low (300) that if you have a set armor, 1 wooden shield, a bronze sword and a pickaxe you can only take back with you 22 -25 out of 30 copper, tin, or whatever mineral you want to mine in you before you get overweight and have to go back to you base, I spent more time walking (10 min from my base to the copper mining spot) then mining said mineral(3 to 4min mining depending on which mineral I was gathering), so the game for me became a walking sim rather than a survival.

Why can't you play solo?
Unless you want to die every enemy you encounter from the dark forest and up you can not play this game solo. Trolls after you get their armor are easy to overcome, but if  you try to go to the swamp with that armor let me tell you, you will get wrecked by those enemies, the health regen is super slow, all of the enemies in that region use poison meaning that they hit you, and if you run from them cause you are to low on health the poison ends up killing you, losing your stuff and up you go to walk for another 10, 20 or 30min depends on how far you died, if there is a river, and if there are enemies on the road stopping you.

There needs to be an armor seccion in the UI. Why? cause it looks a mess when you see your armor, weapons, food, and materials on the same space, and you can accidentally unequipped a gear if you press wrong if next to it there is food, is not a big of a deal but it will be nice just to have the UI looks clean(I installed a mod for that as well)

You want to play with your friends, you can....but you need to check some stuff before that. I told my brother to buy the game so we could play together, we live in the same house, so we use the same WiFi connection. WE ARE NOT ABLE TO PLAY TOGETHER AT ALL. I don't know how they programmed coop, but every time I "Start the server" option on my world and enter to it so we he can join, my WiFi connection suddenly stops working on all my home devices, even the same pc i am playing with and we need to quit THIS GAME so the WiFi connection comes back, and that only happens in this game. Please find a way to fix this cause the only reason he bought this game was to play with me.

I do hope a dev sees this and fix some of this stuff or adds an option to remove some of the stuff, llike the weight limit.
Like I said before, the game is fun but some of this stuff removes the enjoyment for me.
Don't ever play this game with emotionally unstable people because they will absolutely ruin the experience of this fantasic game. This happened to me .... twice.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
- At first it felt a bit unbalanced when it comes to sense of exploration and discovery, and learning and crafting. (Not as bad as, let's say Terraria, which I call a wiki game because you have to look things up to play, but still.) But later on, when I got used to how it works, it actually feels quite alright.
- No official servers. You have to start your own. (Now there's a happy developer: sell millions of copies, host nothing.)

[h1]PROS[/h1]
- Very good look and feel and atmosphere. Very nice graphics! I love the pixely feel. The mist, the sea, the storms, all weather effects are all fantastic and beautiful. Very nice sound effects. After countless hours I'm still not annoyed by the music.
- At first I was critical of the building system, but then I really learned it I guess. Perhaps not intuitive then, but now I think it's excellent. You just have to see the surface you want to attach a piece to; simple!
- Lovely to be able to build up rock/ground, level ground and hack down into earth!
- Wonderful that you can re-plant trees, and this wherever you like.
- Not much disk space required. 1.3 GB, how did they manage this?
- Never ever crashes or freezes.
- I've not yet discovered any annoying bugs.
- You can start your local game and your Steam friends and others can join.
- Or you can start a dedicated server with a headless application.
- Apparently you can move your local game to a dedicated server; very nice if you try things out first but will keep on going with the same seed and progress but now as a dedicated server (I have not yet tried this though).


[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
I had a love-hate relationship with Valheim up until around boss 3 (Bonemass). Sometime after that I started loving it more. Good game play! Fun. Beautiful. Solid. Challenging. Punishing. Rewarding.

If you are reading reviews in anticipation of purchasing this game, closely examine the negative reviews. Many of them revolve around the lack of current developers and slow updates. I want to expose these viewpoints and how they are expectations of a new generation of gamers and not that of the game itself. 

Negatively reviewing a game of this size and its duration to completion due to lack of updates is preposterous. From experienced players I have talked to, you will easily get 200 HOURS out of this game before you feel there is a lack of content. At that point either start the game again as there is random terrain generation, play with a friend, or accept that you paid $0.10/hr over the 200 hour experience and move on. This game sits extremely well balanced between not enough content and the bloat from games with too much content. 

If you want to eventually find yourself unconsciously smiling while taking a bathroom break from this game then spend the cash and download this now. I once packed up my belongings in a cart at night and set off on an adventure first thing in the morning to settle in a new space that was rich with resources and potential. My girlfriend said I had a ear to ear grin when she walked by. Reflecting on it, I realize I was having similar feelings to the first time I got an apartment. 

Me setting out on an adventure... https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198093251987/screenshot/2295214860600716196/

If I can have those feelings come out from a $20 video game then what could I care if there are only a few developers.

Buy the game
Play it blind
Remember it forever

It starts fine, a whole new world. Plenty to explore, you learn the basics and gather plenty. You build your first home, play with some friends, and cook meat over an open fire with the stand. Finally, you kill some deer and fight a god that solidifies everything you practiced until that point. 

Then the nigh perpetual grind starts. Go to the new area, get new resources, and kill another forsaken being. It's quite fun, all things considered. Why give it a negative review? Well, that fun comes to an abrupt halt after you hit the swamp and have to mine iron. You are assailed by mobs from every direction, arrows flying at you, leeches biting at your ankles. You trudge through to dungeons to get the iron needed to make armor to proceed.

After that, you trek through the mountains, with the wishbone to find silver and kill a flying boss. IF you're lucky, you won't have to go through the plains or more swamps before arriving. Just about everything will take you out all too easily, and then you have to run your poor character back to collect everything he dropped.

And that's the crux of the negative rating. The game starts out fine, the grind is even fun. Up until you're getting one-shot despite having decent gear for the level before. Up until you fight new enemies you don't know the patterns for, about twenty minutes away via sailing because you didn't have the chance to put down a portal. 

You can absolutely change the game's settings, to make it less punishing. But, isn't that kind of the point? I adore harder games, but they follow the idea that death is a hiccup. You don't have to dedicate time to recovering, you just get back into it. 

Compare Valheim to whatever you'd wish, but the resources you gather the regular way are too slow to keep it all flowing smoothly. It is a fun game when you aren't slogging through death after death because all of your resources went into decent gear. It's enjoyable when you don't respawn in base, to get raided. I truly wish anyone playing this game all the fun that can be had, but it's not for me after back-to-back deaths where you couldn't do anything, besides gathering more ores and making backup equipment in case you died.

You know, after you spent hours making the first set.

Valheim is a fantastic game and still incomplete with several updates planned.  My biggest disappointment was chugging through the content and seeing my friends move on to other games.

Edit:  I've changed my review from Yes to No.  Over the past year, many changes have been added to the game and while I think some of them are definitely good, many of them really diminish my enjoyment.  There are still major QoL issues and the designers have explicitly stated that they want people to play in a way that they prefer.  

I still get to choose how I spend my time.  And the reality is that this game was best with friends _and_ QoL mods.  But my friends have moved on and the mods rarely work at this point (at least in part to changes made to the game to prevent specific things).  So, I'm posting negative.

I genuinely never thought I would be into a game like this. Once I realized this was Viking Minecraft I immediately became obsessed and have consistently played by myself for hours, and with friends.
To those who don't game as much(like me). This game has hand-holding and it doesn't.(Feature you can turn on and off).
If I didn't have friends guiding me without spoiling anything for me it wouldn't have gotten me to the obsessive point I have with thinking through my work day "Man, I can't wait to get home and play this."

Crafting mechanics were a learning curve for me but if you do some quick research you'll find so much pride in figuring things out yourself. 
The soundtrack and background music is addictive and well written. You'll hum yourself into a daydream sometimes.
The game is STUNNING. Absolutely breath-taking scenery that will make you wish you could experience it in real life.

TLDR
I am so happy with how beautiful and challenging this game is. Please, give it a shot, help yourself by either doing some research or play with a friend to let yourself get into it.

We started as a Primordial soup. Then, over time, we began to evolve. evolve into fish, then monkeys, then, eventually highly intelligent lifeforms known as Homo-Sapiens. as Homo-Sapiens, we were the least physically adept animals, but somehow we did it. On sheer willpower and intelligence alone, over millions of years, we climbed our way to the top of the food chain. Despite all odds, we managed to do it. we've been through plagues, genocides, and famines. And we survived all of it. All the way up until the year 2024, when all of our effort, all of our perseverance, all of the sacrifices we made all lead up to a single point; You played Valheim, a viking simulator based on survival.

The lack of any clue anywhere within the game on how to do anything in the game is somehow a feature in modern gaming, and it's the dumbest concept ever.

If dying wasn't so absolutely soul-crushing and brutal on every level, it might be worth doing the experimentation it takes to figure things out.  However, in order to prepare for any 1 hour adventure means 1 week of real time prep work.  Most of which is running back and forth to repair the weak ass tool you'll have for much of the early game.  All of which creates a recipe where you spend your precious gaming hours farming just to go lose it in the woods because rested buffs wear off faster than you can get anywhere, then you can't fight because your stamina tanks.

Playing singleplayer is a bore and a chore all at the same time.  Nothing feels rewarding, nothing feels gratifying, because you just finished a fight with something, and there's ten more things and a spawner coming up on you.  And that's the day time.  And you're always outnumbered, outclassed, outgunned and everything is 100000x cooler than you are.

I respect a game for being a challenge.  I don't respect it for being so unbelievably vague on how to do anything.  Or what to do.  Or anything about anything.

If it wasn't for the internet, I wouldn't have even sunk any more than a few hours into the game because it's unbelievably boring running/boating miles for a couple stacks of ore.  Thanks to the internet, there's plenty of mods to make this almost playable, but the fun version isn't anything like the "vanilla" experience, and it's fun is fleeting, at best.

I really don't see what people get a kick out of when it takes so long to do actually go anywhere and do anything because so much time is spent gathering 10x the stuff to make replacement gear for the inevitable "all your buffs wore off at the same time because it takes 10 minutes to get anywhere, you can't regain stamina enough for basic fighting now, go die and start over".

By the time you've got enough of all 3 foods, enough armor, weapons and tools, you can go build a forward base.  And then go farming again.

Go in the dungeon, farm.  It's always grinding some random resource which you don't have enough inventory space for, because everything you touch drops 3 things, most of which weigh little.  The rest is made of pure lead, and you can get a few into your limited inventory space.

It's all of the worst parts of the game on repeat for days on end, with a sprinkle of dungeon crawling.

Playing a game shouldn't feel like I'm being punished for something, and the game feels genuinely stacked against you beyond reason, even for a "brutal, hardcore" experience.

There's a difference between artificial difficulty, overwhelming odds, and gameplay with meaningful, tactical decisions.

It's poop on a stick on it's best day without mods.

My overall experience with this game has been negative. The premise is fun but I simply dislike the stamina system. Additionally night time can be borderline infuriatingm as it is very easy to get swarmed while out of stamina and unable to attack. Similar to souls games, sprinting, attacking and dodging/blocking costs stamina yet unlike souls games the combat feels clunky and there is no instant healing. You simply wait for your health to very slowly tick back up.

Inventory and equipping system is also garbage. Your character will literally keep his clothes/armor in the same bag with the rest of your loot when equipped. It takes useful space and makes it that much more disorganized.

Last but not least it's a walking simulator. You will spend a majority of this game walking on land, waiting for your stamina to regenerate.

Fun if you like grindy sandbox stuff but not for me.

Alright Valheim, round 2

I've reviewed this game before, and recommended it despite my multiple gripes with the game that included:

-Unfair and straight up horseshit difficulty 

-Lack of content in giant world and lack of good transportation for said giant world

-Lack of updates (0 major updates before this most recent mistlands update)

-Gimmicky and unfun game design elements that feel specifically tailored to make the game less enjoyable

-Repetitive content

-No true endgame

-Stamina system and food system are kinda ass

-Lack of basically any quality of life

-Leveling system levels up very slowly and drops far too much when you die, basically preventing your character from leveling up beyond a certain point unless you are incredibly good at the game (which most people won't be on their first and second playthroughs).

-Overall lack of polish

All that being said, I still recommended the game as its few saving graces were very redeeming. Yeah, the game was really clunky and annoying at times, but it was still a great time with friends that was memorable.
The graphics are better looking than real life, the world design and base building are top-notch, the music is everything you could ask for, and the combat is just rewarding enough that it's satisfying to beat hard enemies. It's also important to mention the fuling goblins because they are very funny I think.

I have now played through the game a second time after the first major update since the launch (The game has been out for two years), and am not only disappointed but pissed at the amount of time I poured into it again just to reveal how underwhelming this new update is. To list a few: 

-ALL of gripes mentioned above are either still present or amplified due to the new biome being just as bad if not worse as any other area in the game

-New game-breaking bugs including one where your body doesn't drop your loot when you die, deleting all of your items (which actually happened to me in this last playthrough)

-The final boss is kind of cool, but the item it drops is, I shit you not, a placeholder item. We waited [b]two years[/b] for an unfinished update. Incredible.

-New magic weapons are completely pointless because you only get them at the end of the game and are very difficult to get, being overshadowed in power by basically everything else you get at that point in the game. Also important to note that there are 4 magic weapons in the game right now and 1 of them doesn't even work.

-New biome follows the trend of lame gimmicky areas with enemies that are zero fun to fight. Seriously, they designed a fully fleshed out and beautiful biome for you to explore, but everywhere you go is covered in this unavoidable fog that makes you unable to see two feet in front of you. I don't get it. 

I cannot recommend this game to anyone. The combat and gameplay are too unfair to appeal to normal casual players, and the exploration is too slow and tedious to recommend to those who are looking for something similar to Terraria. I guess the building is good, but not 20 bucks good. This game really only appeals to masochists.

Seriously, if you are considering this game and haven't played Terraria, go play that. It's very similar in progression and experience but infinitely more polished and well designed. Plus, it's half the price.

This game is beyond dogshit in it's current state. It is far worse than most of the open world survival games I've played. 

The movement and general mechanics (Switching between tools, attacking with weapons or shooting with a bow) is very clunky and feels like shit to use. Weapons have no reach at all or just plainly miss for no apparent reason. Bows have seemingly random bullet-drop (arrowdrop?) and work very weirdly in tight spaces.

The food system is also subpar, as you constantly have to keep eating to keep your HP and stamina at a reasonable level, and thats not even mentioning the fact that you are absolutely forced to have 3 different food items at once. 

The looting system is also very annoying; why do I have to pick stuff I find on the group twice??? Why does pressing E once not just put it in my inventory, instead of dropping it on the floor and then having to either walk over it or press E again on its ragdoll body.

A lot of mobs aggro for no reason other than you just existing besides them. This would be fine if they also didn't just keep that aggro forever. You can't just run far enough away, they will keep chasing you to the end of the world. And god forbid you try to kite with low stamina because you died and are trying to get your items back.

Lastly, HOW THE FUCK DOES THIS GAME NOT HAVE A BRIGHTNESS SLIDER. 

All in all, a solid 3/10 from me. Game needs a lot of work.

This is a game that holds itself back by not understanding what it dose well and what it does poorly. There are many more survial games that thrive on being difficult and cruel but do so in a way that caters to challenge. An easy example is that the game can't handle elevation differences in combat. Your attacks miss when you don't align with the enemy vertically, but the world generation insists on making maps with elevation differences. Some biomes, such as the mistlands, have massive changes in elevation that get in the way of playing the game.

Items feel random and so many of them have no or one use, and you don't get to delete items till the mid game. The user experience isn't cultivated for a good time so it ends up being a bit of a frustration simulator. Oh and turn on the ability to portal with everything, Sailing is a pointless exercise once you avoid the first sea serpent. There is no other real ocean content to experience so moving goods is just basically loading screen.

I'd recommend this to players who have unlimited time, like you are too young to have a job. I have played for ten hours at this point. I enjoy the crafting, building, hunting, etc. My problem with the game is the PERMA-DEATH. I know, I know, you're gonna say there is no perma-death in this game. NOT SO. I summoned the first Boss after 10 hours of gameplay. (You would think that would be enough.) I was not ready and I died. No problem. So.. I went back and got my stuff, then I ran home. This thing followed me all the way there and killed me AGAIN. NOW, he is spawn camping my house and kills me every time I open the game. THAT'S PERMA-DEATH. I might play it again If I thought I could progress without having to spend another 10 to 20 hours to make a second attempt. To me, the game is broken, and not worth the effort.
EDIT: I was able to use Cloud saves to hack the game. I set the world mode to just after I died in my house. I set my character to before I died. I doubled what I had, AND the Boss gut stuck in a wall, or ran out of stamina, and I beat him down with no problems. I guess i  will  keep playing and see how I can beat the game with exploits.

A pretty cool survival game that had amazing potential but fell into the pile of a lot of Early access games never finished. The devs for a good amount of time did little to no communication with that changing as outcry became larger. Now we're given dev logs that don't really tell us much about what's next and leaves most as broad as possible. Back in 2021 even 2022 if you had asked me if this is worth picking up, I'd say yes because what is in the game can be an extremely enjoyable experience despite a lot of systems remaining basic or staying surface level with no real evolution. Progression is probably this game's worst aspect now as the further towards the end game you get, the less gear holds an impact. Multiple armor sets and different gear options are basically useless/wastes of time vs the main ore sets. There are more games out there that saw this formula and are more committed to active development. I recommend you go after those unless you're looking for a one and done experience.

And a huge sin in these survival games is to add a unfinished biome that when updated, doesn't add the content if already generated and leaves people needing to restart the world. This was a really good time and it's sad to see how they devs treated their success. Everyone was playing this and now its just another game passing in the wind through dev choices.

I try to 'beat' games before I go reviewing them but it has been a couple of weeks since I last played so I'm just going to call it here.

I'm saying it outright, Valheim is NOT a fun game. 

Valheim's 'procedurally generated' map - and this is said quite carefully on the store page if you take my meaning - suffers from an extreme lack of randomization. The game's landscape is drawn from a heightmap, and you just get a chunk of it basically. To my knowledge, the developers have never commented on this or why this is. I'm no expert either but all I know I was able to generate at least 6 maps all with the same landscape and features.

This totally and completely shattered the experience for me.

When playing an adventure game, one of the key components obviously enough is the adventure. There is no such experience in Valheim. You can run for half an hour across the world if you really want, to be sure, you can sprint around experiencing the fixed weather and wind cycle. But underlying all of that 'magic', Valheim is an incredibly static game. More so than any other game of this type that I have seen.

The combat is Dark Souls, I'm just going to call it that in the most derogatory and simplistic way I can because I don't like this game. I'm not going to give it credit. So you have a weapon and a shield maybe, or maybe you try holding with both hands and then you smack enemies, and you roll out of the way of the enemies and more often sprint out of the way of enemies and it's perfectly functional and sometimes kind of fun when you get to bully lower-levelled enemies.

The enemies however, in my experience, get progressively more boring and less interesting as you progress. The bosses have extremely inconsistent difficulty in my opinion. The first boss is more challenging than the second and the third boss is like way too hard.

The game starts with treants (two different kinds of treants in fact over the first two zones, bit lazy in my opinion). Then you start seeing skeletons, then zombies, the obligatory slime, another tree monster, and then literally wolves. For whatever reason, two wolves are more terrifying and more dangerous, than the first boss of the game, more dangerous than a pack of skeletons even, and more dangerous a pack of zombies for that matter.

And this is because Valheim has what seems initially like a simple and enjoyable Terraria style progression system, of beating bosses to get access to new gear. However, this is the worst possible implementation of such a design because you need the wiki open on your secondary monitor to get anywhere in this game. Valheim does not signal the existence of new recipes or new materials or whatever to you. The only reason to know anything exists is because you looked at the wiki. It's atrocious.

Your progression is so lockstep with your progression through bosses, that there are times when you already have the materials to craft something, but the recipe comes from fighting a boss so it isn't unlocked yet. You are HARD gated and the game will often only unlock recipes, and tell you about them, when you get the most difficult and hard to find part of the recipe, as opposed to unlocking it whenever you find any part of it. Even if you would have no hope of crafting that thing yet, at least if the game told you about it, you might have some sort of goal.

I suspect that travel in this game was manufactured to be as slow and dull as possible on purpose. I don't know why, but it WAS done deliberately. By default, you cannot transport certain critical crafting components through teleporters.

Now, let me tell you, teleporters are necessary in Valheim. Unless you have the patience to sit there for like 15-30 minutes just disassociating while you move around the map either with your feet or by boat, you NEED portals.

By default the game says you can't move stuff by portal. You may already see the problem here.

So you constantly have to figure out methods of logistics to get, usually by boat or by foot, either the materials you need to a location where you can forge new items, or you need to get the materials to forge new items to a new outpost where your new materials are. Either way it's a pain in the ass. The best solution, is probably just to go by boat everywhere because with the EXTREMELY limited inventory in this game that cannot ever be expanded, you'll never carry every little thing you need to set up a new outpost.

And it's COMPLETELY necessary. Unless you change the game rules to allow ores and such through portals. I didn't do that though.

Now, I don't have anything against this type of playstyle, really, it's almost something I would probably do on my own but given you will have to do this so many times you might run out of say letters in the alphabet to signify all your different bases...? Wow. Give me a break.

Why does the game force you to do this? I mean, that's the kind of mechanic, that should be played FOR FUN, as in it's something you do because you find it enjoyable to build and interact with construction. NOT out of necessity. And definitely not as frequently, as this game demands. 

Since there are specific materials like iron that are required to build some more advanced structure components, you are actively limited in fact in the creativity of what you can build, just because maybe you don't want to cart a few chunks of iron across half the world just to build like a strut on the side of a building. It's beyond stupid and I have no idea why this option, is the DEFAULT.

By the way, since everything is stacks of 50 or whatever, a HORRIBLY limited number given how many resources you need to actually build anything, actually BUILDING in this game, is also a nightmare, you need to spend forever if you want to build anything even marginally tall, just hauling materials from your build site from your storage or whatever. If you are used to games like Minecraft or Terraria where you can reasonably comfortably hold all your 'paint' in one palette, Valheim is the opposite of that.

The game also has 'base assaults' where some amount of enemies will attack your base, or one of them. I only ever saw like two, random treants attacking and the troll duo (which was crazy easy once you have any bow and a stock of arrows) so I don't know if my game was bugged or what - but given what I heard about later ones, you know I'm okay with that. Oh no! I missed out on an incredibly annoying game mechanic. Oops! Too bad haha.

Anyway, just thinking about all this stuff has made me angry.

To conclude, I'll just explain the thing that killed the game for me. I stood on top of a mountain and thought, this is the biggest mountain. Surely there's nothing larger. Then I looked on Reddit and saw someone standing, on the exact same mountain, and I thought hey, isn't that mine? How does he have the same mountain. Then I learned about how the map generation works and I never played it again. It makes your playthrough less special, if every single player gets to see the exact same terrain. Sure his may have had trees in a different spot than mine, but it was the same terrain.

I've heard no response from the developers, so I assume they don't care or would prefer not to address this because it's safer for their public image. I bet most players aren't even aware of how limited the worldgen is. Maybe it's better that way, but to me it seems like people are just being lied to, and I don't like that. I don't like being lied to, so I don't like Valheim. 

This game is a veneer, it looks like it should be great fun, and it feels like you should be having a good time playing a fun adventure crafting gathering building game, then you realize nothing about it is fun.

[h1]Valheim: A Viking Adventure Worth Exploring[/h1]
Valheim is a survival crafting game that transports you to a vast and beautiful Norse-inspired world, where you can build, explore, fight, and conquer. It is currently in Early Access, but it already offers a rich and rewarding experience that will keep you hooked for hours. Whether you play solo or with friends, Valheim is a game that will challenge you, surprise you, and delight you.

[h1]The World of Valheim[/h1]
One of the most impressive aspects of Valheim is its world design. The game features a procedurally generated map that is divided into several biomes, each with its own terrain, weather, resources, enemies, and secrets. You start in the Meadows, a peaceful and lush area where you can gather basic materials and hunt animals. As you venture further, you will encounter more dangerous and diverse regions, such as the Black Forest, the Swamp, the Mountains, the Plains, and the Ocean.

Each biome has its own unique atmosphere and aesthetic, thanks to the game’s charming low-poly graphics and immersive sound design. The game also has a dynamic day-night cycle and weather system that affect the gameplay and the visuals. You can witness stunning sunrises and sunsets, as well as rain, snow, fog, and storms. The game also has a realistic physics engine that makes the environment react to your actions and the elements. You can chop down trees, dig holes, build structures, and sail ships, and see how they interact with the world.

The world of Valheim is not only beautiful, but also full of life and mystery. You will encounter various creatures, both friendly and hostile, that are inspired by Norse mythology and folklore. You will find deer, boars, wolves, trolls, skeletons, draugrs, and more. Some of them will attack you on sight, while others will flee or ignore you. You will also find ancient ruins, dungeons, villages, and monuments that hint at the history and lore of the world. You will also discover hidden treasures, secrets, and Easter eggs that reward your curiosity and exploration.

[h1]The Gameplay of Valheim[/h1]
Valheim is a survival crafting game, which means that you will have to gather resources, craft items, build structures, and manage your health, stamina, and hunger. The game has a simple but effective crafting system that lets you create tools, weapons, armour, food, potions, and more. You can also build your own base, where you can store your items, craft more advanced items, and rest. You can customise your base with various furniture, decorations, and defences. You can also build vehicles, such as carts, boats, and even a flying machine, to help you travel faster and carry more items.

The game also has a skill system that lets you improve your abilities by using them. The more you run, jump, swim, sneak, fight, and craft, the better you become at them. You can also gain bonuses and buffs by eating different foods, wearing different armours, and using different items. The game also has a death penalty that makes you drop your items when you die, and a durability system that makes your items wear out over time. These mechanics add a layer of challenge and risk to the game, as well as a sense of progression and reward.

The game also has a combat system that is simple but satisfying. You can use various melee and ranged weapons, such as axes, swords, spears, bows, and even magic, to fight your enemies. You can also use shields, dodges, and parries to defend yourself. The combat is based on timing, positioning, and stamina management, and it requires skill and strategy to overcome your foes. The game also has a boss system that lets you summon and fight powerful creatures that represent the enemies of Odin. These bosses are epic and challenging, and they require preparation and teamwork to defeat. They also grant you special items and abilities that help you progress further in the game.

[h1]The Multiplayer of Valheim[/h1]
Valheim is a game that can be played solo or with up to nine other players in co-op. The game has a dedicated server option that lets you host your own world and invite your friends to join you. You can also join other players’ worlds or use the public server browser to find other servers to play on. The game also has a password option that lets you protect your world from unwanted visitors.

The game is designed to be cooperative, and it encourages you to work together with other players. You can share resources, items, and information, as well as help each other in combat and exploration. You can also build and customise your base together, and create your own viking community. The game also has a chat system that lets you communicate with other players, as well as a ping system that lets you mark locations and enemies on the map.

The game also has a PvP option that lets you enable or disable friendly fire and damage between players. You can use this option to challenge other players to duels, or to create your own rules and scenarios for PvP. The game also has a modding option that lets you install and use various mods that enhance or change the game in different ways. You can find and download mods from the Steam Workshop or other sources, and use them to customise your game experience.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
Valheim is a game that offers a lot of content and fun, even in its Early Access state. It is a game that combines survival, crafting, exploration, combat, and adventure in a captivating and immersive way. It is a game that lets you create your own viking saga, and share it with your friends. It is a game that is challenging and rewarding, and that keeps you coming back for more.

Valheim is a game that is worth playing, and worth supporting. It is a game that has a lot of potential, and that will only get better with time and updates. It is a game that deserves your attention, and your praise.

Tough game, wouldnt say unfair but some design decisions can make it tedious. Some things like think leave weight allowance alone but just give us few more slots so not doing the chest organisation shuffle every 5 mins. BUT tons o' mods and even difficulty settings for stuff like that, so it is kinda hard to hold the "main" game balance against the devs. 

Another reason the above should mainly just be noted, and not seen as a mark off, in case "grindy" as game description makes you cringe is the level of immersion the game does have because of its "rules". Where game can be tedious or even bit brutal in its mechanics it is also very immersive with things like not having a proper chimney and accumulation of smoke leading to you dying while sleeping over night from carbon monoxide poisoning. World feels alive, and it feels dangerous therefore and when you "win" feel like actually put some time, effort and thought into it. So eh, makes super limited inventory slots etc a lot easier to shrug off versus a game that is lacking in that feeling. 

Overall, yeah, deff say worth a shot especially if have an old "minecraft crew" of friends play games with and looking for something different and bit more focused than minecraft, or even just well done survival game to sink some time into.

I'll start this review by stating I'm a long time Minecraft fan and have dabbled in other survival games such as Ark, Conan Exiles, The Forest/Sons of the Forest, Don't Starve, and Project Zomboid. That being said.. save for Minecraft (due to personal bias and nothing more) Valheim stands on a mountain above those other games. You want to be in this world. It punishes you for it but you still want it. You want to explore it. It punishes you for that as well but you do it anyways. You don't want to be in the swamps but you gotta be there and its a beautiful design by the devs because lets face it if iron was not in the swamps we would never go back. You want to get the better gear. The drive to reach the next biome is so strong. Upgrade that base bro it could look just a little better. This game does such a beautiful job of balancing the player with the biome system because in most games once you get ahead of the curve you are permanently ahead of it. I know this is more of an incoherent rant than a review and I apologize for it having no structure but damn this game is so amazing.

Valheim features one of the best building systems in a crafting survival game up to date, sporting a weighty structural integrity check with every piece you slap on the other and with the ability to fully refund structures and other buildables instead of robbing the player of their finite materials, (fuck you ARK and your 2500 metal ingot ovens) shows some extremely welcome quol things I didn't even realize were lacking from similar titles. Auto sorting loot from inventory would be the only thing I'd like to see added in 1.0, along with slightly increased speed to all the boats and more variety in foodstuff, but even without those small adjustments, it's a very solid experience even in early-access. Buy it for your friends and drag them to the smelliest swamp imaginable to farm turnips and mine piles of gunk for scrap iron, you're guaranteed to have a good time with any old viking activity here.

It's a shame that they've gone dormant in the last 3 years and never really provided updates that work towards a stable 1.0 though.

Ugliest artstyle, jank ass combat, 6+ months between content updates, still on 0.2 sequence of patches after 3 years, this game somehow convinced millions to buy and keep playing it. The only 2 things this game did differently that's an improvement in the survival genre is how food works and the boss progression system instead of the flat point one like Ark. Things like having teleportation, but then blocking you from transporting mats has no place in PVE and shouldn't be the default. Other games like V-rising copied that design thinking it was good balance or "fun." 

I am biased against viking settings because we've had multiple games set around them so the setting for me at least was a turn off. The music sounds like it was ripped from a royalty free fantasy music pack, the particles are something out of minecraft, and the randomly generated map makes the map design uninspired. People think by having a linear map it would change your progression to a boring repetitive one on reset, but it would be no different design wise, since you'd start in the same progression pattern as randomly generated one. The difference is, the linear one is actually interesting to look at unlike anything made by a seed.

At the rate these patches are going, I am afraid to see how many years it will be before it hits 1.0. I've seen awful games like 7 Days to Die sit in EA for 11 years so far. I wouldn't be shocked to see that happen with this one too. Especially when they literally write "We don't know how long it's going to take" right there on the EA FAQ.

Original review at the bottom from August, when I was feeling a good bit more generous about the update pace.

The last substantial update to gameplay, Mistlands, was over a year ago now, and Ashlands being confirmed for "the first half of 2024" would really suggest a Q2 release, because the developers have specified quarters in the past for releases, and you'd generally want to say Q1 if you were expecting to get it out during it, unless you're hoping to surprise your fans by releasing it "early".
Embracer Group released back in September that Valheim had sold 12 million copies up to that point. I cannot imagine how you can bring in that many sales and not beef up your team to be able to get major content updates out at least once a year by this point. New devs obviously don't instantly mean faster updates but I have to think that when the team was 'overwhelmed' by the popularity of the game when it sold 5 million units in the first month and they later dropped their original roadmap, if they had added to the team then, we'd be seeing a lot better results around now.
Potentially 16-18 months for a new biome and meaningful gameplay changes is insane, and the content coming out in the meantime has been pretty lacking. Hildir's update was primarily building objects and cosmetics, dungeons that felt like derivatives of existing dungeons, and mini bosses that were just reskins of existing enemies with bigger numbers and a new ability, and only dropped things that unlocked more cosmetics. Beyond that was some manner of engine update, which admittedly eats up a good bit of dev time (again if they'd gotten more on board a couple years ago etc etc), bug fixes which are obviously important, and some seasonal related things, some of which managed to miss the seasons they were for.
The game could very easily be something magical when it's finished, but there are portions of the game right now that feel unfinished or underdeveloped, and not because 'there's content promised, therefore it's not finished'. My main problem is just that I want more content from the game than I'm getting. 200 hours is obviously more than good enough for the price, but it doesn't stop me from being disappointed overall, because I played the game almost exclusively with friends, and I think I was almost purely enjoying doing things with them, as opposed to anything the game actually provided itself.
Maybe they'll change their minds and release content in smaller pieces so it feels like there's a good reason to get on more often instead of one large reason so infrequently that I frequently forget the game exists. Maybe I'll ask my kids how 1.0 is.


OG:
"It's a good game, but buy it based off its current state, not its 'potential', because the update pace can be pretty glacial. 8 months for a pretty minor patch with Hildir could be a turnoff for some."

I want to love this game, but it has major game mechanic issues that make it less and less fun the more I play.
-Each new gear level is a flat upgrade which means my gear upgrade is more and more neglegable as I progress through the game. But the enemies in each biome get stronger exponentionally. This makes me feel progressively weaker, and more vulnerable even though my stats and gear are improving.
-You have to sprint if you want to get anywhere on ground that isn't perfectly flat. Which was an issue I could live with, until I got to the Mistlands, which is an interlocking series of 45° slopes. Meaning I never have any stamina when I get jumped by mobs.
-The attack animations and hitboxes make me narrowly miss the enemy if it's not perfectly on my elevation level. Which combined with my two previous points makes the endgame feel like getting waterboarded with concrete and glass shards.

EDIT:
After revisiting the game with a few more wriends, I still have issues with some aspects of the core gameplay. But the introduction of difficulty settings helped to solve enough of them to flip this review.
Now if only we could revamp the attack animations, and weapon reach, so most of my attacks don't miss if the enemy is 1 cm below or above me, or not actively touching my nose.

The game suffers from an excess of grind and a lack of unique content, making the resource-gathering process time-consuming and the biomes feel empty.

One major issue is the inability to teleport resources to the main base using portals. This forces players to construct bases in every biome, leading to constant attacks from annoying mobs. This lack of teleportation not only eliminates the fun factor but introduces a sense of routine and frustration. In my 43 hours of gameplay with a friend, we managed to defeat only the second boss out of the six or seven available, highlighting the slow progression in the game.

Moreover, the grinding aspect doesn't bring any new and distinctive content to the gameplay. The biomes remain unchanged from the beginning to the end, creating a monotonous experience. The vast and expansive map, while initially intriguing, becomes a tedious journey due to its emptiness. Exploring the world quickly loses its charm as all the mobs and landscapes start to feel repetitive.

On a positive note, the crafting system is well-executed and allows players to build impressive structures, which kept me engaged for an extended period. However, beyond crafting, the game lacks additional elements to keep players invested. Overall, the game's imbalance between grind and content diversity diminishes the overall enjoyment and longevity of the experience.

Updating my old review to reflect current changes...

So they finally added a feature to allow all items through portals; this has made the game significantly less grindy and much more fun to play. 

They also added a feature to increase the yield of items you get when mining/harvesting/etc - this has made the game significantly less grindy and much more fun to play. 

With the recent (and upcoming) content there's plenty to see and do which is now much more accessible to people with less time on their hands (while also maintaining the previous grind-fest rates, if you so choose, to keep the Valheim puritans happy as well). 

9/10

This game is amazing in some ways, but lackluster in others. Overall, I certainly recommend it, but I can't really imagine playing it beyond a single playthrough.

I still remember getting enough materials to finally build a ship, and sailing to sea. Man, that was an incredible experience. I also enjoy the combat, which is lackluster in most survival games. In Valheim, you can get really good at the combat, and push really hard into difficult biomes despite not having the properly tiered gear, which is amazing! The crafting and building are both top notch, as well as the aesthetic. Overall, I really enjoyed the game, and I've had a blast playing it with friends.

So where are the shortcomings?  Every new biome you enter simply ends up being the next "level" to the game, so you're forced to build a base there, grind out all of the latest tiers of gear and building pieces, then move on to the next biome. I'd much rather see a system where you can keep improving on your home base, but you can't teleport with your latest tier of metal, so you're stuck either sailing for hours at a time or just building a new base. This creates a situation where you create a ton of rushed, haphazardly built bases all across the map, and never putting a ton of effort into any of them, because they merely exist for crafting, rather than actually occupying. 

Further, since everything is a clear upgrade in the next biome, you don't have any true build variety, either in your character or bases. You can't build something early on, then continue to improve on it, and use it into the late game. You're simply kitting yourself out, then abandoning everything you put all that effort toward, and replacing it with the latest and greatest.

There are interesting armor sets to be found in multiple biomes, like the Fenris armor set that gives a damage buff to fist weapons and a movement speed buff. However, you only get a single fist weapon in the entire game, and since it shows up in the mid game, farming to build the fist weapons and the Fenris armor set is an absolute waste of time. You're far better off simply ignoring the armor set (that gives almost no armor at all), never farming for it or the fist weapons, killing the boss of that biome, and putting all that time to farm into simply progressing to the next biome.

I honestly wish that every new biome simply offered something different, rather than something better. For example, if one biome offered amazing ranged-oriented stuff, and its own building aesthetic, while another biome offered excellent farming tools and its own building aesthetic, while another offered excellent swords and its own building aesthetic.

On top of that, Valheim seems to offer massive progression in terms of the things you acquire rather than any real progression relating to the inherent power of your character. You actually have the same 25 hit points on your character from the start of the game all the way until the end, but you can eat better food that offers all of the extra hit points. So really, you end up merely relying on external stuff rather than your character.

The game is fun and certainly worth playing all the way until the end, but for true longevity, I think they need true character progression and the option to explore biomes to gain optional things, rather than the requirement to rapidly progress through each biome and gain power in the form the biome's gear offerings.

This game is fairly decent overall.  It's a survival/adventure genre that plays better with friends.  There are a few gripes I have that I'll glance over, then get to the major ones.

To start this game is fairly unforgiving, even on easy mode.  Don't overestimate yourself, or underestimate the enemy.  The game has an intended path for you to follow concerning which biome is next on your list to conquer, but the game doesn't exactly lead you there (i.e. I was in the plains before I found any swampland, let alone mountains).  Enemies from the harder biome will wreck you so fast it'll make Usain Bolt look like a turtle with a limp. 

The world is HUGE, and the game is grindy.  Getting resources can be a pain in the butt especially considering metals can't be brought through a teleporter, so you either have to run ALL the way back or build a forward base in that biome (or cheese it).  The grind is real in that game though.  

Now for my main hissy fit.  There just isn't enough interesting POVs to keep my tiny reptile brain pre-occupied.  Gathering resources can only last so long before you need a change of pace, and while there are a few interesting places to visit, it's mostly just random half broken buildings with a couple feathers and some rubies.  There needs to be more content, whether its more places to visit or more to craft/create with the random resources you find everywhere (preferably both).

I hesitantly give this a recommendation, despite my grievances against the game. I got it on sale so I recommend you do too.  It's decent, but feels a little empty overall.  I'll play until the final boss is dead, then probably won't touch it for a long while afterward.  
Rating: 5.5/10
