While I haven't finished it yet, I have ran into some ideas and issues.
I would love steam workshop and or umod support. I feel this would open up the community more and keep the game thriving. Was never a nexus or mod manager user and forcing other people to 3rd party mods.
That being said, my main issues have been everything water and save related. 
Before I set sail, I click save while on land, I set sail, and I get wrecked by a serpent for the first time. Water combat and mechanics are pretty lackluster Imo. Anyways, after that I go to load my save... Guess what? It was OVER WRITTEN BY AN AUTO SAVE? Like come on! I quit for a day and came back and slowly re-farmed the material to get my body back but it was the most tilting experience I've ever had in a single player game.
Overall though game is solid as heck. No complaints about progression and how unique and complete it feels to anything else I've played. Huge recommend. Just devs, personal note, please don't let your game die. I only know there's a few of you but giving it to the hands of the community (workshop) would be a huge clutch.

I've revised my review after several hundred additional hours.  Honestly, it's a fun game.  I had set the bar too high years ago, and especially considering the trash AAA studios are putting out these days, Valheim has been nice to play with my buddies on a dedicated server.  There are many ways they could have improved this game since it's release, a few disappointing aspects, like the longship being the top tier. medium mead bases being the best available, the janky building system, AI behavior, and a few other things, but it's a nice break from the FPS games we've been playing.  I do wish there had been more content updated over the years.  Overall, I could definitely recommend the game at this price and it's current state.

The game isn't necessarily bad, and I think there is a lot of potential. For me, there are too many rough elements that take away from the fun survival game play loop. Small quality of life issues like not being able to deconstruct old items, not being able to use a torch in build mode, and poor mob re spawn rates add up.

A learning curve that feels balanced and encourages you to keep exploring. Whether you want to go dungeon raid, do some relaxing gardening, or drag a cart around the country side to go mining, there is always something to do at our own pace.

On another note and just me being a nerd, i wish trees would always drop their seeds so i don,t have a bare forest when I am done with a project. Building has been fixed allowing snapping to the bottom of objects.

Combat is basic and smooth.  Dodging and blocking is responsive and fun.  All combat is based on player skill, but there are skill levels that can affect your performance as well.

Materials for building and crafting are simple and straight forward.  Late in the game crafting materials remain pretty basic with new materials rarely being added in with old materials remaining relevant.

Building uses simple parts to make complex structures.  The building model uses structural integrity, so without support buildings fall down.  And trolls smash. . . 

There are some good options for customizing difficulty, but bosses still remain a real problem if playing solo.  Mods are also  supported.

I enjoy the game, ive had a lot of fun solo and playing with friends.  After a while i was overwhelmed with constant deaths.  The deaths cost me a lot of levels in my skills, but besides that the bosses were hard walls on solo play.  Im not sure im a fan of losing skills and inventory.  A later patch added the option to keep inventory, but skill degredation is still a thing.  There is no doubt its better with friends, but its become a lot friendlier for solo players in the last year.

Perfect game for someone who wants a more challenging survival sandbox experience.
Game overall is well-done. There are some annoying parts, but most of the game is pretty good despite that.
Be prepared to die a lot of times if this is one of your first survival sandbox experiences.
Great for playing with friends, as the online experience feels natural and fully-integrated with the rest of the game. You can share worlds by turning them into servers pretty easily, which is great for discovering other people's worlds and seeing different ways people survive. All of this, and it is still only in Early Access, which is pretty surprising.

I would recommend checking some tutorials and wikis on the game before starting since it is a big learning curve at first, but you get the hang of it. The crow is a very good idea to guide the player, but after a while, it becomes kind of annoying and it isn't always there when you need it, so the wikis and tutorials can help a lot.

Valheim The Review

	Have you ever found yourself looking at the steam store and wondering what to buy next and a game catches your eye? So you look at the reviews just to find that some of them are all jokes and have very little to do with the game, and don’t tell you if it is worth buying. Well, this is where to look. In short Valheim is worth it for its history and mythology, its core elements,  and multiplayer and role playing. I have over two hundred hours on the game  and this is why you should buy Valheim.

	Valheim is a good purchase for many reasons, the first of which is because of its lore and Mythology. Not to sound like Matpat, but Valheim has great lore and mythology. It has rune stones that tell stories of people sent to the tenth realm, Valheim, by Valkyries of Odin; these runes also talk about Valheim’s creatures. You are sent there because of Odin’s enemies growing stronger. These enemies were sent to Valheim long ago. Valheim also follows the mythology well because they talk about things in Norse mythology including Munin, Hugin, Dwarves (Dark Elves), Yggdrasil (The GIant Ash Tree), Odin, and Thor. This all reveals that Valheim has good lore and follows  Norse Mythology.

            Valheim is also worth your money because of its core elements even with the grinding required, building, cooking, fighting, and crafting. It does a good job giving the player lots of options of how to build, and has a lot of variety in what you can build. For example a farm, house,fortress, dock , storage room, and portal room. It also has lots of foods with different effects and a good stamina and health system. It has pretty decent fighting with lots of weapons and a skill system of which you lose 10% of your skills on death. Its crafting system is vast-ranging from a cup for mead to mage staffs, and swords. Overall, Valheim has great core mechanics.

  	Valheim has amazing multiplayer and roleplaying aspects. Valheim can hold up to ten players in a world. While the game can be thoroughly enjoyed in single player too. Valheim is much more agreeable in multiplayer. Multiplayer leads to unique opportunities for role playing , and makes the game easier to tackle. You can make stories and adventures, build castles together, and slay dragons together! (Not only metaphorically) Valheim gives a group the ability  for people to have an amazing time together and makes the game replayable. This all goes to show that Valheim has wonderful multiplayer aspects.
	
	Overall Valheim is more than worth your money. It is simply amazing how well Valheim sticks to Norse mythology, the only main difference is ten realms instead of nine. It has breathtaking core mechanics, spectacular building, crafting, cooking, and fighting. For the cherry on top it has splendid multiplayer and role playing capabilities. In all, Valheim is more than worth your money, the only downside is you might get addicted. I urge you to buy and play Valheim today!

Some people will tell you that this game is not worth it because of the Runescape 92-99 Runecrafting-esque grind to do just about everything, but I'm here to announce that I enjoy that level of grind in my coffee, so I recommend this game 100%. 
I'm a sucker for a game that lets me feel like I earned my place at the top of the food chain and this game is a constant reminder that your place at the top is earned every minute of play, it is not permanent. If you become lazy in your gameplay, you will suffer. The creatures of Valheim can smell your incompetence and your complacency. Go grab some wood in the middle of the night without eating first and tell me how well it goes. Usually not well.
Graphics are unique and not the "Visual sandpaper for my fragile eyes" kind of unique, but the "This looks like a PS2 game with more depth" unique. I like the style and I feel the gameplay works with the art style 99% of the time.
I'm sure it's fixed with mods, but I feel that my setup should be able to play this game with ease, but my fans are always reminding me that this game is taxing on my system. I run a 3080 laptop gpu, i7-11800H, with 32GB of RAM crammed into a laptop with a nice display if you are wondering if your system can handle this game (it should).

Is this game worth the money? I give it a hard yes. If you look at other reviews and notice the community stating that the game is in Early Access Hell you will think the game is not fun for the cash dropped on it, but I think the game, even in its current state, is worth the cash you will drop on it. Full price, on sale, as a gift from your cool friend who is into vikings too much, if you want it, just experience it.

I'll get straight to the point, the game has a lot of potential and because I played it with friends, I actually had fun, since we could rely on each-other. I know it's still in early access, so, even though I could judge it a lot harsher, I'll focus on what has been implemented, rather than what it's lacking, and, it is lacking in plenty of areas.

One last thing before I go through the list, I know there are a lot of mods for this game, but, I think it would be unfair to rate it based on what modders did, or, on what the game will/could be.

This being said, here we go:

[b]The bad:[/b]
- This is barely a survival game. Sure...it has elements of the survival genre, but: You can't die of starvation/thirst, can't get sick, the only times the environment can directly kill you is if you're swimming without stamina, if you're out during a blizzard, or, if you jump into a fire. Maybe playing with friends is what killed it for me, but I did not feel like I was playing  survival game.
- The magic system f*****g sucks! Not only are the spells boring (look and variety), but they don't have any synergy and you unlock magic RIGHT BEFORE you fight the final boss. With taking it slow, exploring and trying out mechanics and what the game has to offer, I unlocked magic at roughly the ~215 hour mark.  So basically, right before you fight the final boss, the game is like: "Hey! Do you want to completely change the fighting style you've been accustomed to and have been using?" Once you unlock magic, there's pretty much nothing else you can do, except for fighting the final boss or farm/gather the final ingredients to upgrade your magic items. 
- Not all "classes" are viable. Except for the tank, that gets armor in every biome and the mage, that gets unlocked in the last biome, anything that relies on medium armor stops getting upgrades (armor-wise) after the mountain biome. That left the people I played with terrified of Deathsquitos, since pretty much anything could one/two shot them.
- Taming system sucks (less than the magic system). The only thing taming is good for is getting the resources off of the animals without having to hunt them. The Lox might be a bit of an exception, but, the moment you go to the next biome, any pet becomes next to useless.
- Crafting system becomes cluttered after unlocking everything the the first 3-4 biomes. By "end game", I actually started dreading crafting due to through how many items I needed to scroll before reaching what I needed.
- Lag. I've rarely had it, but the people I played with complained about it, despite having solid hardware that surpasses the "Recommended" resources. My internet plan gives me 1.000 Mbp / s and I'm using a Legion Pro 5, o I know I wasn't the issue either.
- Farming Simulator. I mean, unless you're joining the game with friends and you're able to split tasks, get ready to spend most of your time on Cooking/Farming/Gathering/Hunting.

[b]The good:[/b]
+ Great scenery. Despite its simplistic graphics, you would honestly miss out if you wouldn't stop every now-and-then and take in your surroundings.
+ Awesome weather effects. ESPECIALLY if you're out sailing during a storm.
+ Biomes  are well defined. You can see the difference in atmosphere when entering one biome vs another. Sometimes it creeps up on you, sometimes it hits you like a shovel in the face.
+ Sound localization. It's honestly, one of the best I've seen.
+ Base building. Despite not being incredibly varied, you can really make some great buildings/bases with a bit of imagination. The best thing about it though, is how much you can make your base look like an actual village....it's, honestly...wow...just...wow.
+ Combat. No target locking, great hitboxes + you can use the environment (even the weather) to your advantage.
+ Resources in all biomes get used throughout the game, resources rarely become obsolete (except for flint and what bosses drop)
+ Distinct looking armor. Be it from biome to biome, or one "class" from the other.
+ Weapon diversity. They're basically categorized into Slashing/Piercing/Blunt/Ethereal, but each weapon that belongs to  class is clearly distinct and invites a different play style.

TL;DR: The game is cool when played with friends, but there are a number of poorly designed elements, that waste so much of your time, and, honestly, considering how much time you need in this game to do anything because of this, if you're not going in with other people, I'd advise you to try something else.

Fun game from early to mid, but WAY too grindy and frustrating the farther you go. With a big group of players it stays pretty consistently fun and balanced, but god forbid you play solo or with one buddy. 

In short: The bosses seem to be balanced around 5 players in mind. They don't scale to the number of players nearby or in the server, making bosses like Yagluth, the 5th boss, WAY too tanky. Combine this with their attacks aggro'ing random add's that are immune to the bosses attacks and the fact that you have to spend about 20 minutes to beat the boss if things go well and this culminates in an awful experience around the early-mid game transition. 

In short: If you have a group of friends you're playing with, go for it. Otherwise, I can't recommend this game.

Overrated game. Wannabe Dark Souls where difficulty is replaced be tediousness.

Prepare that there is quite huge change you need to uninstall and install after every update, because basically every update can broke the installation. Also, don't think about modding, as every update breaks all major mods.

Game itself could be good, but there are too many problems.

After the H&H update the food system has been totally broken. I.e. foods are divided to stamina, health or eitr foods. The reasoning for this was that you can eat stamina foods when exploring, health foods before fights, etc. Unfortunately the game mechanics make one need stamina always. I.e. without stamina foods you cannot hit enemies. One other argument was to in old system players only ate best foods. That hasn't changed at all. Best foods have just changed.

Most not entry level enemies are horrible sponges that you need to hit few dozen times to kill em. And they rarely come alone. And the engine often makes everything harder to you than it should (see later comment about visibility.)

Most enjoyable biomes are first two, meadows and black forest. After that the game become slog. Apparently game is developed without proper plan, as enemy stats are rebalanced everytime new biome is published, or otherwise larger update is published. (Anyone remember one hit one kill deathsquitos? Currently I actually miss those.)

Developers don't seem to understand the difference between difficult and tedious. Every major update has added more grinding to game, which makes it boring. This is easily seen in the fact that same progression is seen in every aspect of the game. E.g. workbench needs to be upgraded N times. Then forge needs to upgraded N times. Then Black forge needs to upgraded N times. Also artisan table needs to be upgraded N times (in the future). Food preparing cauldron needs to upgraded N times. That wouldn't be such issues if that wasn't cumulative. To max upper tier crafting tools one needs to upgrade lower tier tools to max. Also, be prepared to start from zero when moving to new biome. Old stuff doesn't disappear, but often is too far to practically usable. Teleports make this little easier to stand, but one cannot teleport with certain items, most importantly ores. So either take a multiple long and dangerous walks or sea voyages, or forget better equipments. 

Also, the game development is super slow. Thankfully now there are multiple developers, but that hasn't been visible in development speed. Most updates offer cosmetic changes and break all mods, or even the base game.

Worst thing is that sometimes the the game just breaks, even without any updates. Seems unity is really poor engine.

One example of OLD problem with game is that visibility between camera and character is not cleared, which often causes player not to see what's in front of character, which too often makes fighting just random button mashing while hoping for best (esp. forests are full of low branches). Best way to lose 5% of your skills is to die because you couldn't see where to hit/shoot because there was a tree behind the character. That is kind of problem which should have been ironed out before going early access. Only reason to leave it game is to artificially make the came harder.

I you like grinding repetitive tasks then this may be your game. Or if you play with friend, so you can share the repetition.

Best when played with friends on own dedicated server. But then again frequent (cosmetic and unnecessary) updates will break the game multiple times. Personally I'm really happy I managed to play this game through couple of times before H&H update made is worse.

TLDR: After getting a few hours and replaying this game about five times, I can say I [strike]recommend[/strike] this game. 6.5/10. Turn on double resource rate to get a more enjoyable and manageable experience. One of the [strike]best [/strike]survival games, if you like building get this game.
The main issues are: grinding, boss battles, boating, de-sync. and combat/punishment.

I have just gone through a rush of this game and V Rising and both do things wrong and right that I wish they could just combine the right to make a perfect game. If you like combat probably don't get into this game for it. If you like building it is probably the best building system out there. I have friends who have literally put 40 hours into a server just building. I personally do not play this game for the building I play it for the progression and exploration.

The exploration is peak. It's why I play the game. There is so much to find explore and loot. There are dungeons in about every biome. Each with their own challenges and loot. Finding new land to uncover more dungeons and enemies is a joy and great. Each biome is so unique and brings their own challenges and fear. 

The enemy variety is exactly what a survival game needs. Each with their own strategies, attacks, strength and weaknesses. The progression system helps this by changing what your afraid of. Once you were scared of trolls, now you can just block your attacks. Perfection. 

Music is up there. Really fits the atmosphere and is great background noise while playing.

The repair system is something every game needs. You don't have to keep grinding for resources after you make something. You just need to click a hammer icon and that's it! Other survival games should take note.

Pros TLDR: Music is solid, exploration solid, durability/repair system, and enemy variety are great.

Now my gripes:
The grind is not fun... Every survival game has them but Valhiems are awful when they are awful. Unfortunately the worst one is right away. Double resource rate doesn't even solve it. The bronze age is awful because of copper. While minning copper you get stone. Sometimes when mining you don't get any copper when it breaks a chunk. This makes it extremely tedious! Then your boat isn't big enough to carry a whole lot. Additionally, you usually don't have the bigger weight capacity so you just can't get as much. Awful. Has made me want to stop playing every time. You also need tin. This is so much easier to get and you get so much more. Then when you bring it all back to base it's a 2:1 ratio for converting to bronze. You think it would be 2 tin to 1 copper. NOPE it's the other way around. Awful. It's not fun and causes bronze to be the longest age in the game. After all this bronze tools/armor feel like they cost so much to make!!! It needs to be reworked. I believe just swapping the 2:1 ratio will solve this issue or at least help. Silver is rough.

Until you have to GRIND FOR MORE later on!!! For plains gear you use iron again! So you usually have to go get more! This is an issue because you can't teleport metal. Instead you have to use a boat. Boating freaking sucks!!! Mistlands you need more iron!!!

The boating system is literally press w and then turn occasionally to adjust for terrain or wind. It's unengaging, slow, and so boring. Even with getting the moder buff, it can literally take a full hour to get back in some cases. It's boring in single player and multiplayer that you literally just pull out your phone while playing because there is nothing to do. Multiplayer it's worse cause only one person actually controls the boat. Here's the worst part... the developers want you to use their boating system... The community has been divided on this issue. The developers are persistent in not teleportation metal. The reason for this is you miss a huge part of exploration and utilizing a whole game system. But boating freaking sucks! I agree with the devs but backtracking is not fun.

So how to solve these issues because they do overlap. Me and my friends have discussed this a lot and have come up with two solutions. Ore progression system and boat minigames. Ore progression is basically, once you beat boss, you can teleport metal. Defeated bonemass? You can now teleport copper and tin. It still incentives exploration to new biomes just not old/completed ones. Boat minigames could be, paddle at the right time for a boost, regardless if your steering or not. These should solve the back tracking issue, and the boating issue.

But we're not done with complaints! Combat/boss battles/dying are pretty rough. The later you get the better but it's around the plains when it gets better. First off combat is simple. This is good. I like this. The light armor heavy armor system is not as good. Heavy armor slows you down too much. It should be like 3-2.5% movement reduction per piece, not 5% each. Dying is bad because you lose everything. This is normal for survival games but V Rising did a good job solving this for it's gameplay. I think valhiem should have you drop everything but leave like the helmet and cape. Why? Because the mountains suck. With freezing, and enemy damage and even fall damage. Getting your loot back is tedious especially last half of the game. The extra armor and cape would go a long way. Yes you can modify this but the developers want death to be punishing and I think a compromise would fix this issue. Also the levels lost on death are fine but I think the timeframe of no skill drain should be increased by like 1.5x.

This is a mixed issue... The boss battles. The scope for all of them are good. But some work way better than others.

Deer boy, yagluth, bonemass, are the best. The others are rough. Elder needs like one more attack move and is the least fun/engaging to fight. Moder needs like two more attacks and fixed ai. In multiplayer it doesn't know what to do so just sits there while being pummeled by arrows. Yagluth is good except for it needs to be less resistant to other weapons besides silver. The Queen needs to be nerfed in singleplayer. Either with a health decrease or less minions spawning. Not fun solo. Deer boy... is perfect don't change them.

The Bad TLDR: Ore progression needs work (bronze especially), boating is not fun or engaging (why did they not do the ocean update...), dying is a bit too punishing, bosses need tweaks or AI fixes.

Mistlands has ruined this game for me. You need to grind for so much, there isn't a guarantee of black core, seal breakers. Abandoned structures are annoying and don't guarantee a extractors or soft tissue. The terrain is good for stopping you from adventuring into the mistlands but the wisp does not reveal enough. Why does extractors cause roots to become diminished. Why do you need 15 black cores for the feather cape when they aren't guaranteed in mines. Why give the feather cape when your done with exploration in the mistlands. So many strange decisions that ruin the flow of the game and just add so much grind. For context you need to get 3 items in plains, mistlands you need 5: black core, soft tissue, extractor, sap, sealbreakers. Make crafting costs cheaper. Guarantee cores and seal breakers. Make wisp area bigger. The mistlands just isn't fun and is why I can't recommend valhiem now. 

Boating needs tweaking, mistlands needs fixing, grind needs tweaking, punishment needs tweaking, metal needs tweaking.

this game is one of the best survival crafting games besides a few [i]major[/i] flaws (in my opinion):
[list]
[*]this game requires such a massive resource grind that the lack of beasts of burden, ridiculously high mob spawning rate, and sometimes massive distances between biomes create a really tedious travel experience [i]especially[/i] when doing corpse runs.
[*]stamina seems to regen at a flat rate rather than a percentage of your max stamina, and the recovery rate is slooooow, and doesn't seem to recharge any faster from meals. the flow of combat is ruined if you bottom out or get caught by an enemy during or after a long sprint, and against some enemies having no stamina is essentially a death sentence. stamina regen needs a serious rework if they're trying to go for the soulslike-style of combat they seem to want
[*]raids by default happen way too often to the point of feeling like a chore. especially on a multiplayer server, and especially once trolls start joining raids, they become borderline unfair without resorting to popular cheese tactics like invincible terrain walls, and I consider needing to work around a game's mechanics instead of with them to be a major flaw in the overall design.
[*]building and farming requiring stamina doesn't make much sense to me. I don't see it ever becoming a tactical choice of any kind, just an artificial way to slow down your experience as you wait for your stamina to recharge at a snail's pace.
[/list]
that being said, there's lots to love as well such as varied weapon movesets (even if enemies have basically 1 or 2 attacks each), a really intuitive building system that lets you make some amazing structures, and cooking that actually feels like different foods serve different purposes.
overall, the game is tons of fun and I love so much of it, I think it would be a near-perfect survival game with just a few changes. add oxen or let tamed wolves or lox pull carts, add a way to travel with livestock via boat, make raids only happen when players are in a base for a certain amount of time maybe as a way of shaking things up, separate raids into waves maybe with a troll (etc) joining at the very end as a boss. I find the game overall a lot more enjoyable with tweaking the difficulty settings, so if you find some of these aspects frustrating too, try toying around with them as well and hopefully you'll have a better experience for your personal taste as well

THE BEST SURVIVAL GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED

So I've played this game for 66 hours and I think I can give it a good review.

I'm a fan of Oblivion, Skyrim, but also throwing in the crafting, mining, farming, foraging explosion from the last 12 years.  Also a big fan of coop games.

The pros of this game first.  I think the best is the multiplayer mode.  It is so much fun to play with your friends.  Just pray you don't disconnect while riding a boat, or you're going to drown.   The combat is really fun and when you hit things it feels really good.  Even shooting arrows feels awesome when you sneak up on enemies.  The cooking system is fine, just make sure you have food and your stamina will go up.  This is a complaint it seems, but there are foraging opportunities and eventually you will have so much meat it doesn't matter.  Building stuff is also really good.  I was able to make a pretty cool log cabin mansion.  The gameplay is just so much fun.

The cons of this game next.  Points of interest are boring.  Very little variety in what you actually find in this giant world.  Same with enemies.  About 3 per biome.  The music starts out nice, but it gets old very fast.  There is one song per biome.    Do not go out at night.  Enemies will spawn and make your life hell.   Gathering resources is a time drain.   You can bring metal items through portals, but you cannot bring metal ore through portals.  Thank you for allowing us to turn this off.  This is nothing short of a time waster because there isn't much else to really do in the game.  I go back to my first point in the cons.  There is actually not much to do in this game, so it feels like the devs lengthen it with the metal gathering.  There are no quests, significant NPCs, points of interest.  The game loop is:  Get metal, make stuff, beat boss.  Get better metal, make stuff, beat boss.   While you might say "that's all games," well yeah.  In this game, that is truly the only thing.  You have a large world to explore, but there isn't much in it. The devs have made it so you can bring ore through the portals so I like that aspect.  Another complaint is that since this game has gone HUGE in early access the updates have been very spaced out.    They've sold like 1 million copies and this is STILL in early access.

Anyway, this game is so much fun.  It is still VERY early access and there are a lot glaring flaws to me regarding a complete game.  I recommend it when it is on sale and buy it with your friends.  Don't expect much else other than running around, gathering resources, building stuff, and beating bosses.  The mod community I understand is creating bigger worlds with stuff in it.  So keep an eye out for that.  Problem is, this ends up like a Bethesda game that relies on everyone else to make it better.

[b]Valheim lures you in with a solid foundation only for you to find out that it recycles the gameplay loop[/b] of: 1 - Get minerals/materials; 2 - Craft armor/Expand farming; 3 - Defeat the boss to access the next area - too many times for comfort without any new mechanics. It's also proficient in sucking out the fun of everything that you *hope* is going to be fun.

Let me give you a "for instance":

• There are these huge ox/buffalo type creatures that you can tame so you can ride. You'd expect to be able to shoot arrows while riding, for it to carry cargo or at least attack on command. Nope, you can only run with it. Taking it anywhere beyond the continent on which it was tamed is a herculean task involving bad collision with boats and praying that nothing catches its aggro. There also a skill attached to riding, somehow shoehorning even more grind.

• There are wolves you can tame, which we went through the lengths to get an elite 2-star one, only for it to be destroyed by enemies beyond the region native to the wolf. There are no upgrades you can give them and they also have the exact same trouble to get across the sea.

• Sea? There are boats in this game and you are going to spend a lot of time travelling in them, and for all this time, all you can do is either row extremely slowly or pray that the wind carries your sails. There is no more mechanics beyond fighting the occasional sea serpent, which is just spamming ranged attacks from the deck. It's a glorified cargo cart.

• Speaking of which, there is a weight mechanic in the game which affect the carts. If you, god forbid, try to use it for the intended purpose of carrying huge weights, it will barely move. Moving it around without rolling it over is a whole 'nother story as well.

This all happens in the [b]default, intended experience[/b]. I'd forgive all of these flaws if there were regular updates, but there are [b]not[/b]. Every single problem you face may be resolved by an active modding community, having you spend time synching your group up for even the most basic quality of life changes such as allowing multiple people to access the same chest, using items directly from nearby storage to craft or a button to quickly stack everything non-favourited into nearby chests. You can play this in a Rust-like manner, but really, just play Rust for that, at least it gets updated.

[b]Stay away if you want a single-player or co-op experience, the devs not only take forever to update the game but also insult your intelligence.[/b]

Early Access Review, only made it into the "end-ish of early game" for what it's worth in 22hrs.

This game is absolutely a joy to play with or without friends. The sheer power you have with being able to shape the land and build your own structures adds a lot of depth that wouldn't be there if this were a standard "hub world kill bosses take loot" kind of game.

Now, if building and survival gameplay isn't necessarily your favorite thing in the world, or wouldn't entertain you by itself, then the bossing and combat seems and feels relatively simple. There aren't that many mechanics or deep tech to delve into, nor are there many bosses (5 in current version as of this review, 9 slated in total for final release as of this review), but the fighting is enjoyable enough to keep you busy while progressing through the equipment tiers.

Gameplay progression feels fine for a game of this scope at least from where I am in terms of progression, Only gripes is that it feels less like a slope upwards of progressing your gear, and moreso very large spikes in certain areas, which may either feel incredibly good or sluggish if having to anticipate and dig through an insane amount of rocks just for the middling amount of copper you get while on a mining trip.

Graphically, the game's texturing and polygons aren't extremely detailed, but is shaped by excellent lighting and shadows to create a pleasant and stylized feel, with wind strands streaking through the air and the swaying of branches and leaves to create a truly beautiful, breathing world with the graphical limitations self-imposed by the devs with the style of choice. The textures may be a sore spot for someone looking for extreme fidelity out of their souped up graphics cards, but this game can and probably will run on a potato PC just fine.

Overall, it is a great feeling survival game in Early Access, with all the potential being there, and plays currently like a simply good video game. The focus on PvE may push some away from enjoying it if they're looking for a PvP focused experience, but it feels great as a comfortable pick up and play game. I certainly hope there will be a lot more coming within Early Access and this game can be fully realized to all its potential.

Oh, and it's a 1GB game.

EDIT: (1/15/2024)

 So it's been about 3 years since release and there's been a handful of updates and balance reworks to the game and my thoughts still remain the same: this is one of the best survival games I've played thus far.

If there's any game that is a must-play, it's this one.

I remember the first time I crossed the river into the woods. It still haunts my memories to this day. In the mist I crouched and walked stealthily, being careful not to scare the game I hunted. I needed food and deer skins to survive. Then something happened. With mouth agape, I stood up and looked but couldn't believe my eyes.

Towering over the trees and blackened ruins of a stone tower was a giant blue-skinned googly-eyed bald man just standing there, looking at me. He was just LOOKING at me and I, in my horror, was just looking at him. Then after a pregnant pause, I heard his thunderous footsteps as he lumbered and loped towards me. At first I thought it was my heart racing in my chest. No such luck. The biggest, scariest, Sesame Street muppet of all time had marked me as his quarry, his next victim. I looked at my pitiful flint-tipped spear and knew I had no chance, no strength or might to oppose this creature, my new nemesis.

So I ran. I ran and ran until the only sound was my own feeble footsteps splashing in shallow water and the croaking of angry little frog men. Just as the downpour started, I made it home to the abandoned, dilapidated shanty I reclaimed for my own lodging. I'm content to eat mushrooms and berries for sustenance now.

Absolutely incredible experience

To start off:

Game is VERY friendly to groups. Fun, cooperative, and rewarding.

Game is NOT friendly to solo play. Broken, frustrating, fundamentally designed to make you miserable.

Valheim's procedural algorithm is created to make everything as miserable as possible for you. With friends and backup the gameplay loop is MUCH more bearable and enjoyable. However, solo, the game is a gruelling, messy, janky, unforgiving mess.

Powerful mobs will spawn directly on top of you during menial tasks. Multiple mobs are more overpowered than bosses and spawn on a regular basis in the worst spots at the worst times. Be prepared to regularly fight for your life against generic mobs for 10-20 minutes just to get back to mining and collecting materials. 

Carrying capacity is incredibly low and base server settings do not allow you to carry precious good through portals. Keep in mind the game world is absolutely MASSIVE. Valheim believes the intended way to play is to Run, Walk, Swim, and Sail for literal hours at a time back and forth for 2 dozen precious metals, rinse, and repeat. And did I mention that building new equipment and upgrading them requires HUNDREDS of precious metals?

Valheim is NOT a casual game which is evident just by reading the comments - Players bragging about 2000+ hr playtimes, not because they really enjoy the game, but because that is what you can look forward to if you want to play the game as intended. Hours upon hours of running and sailing aimlessly, dying, and spending even more hours trying to return to your body to get your equipment back.

There is a stark difference between rewardingly difficult games, and whatever this is. Valheim will test the absolute limits of your patience in all the worst ways - Through unbalanced combat, punishing exploration & traversal, and a bizarre hate for single players. 

If you have a desire to spend money on this game, make sure you have a crew of friends to play with the get the most out of it. If not, I highly recommend you spend your money on any other survival game out there. Try out Sons of the Forest!

To be honest, this game has ruined every other game of this genre for me.  So many survival/crafting open world games bombard you with menus and features, while Valheim just keeps it simple.  You have one crafting menu and then an inventory menu and that's it.  Other menus are kept attached to other items that fulfill various tasks, and they also just keep it simple.  That alone makes it my favorite.  Add in the beautiful visuals and genuinely addictive and intuitive build system, and the game doesn't have to do anything to pull you a certain way.  It just naturally makes you want to explore.  The enemies are fun, the combat is fun.  Each weapon does something different.  The grinds aren't too grindy.  What else is there to say.  I genuinely can't think of a reason why I'd play any other survival game over this.  10/10.

Boring and poorly executed. 

The building system is underwhelming and uninteresting, with prerequisites for crafting (required roofing for utilizing already built workshops) resulting in the player never naturally building a base and thus haphazard uninspired base building occurs. From the building choices I observed, the player is given limited building pieces to construct their base, dissuading the player from constructing an aesthetically pleasing or utilitarian abode unless they actively work against the game's current interface.

Grinding is also prevalent within the game, with the player having to constantly collect multiple of the same material for small, incremental progression rivaling the grinding of mobile gaming.  For example, to craft the starting tool, the player is forced to wander across the landscape to find several objects that lie on the ground to craft a starting ax. The time it takes to find the starting materials just to get into the game is absurd, as they are spawned widely across the staring area and the game needs the player to pick up a total of around 5 of each material, resulting in the player wasting around 5 minutes of their time to craft the starting tool. Furthermore, optimized collection of materials with tools is still atrocious. For example, collection of wood with an ax required the player to stare at a tree for around 3 minutes and click the left mouse button. Eventually, the tree will split into two smaller logs which require an additional 1 minute of chopping for each log before retrieving materials. Thus, the player is forced to grind with tools for minimal materials even after devoting significant time to retrieving the materials required for crafting and upgrading such tools. 
The worst materials are animal specific drops. I was often waiting for boars to drop certain fabrics required for almost all starting technology and technological upgrades. These boars not only take a while to be found, they spawn randomly across the biome with painfully slow re-spawn rates, resulting in players spending most of their time "gaming" by walking across the landscape and hoping to maybe observe a boar or two. While I am new to the game, future technology and building seems to replace the tedious grind of early game animals and materials with a more tedious grind of rarer animals and materials, giving no significant sense of progression.

Technological progression is also poorly implemented into the game at its current state. There are different technological grades of materials that are unlocked as you discover more resources. For example, a flint ax replaces a stone ax. But, the game also gives you options to upgrade your current, inferior technology if the player has certain resources. What makes this system confusing is that the refining of inferior technology and creation of better technology are both locked behind the same buildings required for progression. Thus, the false sense of choice in progression is an area of redundant game design that only serves to confuse the player and waste resources that could be better spent in newer technologies. 
The upgrading of materials also mimics similar design to that of mobile gaming, where minor stat changes are accompanied by progressively more tedious and difficult grinding to unlock the next technological building. Upgraded technology never significantly improves the base tools stats, neither does upgraded technology introduce new, interesting mechanics to a tool. 
Additionally, technological progression itself requires more ugly buildings to house all the technological buildings in the same space. Furthermore, the technological buildings each force the player to grind for more of the same resources, artificially extending game play with boring, "fetch quest" assignments.  

Skill progression did interest me, until it became blatantly clear it was another grinding ordeal with diminished returns for progressively more tedious actions. In essence, the player is rewarded for completely a repetitive task (like cutting or running) by improvements to the in-game character's stats (like damage-per-second or stamina). The game is then able to punish the player for dying by removing progression in skills. The problem with this system is that a player must also grind these skills, along with the obvious grinding of materials, for a play-style outside of ranged abuse of the game's AI. Furthermore, the player is forced to slow their progression in material collection to preserve their current skills, or slow their progression in skills by collecting materials and potentially dying. Both systems require immense time investment, resulting in a painfully boring elongation of already stretched game-play. This dissuades the player from exploring and adds another artificial obstacle for player progression and enjoyment. 

Finally, combat is awful. Click left, abuse idiotic AI, and grind for better gear. 
There is very little depth to combat, as each normal encounter on the map involves a two hit KO to any opposing animal. The combat itself involves a brief animation followed by a randomized range of damage applied to the creature if you hit the opponent. No depth, very little variation, and each weapon is locked behind grinding progression of a separate skill. The designed opponents, besides the bosses, have no good attacks that you can choreograph and counter, and the combat does not motivate the player to refine his/her skill in the game. The combat essentially operates as progress check for the player's current gear, with the player unable to interact with new or novel areas until they did enough grinding and mindless wandering around the previous area. 

The game lacks depth, does not respect the player's time, artificially limits enjoyment with obtuse mechanics and game design, and is difficult to enjoy as a single player experience. I would not recommend Valheim, but if you enjoy casual survival games, you might be able to make this work with friends.

We had a server for Valheim when it first dropped and played about 30 hours before we ran out of content to play. Two years later we've returned, and in greater numbers. With a whole new biome  to conquer in the mistlands, and the ashlands just around the corner, we are all having a great time!

The survival aspects of the game strike a great balance between difficult and forgiving by not forcing you to constantly eat unless you expect to be in combat. The stamina system can be a bit annoying but is meaningful to keep combat challenging.

I still recommend mods like Valheim+ in order to tweak some of the settings to your liking (automating resource production to minimize tedium, or improving skill gain for little used actions like swimming or sneaking)

Building is my personal favorite part of any game like this, and while the need for structural supports can be frustrating, I believe it helps you to be more creative and think more like an actual designer than just slapping together some huts. I do wish for some additional pieces/options in the building mode to allow for even more creative builds!

Overall my personal favorite survival game.

When the game was released in 2021, we were all quite excited, playing non-stop and defeating almost every boss until we reached a certain point where we decided to pause and await the next significant update. Now, here we are in 2024, and the game remains essentially unchanged from where we left it. It seems like the developers are focused more on monetization than providing substantial updates, and it's becoming apparent that they may be running out of ideas.

Despite the positive aspects of the game, which is undeniably enjoyable, it's disheartening to see little progress or innovation after three years. While I'm inclined to give a positive review based on the initial fun factor, the lack of meaningful updates is becoming a concern.

At 60 hours play time - this game is amazing.  Good enough graphics, excellent game.  Amazing attention to detail in terms of how realistically some aspects of the world work.  If you are looking for open world, crafting, building, survival and a nice balance of killing stuff - Valheim is just perfect.

Depending on how you feel on a given day, you can play intense, or just chill and forage and collect stuff.  The immersion is too good to be true.  For a given world you can play by yourself for a bit, and then play with friends in the same world.  Again, brilliant flexibility.

Also, the balancing is great, and there are a number of options to increase or decrease the difficulty on different aspects of the game independently of each other - so if you just want tougher or easier monsters, no problem.  Or if you just want to grind less on resource collection because you have limited time, you can increase the resource drop rate.  These options can be changed at any time for a world, so you have a lot of flexibility in changing them at different times to suit you.

TLDR: To enjoy Valheim you will first need to set your expectations absolutely right, it is not an ordinary open world survival game which you can casually explore and have fun writing your own adventure in this sandbox. Valheim is a challenging, highly punishing, time-consuming game that highly relies own players' own intrinsic reward to provide satisfaction. The game at its current stage is still very rough, and I would advise suspecting its "overwhelmingly positive" review as they might come from true enthusiasts of such genre but not applicable to other casual players, much like the Souls series.

[olist]
[*]Designated Difficulty
The intended default difficulty of this game is highly unforgiving and punishing, which shows on aspects including combat, exploration, resource management and death penalty. 
The combat is methodical like Souls, where micromanaging stamina and distancing is crucial. However, the game is plagued with slow stamina regen and damage sponge enemies, meanwhile even the slightest uneven terrain would make you unable to hit your enemy. In mid-late game, it became extremely tedious to fight even just a single enemies, which in reality they often come in packs. 

Depend on the player, the exploration of Valheim's world may either be "spiritual experience like meditation" or "a boring field trip on an unnecessarily large empty world". There are little to no reward for exploration other than fining dungeons for key resources for progression. Running and jumping around consumes stamina rapidly, yet even the tiniest elevation requires jumping to get on. The world of Valheim is broken into multiple islands separated by oceans. It is inevitable to visit multiple islands in order to complete the game. However sailing is rather annoying before end-game as players have to rely on the unpredictable wind direction to sail. All they can do is wait an unclear time for the wind to match their destination.
Resource management, mainly gathering, is extremely demanding. Lumbering, Mining, Hunting and Dungeon Crawling has to repeated for a ridiculous amount of times. Combined with slow stamina regen, strict weight restriction, bad world generation and long enemy aggro distance, most of the play time would be spent fetching stuff across the lands and running away from tedious fights.

Dying in Valheim is a huge pain in the ass. Similarly to survival games like Minecraft, you will lose all your inventory upon death and get a chance to retrieve them if you could manage to revisit your death spot. But dying in Valheim is much worse than just that. Not only you lose hard-earned skill points, your loss equipment are often results of enormous resource grinding, especially when you are in the later game. However, your enemies will not despawn upon your death, so you now have to deal with the enemies that already poses a death-threat, using previously replaced lower tier equipment. If you are unlucky enough to die on the seas, you will lose tens of hours of grinding, irretrievable by any means.

[*]Bad UI Design and Information Presentation
The UI of Valheim has its own aesthetics, but overall it is just incredibly inconvenience and will hurt your eyes. The texts are small but the panels are clumsy, and all options are squeezed together like a tightly packed can of tuna. 
The game also doesn't tell you enough what you need to do for progression. One might argue this is "intended to promote exploration", which could've been an okay idea if the world weren't so dull and empty, and traversing wasn't as hindered as swimming in a pool of tar. Most of the time, you are off to wander the empty world trying to figure out "where do I get this material"
, "what is this material for", "where is the next boss", "what does this key item do", all while scratching your head in frustration and confusion and exhaustion, because none of the items have informative description and the random world gen decided to not spawn key structures required for progression.

[*]Demanding Resource Management
The vast reviews talking about woodcutting is not just a joke, but more like a "haha Im fine" moment with intense internal screaming. The amount of resources required for doing literally anything in this game is ridiculous. Even if you played with a "semi-creative mode" that removes costs for building structures second time onward, you would still need hella lot of resource for crafting. And by the mean time, useless drops clumps up your storage like crazy, because somehow the game doesn't have a way to properly dispose them other than throwing them far away from your base, or into the ocean, or on the roof where you won't pick up accidentally. 

[*]Lack of Sense of Progression
In Valheim, there are no permanent powerups unlocked as you progress. The only way to get stronger is through intense grinding for equipments and skills, which both will be lost during death. And worse, skills only provides unnoticeable minor improvements, and better equipments from 10 hours or grinding only provide like a laughable 10-20% increase in power/defense. 

[*]Shallow Combat System
As aforementioned the game has a souls-like combat that plays around stamina management, but it severely lacks depth and varieties. Different monsters have similar movesets, just different attributes like HP, Def and Atk. So is player movement, using different weapon only brings a small deviation in attack animation, and unlocking new weapons only brings stats improvement. Due to its grind-heavy nature, the game forces you to fight the same enemies over and over again, which further worsened in the end game when they come in unavoidable hordes with ridiculous HP and Atk. The (current) final boss of the game is the ultimate sh1tshow of all of these issues combined, and is almost artistic in a way that it builds up so many frustration to a point I reached nirvana clarity after defeating it.

[/olist]

In conclusion, I would say the game is highly overrated, and will not recommend it unless you are the very specific kind of players it is tailored and targeted towards.

Then you'll fucking love the fact that you're going to end up getting killed in a dungeon, losing all your shit, and having to run back to try and collect it only to get killed AGAIN AND AGAIN, because you CANT FUCKING HIT something that's standing on a fucking sheet of paper, thereby raising it's hitbox out of your reach! Swinging a big 2h sword? MISS!!! Swinging a mace? MISS!!! Swinging an axe? Fucking forget it! That shit's either like 1/2" off the ground, or you're standing slightly above it and YOU CAN'T HIT IT! You're a viking! You're too fucking stupid to swing a little higher or lower, but the mobs can sure as fuck still cheese kill you while you're out of stamina due to this bullshit!

The hitboxes in this game are absolute shit and haven't been fixed since it's release, and their discord server won't let you post without giving them your phone number for whatever the fuck reason. I can't recommend this to anyone until they fix them. It's so bad, and so well known, there WAS a mod that specifically fixed this issue, but apparently the latest patch broke it again... If you read other bad reviews for the game, they also mention this issue..

Aside from this game breaking issue, especially with the latest content in the mistlands, where everything's sharp peaks, deep valleys, huge slopes, and dungeons with stairs or sloped walls, it's a fun game. Hence the 700 hours or so I've played... But as of the Mistlands patch? Nah.. Save your money till they fix it, but don't hold your breath... It's been like this since day 1. It was never this bad though until they threw it in your face with the mistlands expansion.

1/14/2024.    Went back to play online with a buddy of mine.... Yep, the game is still ass and I regret wasting the free bandwith to install it.

The hitboxes are still absolute dogshit. Also, apparently now things can spawn directly behind you while you're traveling through an open field that WAS previously completely empty. While most devs use their time to patch their games and make them better, Irongate has only managed to fuck things up even worse than before.

10 more days and Ensrhouded is out and I can delete this bullshit game and never play it again....

I don't get why people love this game. To me this game is just a bunch of mechanics taken from other games merged into one game and the result is this clunky mess. Combat is praised for being like Dark Souls. No it really isn't, maybe to those who saw Dark Souls but never played it. The stamina regen is much much slower than Dark Souls so most of the time you'll find yourself running out of it and getting killed because of it. Also there is no lock on so you are likely to miss some swings. The enemy pathfinding seems to be broken or just poorly made because the enemy will run at you, take a swing then run away then run away some more then use their ranged attack so you are playing catch with your enemies. If you happen to be in a group of them say for example five 3 are running away 1 is taking a swing and the last one is using range attack. Building is like Rust but bad, the building block snapping is poorly made. The structures have decay but you don't have anything to prevent it so you just have to repair it. This is annoying because the game encourages you to build base in every goddamned biome in this game because the resources you mine in them cannot be taken through a portal. And the resources and their rates I had to increase the rate to 3x because I played 4 man coop. Let's take the Bronze tier as an example . You need 15 Bronze bars for a full set of Bronze armor 1 bronze bar is made from 2 copper bars and 1 tin bar so for the full set of Bronze armor you have to mine 30 copper and 15 tin that is 45 ores you can't take through the portal and now we have to multiply it by 4. And that is not all because we have to make weapons and upgrades as well. If you want everything from the bronze tier it makes 292 Bronze bars according to the wiki. The best part about this is that it gets much worse. For the next tier we have Iron and the full set costs 60 iron to make. So this is just a massive waste of time. Dungeons are boring, you fight like 3 skeletons in a hallway. Swamp is by far the worst biome in this game. The leeches in water are a pain to hit because of the hitboxes and because they are under you (could be fixed by lock on) (if you steal something at least steal the whole thing not just half of it). The map is needlessly big. This is not an exploration game, you just find biomes that are the same with the same structures and enemies every time. The bosses have like 2 attacks they spam and are quite underwhelming but the buffs you get from them are nice and useful. In conclusion, massive waste of time because of grinding, annoying teleportation rules, half-assed souls like combat, carry weight, poor cart mechanics and other experiences I’ll rather forget. Buy it on sale if you really want it. Play it with friends so you can grind your life away in the african cobalt mines together. Bye.

Love this game.  Didn't seem like it was going to be much at first, but I've played it a bunch and no sign of it getting boring.  Just when I think I'm getting good and tough, with good gear, I get some humble pie.

This game is fun, right up until you get to the Mistlands, and whoever from Coffee Stain produced the level design for there needs to be outright fired.  

Someone turned around and said "Hey, who thinks Stamina management is the best part of Valheim? Let's make a whole zone focused around that!".  Mistlands is f"""""g dreadful, it is absolute garbage and is the pure reason I'm giving Valheim a negative review, it is that bad.  All you do is jump around cliff, wait for stamina regen, jump around cliff, wait for stamina.  God forbid you get wet and then some random creature sees you from the mists.  It wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the dreadful vertical combat, I literally had an enemy pushing me but because it was slightly below me, my weapons did nothing, couldn't hit it at all.  

Well I say that, it was around 2 hours between swings because of terrible stamina.  Honestly if you're going to buy and play Valheim, do it, it's a great game, but ignore Mistlands, the place turns a great game into a chore that takes the shine off the rest of the game.

I used to love this game. Then they ruined it by making the swamp an unbearable nightmare. Decision to make block ability tied to health instead of stamina is idiotic. You have to use health heavy food to survive attacks but you NEVER have stamina because you're wet (and probably cold) and you have heavy armor on so you can't move. Which you need to do because the Abominations, solo, are unbelievably hard. Harder than most of the bosses. 

What a shit show. I'd love to experience the rest of the game but the swamp is a train wreck.

Valheim:
You awaken in a realm of rain and darkness, scantly clad in a loincloth that is, by the time the Valkyrie dumps you on the waiting dirt, no doubt inundated with rainwater and espoused effluent from being flown over an unknown land in the claws of a warrior's angel.
Get used to that loincloth folks, You'll find yourself wearing it far more often than you care to admit in a public forum such as a steam review.
Valheim is a curious game to look at from the store page, and I didn't initially buy it when I first saw it. This game is correctly advertised for sure, it is a Survival game, It is an epic building sandbox, It is a satisfying Monster basher, It is Norse themed. So why wasn't I interested?
Valheim is packaged up and displayed in such a way it makes you THINK its just another survival game, such as Rust, or Day Z (Worth noting, I have played neither.) but with the option to forgo teaming up with your fellow peasants and go crawl through dungeons by yourself the old fashioned way, but it had the feel it would be missing something vital by doing so. So i pondered and pondered if it was worth getting.

I hold my tankard of mead up to you Iron Gate, not only did you blow my expectations so far out of the water the word "overkill" in the dictionary now has a picture of my bewildered mug under it. 

Valheim takes the elements of survival we are all used to, Wood chopping, firemaking, basebuilding stone digging etc and makes you work to the knuckles in such a way that is unbelievably rewarding. I got this game 3 months ago and didnt even shut it down until i hit the end of the current content. It is unbelievably addictive, and satisfying. Items that you once coveted in the early game become as common as currency later on and you look into your chest full of surtling cores and feel like you really did make Surtur your Bit-

The game's aesthetic is gorgeous, it is minimalistic yet charming, and with the right know-how it really doesn't matter when your building your mighty mead hall. The mechanics make the world feel dynamic, and the game encourages you to spread your sails and set up outposts, although in time these outposts become little more than hubs for resources as your home moves to the next biome. This almost clinical state of affairs really does show in the late game, when you find yourself trapesing across the blackforest, ignoring the hoard of greybeards following you like fan girls flocking behind that dude from JLS, because your one damn bit of copper short of making the final upgrade for a crafting station that's several chapters beyond on the progression tree.

But that is also what makes the gameplay of Valheim so appealing. What was once challenging becomes trivial with hard work. You earn your place in this world through blood, sweat, and many corpseruns in that loincloth. The game never stops giving you challenges and surprises that knock you sideways, but with clever thinking and learned skills you can triumph.

Note the word, Can.
Because Valheim is a vindictive Bast-

To use an oceanic analogy, as you spend alot of time sailing in this game (also, really enjoyable, takes skill, and has nice music.). It is like flicking a prawn at someone and them pimpslapping you in return with a giant sea serpent. Not only are you bamboozled because where the hell did that sea serpent come from but you stare at your screen going, what the hell just happened?
That is the sensation Valheim will give you, quite often. The difficulty curve is harder to scale than a cliff on a pogostick. It wasnt until the mistlands I learned you get parry bonuses, Thats the last developed biome by the way.

I would recommend this game to anyone. It is endearing, charming and hard. It makes you really feel like the Allfather is testing the very best in this realm. Word of advice? Bag the Crystal Battleaxe. That thing is Gorgeous and I used it all the way through. 

I really look forward to where Iron gate go in this game. If i could recommend anything to them it would be maybe the inclusion of more furniture options, as my mighty mead hall has the same things in every room and it feel a little empty.

Keep up the good work Lads!

Great sandbox design combined with an RPG style of gameplay.  I really enjoy the immense open world with beautiful scenery and simplistic yet nuanced approach.

Some cool physics introductions, but too much grinding, even in coop. The gameplay loop was designed by torturers, too much waiting time (e.g. fermenter) and too much needed material (iron finally gave me the reason to drop it). Building is unnecessarily complicated.
In conclusion, this game is only playable with mods, which I can understand from an early access. But all in all, this is not a game, this is a full time job.

I may only have 15 hours on Steam but I put a considerable number of hours in Valheim over on game pass.

This game is a joy, I usually don't enjoy the grind this genre usually comes with, however, something about Valheim is just SO satisfying
The building is really fun and I've lost many days between me and my friends building our village and numerous outposts
The combat is reasonably simple, however, when you first encounter the next biome it is scary, those monsters can and WILL kill you if you let your guard down just for a second, once you move to the next area and you're geared up the previous is no longer a threat

It's a hell of a game with a tonne of content to discover, vast lands to explore, many monsters to kill and of course, build and expand you viking village.

I'll be putting much more time into Valheim before it's done and I look forward to every second.

It's also the most polished game I have played in a very, very long time. I have encountered no bugs, no crashes, no weirdness, it is as polished as games should be and the developers should be proud that they've put out such a well made product.

They clearly care about the game and it is a labour of love. Passion, care and attention to detail are things that this game has in spades, if you're on the fence about this one and you enjoy other survival games this one is a no brainer, pick it up and enjoy your new viking life

Skall!

Edit: A few hundred hours later and a new world aimed at preparing for the Ashlands.

It's still a fantastic game, the Mistlands was terrifying, beautiful and gross all at the same time, (I'm looking at you, Ticks). The new gear and addition of a new combat style added some great variety to the game and the world modifiers allow me to play as I please, reducing the grind a little and allowing me to portal metals.

I can't wait to see what the Ashlands brings this year, if Mistlands is anything to go off it'll be a blast.

This game is the new benchmark that survival games use to get great playerbases. ive met soo many players from all walks of life, as this game respects YOUR time, weather you're a casual gamer that only has a few hour in the week between life's chores or a full time streamer that can spend days in this game it has something for all of the above. There's no need to be on to get lastest boss kill as its only there for a "season", there's no "battlepass" to try and complete to force you to play so you feel some accomplishment. You could just spend your few hours hunting deer in its majestic scenery or enjoy a sail on its oceans to see what a new island holds, even if you relish tricky combat its got that sorted for you with things like a giant troll swinging TREES! as clubs or the WTF! moment when you meet your first abomination and many more. Even if your a cozy gamer who likes nothing more than building and farming, its got you covered with only of the BEST building systems I've ever played with and some of the creations I've seen in survival buildings it lets you have sooo much freedom. I would have only one real negative comment which I know has been brought up plenty of times which is the multiplayer experience which is great but it can be limited to ten players (unless you use mods) but not so much on player hosted game but more on dedicated servers the lag you get from different people in different parts of the world can be annoying when your trying to be in combat and you see "rubberbanding" happen quite a few times, but this is my only real gripe about the game as a whole. I still fully recommend this game to anyone willing to give it a go and at such a good price even on full price for this game is amazing!

[b]Love this game![/b]
There's something for the hardcore and the more casual builder players. 
Also, the game is huge and expands massively as you get further and unlock new materials and crafting stations.

Valheim forces you to explore all around the world and makes it easy and enjoyable with boats and a nice map.
Enemies can't be taken for granted, you can't just spam attacks and while the combat is much more simple than something like a souls-like, the amount of weapon types, the parrying and the stamina makes the combat satisfying and allows for multiple playstyles. 

The building system is generous and even super simple houses are super fun to build! There's a grid but you are not forced to stick to it and the game allows for 26° and 45° angles. 
[u]BUILDERS BEWARE[/u] Monsters and especially raids, will f*ck up your base. Monsters when not able to target you, will aim for player built structures and tamed creatures, leaving you with all the items on the ground. While the first raids are easily defeated. A troll can make quick work of any wooden structure, ruining your day.
[b]To prevent this, dig a moat around your base OR turn off raids in the World Modifiers.[/b]

Overall, I recommend getting this game during the next sale if you like survival-crafting games and I plan on playing many more hours with friends.

Valheim - A Viking Saga of Epic Proportions

Valheim stands as a towering testament to the exploration and survival genre, offering a captivating Norse-inspired adventure that seamlessly blends brutal combat, intricate crafting, and an expansive world ripe for discovery. This game, designed for 1-10 players, is nothing short of a masterpiece that takes you on an exhilarating journey through a procedurally-generated world, challenging you to prove your mettle to Odin himself.

Stunning Exploration:
Embark on an odyssey through the Tenth World, a mysterious realm inspired by Norse mythology. Valheim beckons you to sail uncharted seas, confront bloodthirsty monsters, and unveil secrets lurking in distinct and immersive biomes. Every step is an opportunity for discovery, and each environment brings new challenges and wonders.

Mighty Halls and Customization:
Build viking longhouses that stand as monuments to your prowess. The detailed building system allows for customization both inside and out, progressing through tiers to upgrade and defend your base. Valheim empowers you to forge your legacy, crafting not just shelters but bastions of power and resilience.

Gather, Craft, and Survive:
In Valheim, survival is an art, requiring you to gather materials, craft weapons, armor, tools, and defenses. The game's intricate crafting system intertwines with its punishing yet rewarding combat. As you defeat mighty foes and discover new recipes, you'll sharpen your blades, brew potions, and progress through the challenges the world presents.

Key Features that Shine:

Immersive World: A procedurally-generated world teeming with distinct biomes, enemies, resources, and crafting recipes.
Multiplayer Excellence: Play solo or join forces with up to 10 players on dedicated servers, delving into limitless world creation and scaling challenges.
Stamina-Based Combat: Combat that rewards preparation and skill, featuring unique weapon attacks, blocking styles, ranged combat, and strategic maneuvers.
Rewarding Food System: A food system that doesn't punish but rewards, providing buffs based on the types of foods consumed.
Intuitive Crafting: Discover recipes as you explore, with resources and ingredients seamlessly integrated into your journey.
Flexible Building System: Construct shelters, villages, outposts, or claim abandoned buildings, all while considering structural integrity and ventilation.
Sailing and Exploration: Sail boats and ships to explore distant lands, braving the sea's riches and facing formidable monsters.
Epic Boss Fights: Engage in intense boss battles that challenge even the most prepared vikings, offering valuable rewards for your triumphs.
Valheim is not merely a game; it's an odyssey of epic proportions, an immersive and enthralling saga that captures the essence of Viking lore. With its meticulous attention to detail, flexible gameplay mechanics, and a world that invites boundless exploration, Valheim stands as a shining beacon in the pantheon of survival games. Raise your weapons, sharpen your blades, and prepare for a Viking journey like no other.
