Valheim is a unique take on the survival game genre, and one of the most successful I've encountered. It has a gorgeous minimalist art style complemented with modern lighting, and a Terraria-esque progression system that compels the player to explore their world and all the differing biomes and landscapes it has to offer. Considering that this game was developed by 5 people, I am blown away by the amount of content there is to sink your teeth into. The stakes are high, the combat is engaging, and preparation is key. The game's survival mechanics encourage the player to develop their infrastructure and plan their journeys carefully. If the gameplay loop of gather -> build -> craft -> explore -> fight appeals to you, and you're the type of person who enjoys feeling the rewards of their preparation, then I would recommend this game.

[h2] Pros: [/h2]
[list]
[*] [b]Food:[/b] The most engaging food mechanic I've encountered. Food doesn't exist solely to fill a hunger meter or heal the player, it is the primary means of progression in terms of upgrading the player's key stats: health and stamina. Consuming food provides substantial buffs to these values, and makes food a central focus of the games progression system. It encourages players to search for new food opportunities and cook a healthy variety of meals, rather than acquiring a surplus of one food item and forgetting about the entire mechanic.
[*] [b]Building:[/b] The building system in Valheim is much more flexible than meets the eye, and introduces interesting challenges that are not present in other games. For instance, structural stability is a crucial consideration a builder must make, as it prevents them from building too high or too far without the proper considerations for structural support, including the strength of the material used. Smoke ventilation is also crucial, and therefore chimneys are not aesthetic choices but mandatory for the proper functioning of a shelter. Working around these mechanics provides a unique challenge and sense of reward.
[*] [b]Exploration:[/b] Exploring the diverse world of Valheim is a rewarding experience, allowing the player to immerse themselves in the game's beautiful art style and fantastic soundtrack. It's exciting to find dungeons scattered throughout the world and discover the unique resources and enemies each biome has to offer. [i]Sailing[/i] is present in this game, and acts as the superior form of long-distance travel. This leads me to my next point..
[*] [b]Oceans:[/b] The oceans in this game are fun to sail for two reasons: water and weather mechanics. Weather is a consideration players must make before setting sail, for the seas produce towering waves and monstrous creatures that will seek your end. It is both humbling and hilarious to be thrashed about on the seas with your friends while trying to make it to safe land before shattering among the rocks.
[*] [b]Combat:[/b] While not the most complex combat system, Valheim offers a fun challenge that requires carefully timed inputs and preparation. There is substantial enemy variety, and simple button mashing is sure to get you killed. Boss fights are also exciting with unique mechanics and grand scale battle. Valheim's RPG skill system complements combat well, as you can tangibly feel your character improve as their skill increases.
[*] [b]Enemy AI:[/b] Surprisingly, the AI is intelligent enough to be a real nuisance sometimes. Their pathing works quite well and is difficult to cheese, while their sense of self preservation is both amusing and effective. Enemies respond to a players behavior, if a player behaves like prey, the enemies will be emboldened, if the player instead behaves with the intent to kill, the AI will behave more cautiously and even retreat from a fight if the player shows enough confidence. Some players might find this irritating, I find it hilarious and sensible.
[*] [b]Multiplayer:[/b] It goes without saying that this game is best experienced with friends. The multiplayer works quite well, and the process of building your base and exploring new lands is most rewarding when others benefit.
[/list]

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
[list]
[*] [b]Lack of ocean content[/b]: Although the oceans are fun to explore on a mechanical level, the game would supremely benefit from the addition of more content to the oceans. For example, enemy ships that track you down and attempt to sink you and your crew, more sea monsters to fear and hunt, and deeper ship customization. I imagine the tension that would be felt hauling a large shipment of ore while being chased by a fleet of raiders would add more excitement to the game.
[*] [b]Could use more furniture variety:[/b] While the amount of furniture already in the game is sufficient, as someone who draws most of their enjoyment from building, more options would provide a great deal of incentive. It is hard to list this as a true con however, as it is more of a personal preference.
[*] [b]Needs faster modes of travel on land:[/b] Unfortunately, the fastest way to travel over land is by foot. I believe the game would be improved significantly with the introduction of mounts and animal drawn carriages.
[/list]

Overall, Valheim is a survival game made with love and care. Anyone who enjoys carving out a place for themselves in a harsh land, adventure, and discovery will enjoy this game. It is [i]well[/i] worth the cost if you fall in this demographic, and it goes on sale often. Buy this game and support the developers!

Survival / Building/ Crafting /Exploration/ Seafaring/ Awesome fun time.

Honestly a really fun and inventive survival craft game. There is some odd design choices to get used to early on (Such as middle mouse button being block and middle mouse + space being dodge) but it's a great time overall. This is a very pretty looking game with lots of great atmosphere and ambiance. The music is very fitting for this kind of game as well.

The mechanics give a great sense of progression. I didn't think I would enjoy my various skills (like running, weapons, wood cutting etc.) to be leveled with xp, but I very quickly found it to be fun and rewarding. There is also a very great sense of wonder and curiosity to the game. I wanted to learn what things I could find and make to either improve myself or my base. There was also plenty of times while playing this game when I would think "What the hell is that?!" and then very quickly figure out what "that" was one way or another lol.

I haven't fully explored or beaten this game yet. So maybe the mid to late game gets brutal (If so I'll update this review later). This game seems to follow a rough defeat the bosses design path that Terria has. I've only beaten the second boss, but I wanted to write down the story about how I got to the location of the second boss.

A friend and I were playing the game when we stumbled across a burial chamber that had some parts we needed. We went exploring and took down every skeleton we came across. Then we found a rune that pointed us to the second boss. We looked on the map and saw it was farther than anywhere we explored. The next day we tried walking towards this boss location but found an issue. There was a large ocean between us and where the boss spawned. We would need to build a proper boat and sail across the sea. But it was going to be a long journey. Luckily from the burial chamber we found parts to build a portal that could link two spots together. I built the first portal in our home base, then we packed all of our materials and headed to the coast. We were worried that something might go wrong and this might mean we loose all of our gear. But that day had to be the day we were sailing, the wind was perfectly pointing north in the direction we needed to go. I set up a temporary workstation and built the Karve boat. Within seconds the boat start leaving, so my friend and I panicked and got in. I took the piloting seat and discovered how to un-hoist the sails and the ships starting pulling fast ahead. A few minutes later we spotted the land we were headed towards. I slowed the boat down and then beached the boat. My friend and I set up a temporary base and set up the second portal to return back to the base. Just over the hill was the shrine to summon the second boss.

This may not sound like a lot, and this might just be my lack of survival crafting game playtime showing, but honestly this experience in Valheim was pretty amazing. The perfect sequence of events and mechanics made it so we had to adventure into literally the unknown and find a creative solution to our problem.

So, yeah, overall I would highly reccomend this game. But due note this is a kind of "slow burn" game. This is the kind of game to either play solo or with a couple of friends for a few hours to just kinda explore, build, improve and have fun in.

2nd update, 2 years after EA release:
Two years later, game updates have significantly improved Valheim.  It's still more "brutal" than the average Minecraft enjoyer might like, but seems more fun than the usual PvEvP games of craft & survive (games I don't play). Still needs major QoL updates, as below.

1st update, 1 year after EA release:
Install the 3rd party software named BepInEx, then go to NexusMods, and download a dozen or more QoL mods and Valheim becomes playable at the enjoyment level of most standard crafting/survival games and eliminating all the unnecessary grinding (which is everything).
Music is still the #1 best part of this game.


My review comes from the point of view of someone who doesn't play hardcore crafting/survival games; only Minecraft and Starbound, since their respective betas, and No Man's Sky FWIW. I didn't jump on the bandwagon nor buy into the hyperbole/hype when it released in Early Access 2 years ago. There's a fun game here, but it's still marred by unnecessary design decisions that actively frustrate. Difficult to recommend honestly. Seems like it wants to appeal to Dark Souls fans who want a crafting-survival game, but may think Minecraft is too "kiddie" for their fragile image.



Original detailed review, updated:
Valheim is standard, run-of-the-mill survival game #589,431. But this time it's Norse mythology themed ohboysouniqueinsertprimitivecavemangruntshereorsomething. Seems it got popular on Twitch as this week's meme/fad game (everyone stream this because everyone else is), but I wouldn't know except for the Steam reviews making that obvious.
It's better than last month's survival game #589,430 (zombies!) and next month's survival game #589,432 (zombies again?) will be better.


PROS
* The music is delightful! The acoustic guitar is recorded played on the real instrument; you can hear the string scratches when the musician plays at times.
* The simple combat is satisfyingly more crunchy than Minecraft's.
* Loot that drops has the friendly magnetic pick-up effect, so you don't have to individually click on items to get them. (It only picks up when you walk right over an object though.)
* Status effects interact smartly -- if you're wet & have 2 minutes to dry off, standing by a fire rapidly lowers the timer instead of "poof you're instantly dry". Deer can smell you approach if they're downwind.
* Options to turn off bloom, field of view blur distortion, chromatic aberration, and screen shaking; thank effing Odin for that!
* It's a completely functional game released in Early Access with a roadmap and only $20.
* Can host your own server for friends-only, old-school style. Likewise there's a server browser.
* Gamepad support, native. Gamepad button prompts recognize Xbox, PS, and Nintendo controller differences.


NEUTRAL
* Game doesn't explain how to do anything -- for survival purists & experimentalists that's great, for folks who want to relax & play a game, not so much.
(Some things flat-out aren't intuitive, like using W & S to unfurl & furl the sail of the raft when you're expecting to point your cursor & press E like every other interactable in the game, and without a button prompt.)
* Building mechanics are serviceable but nothing outstanding. Snapping is nice. The unique building style will be foreign to Minecraft-alike builders, especially the need for supports & the roofing forcing realism.
* You gain health from killing things?  Also isn't explained.
* Graphical, LOD, pop-in, stutters, and despawn glitches [strike]will likely be ironed out since this is only the first-week Early Access but[/strike] are ((still, 2 years later)) present & distracting.
* The medium-poly models and pixelated "PS1 graphics fad" textures will put off elitist Gamers who expect "realistic" graphics in every modern game, or who saw screenshots that look higher fidelity from afar and didn't look closely at the foreground. Those Gamers will rush off to find an "HD" mod and a Reshade to over-oversaturate the game, but they would anyway. The aesthetic is done well here if you appreciate this art style (I do).


CONS
* YOU LOSE SKILL PROGRESS WHEN YOU DIE! This is the "brutal" thing from the store description "A brutal exploration and survival game..."
* Gathering resources is slow going. Valheim does not respect the player's time. Absolutely everything in this game is a massive grind / time sink.
* No paper doll to equip gear, so gear is another item in your small inventory grid which you click on to equip & unequip.
* Game design decisions are sometimes intentionally, frustratingly unfriendly (see 'lack of paper doll for gear' comment above, and earlier mention of raft sail's deployment being 2 extra, unnecessary buttons even though the game established a prime interact button which would be expected to be used; and doesn't show the button prompts for these new, foreign button interactions) such as roll dodging being a 3 (yes 3!) button combo press, instead of simply double-tapping a direction. You've heard the phrase "change for change's sake"? Valhiem devs designed "difficult for difficult's sake" -- or plainly stated another way: intentionally designed to be unfriendly to the player. It's not even, as the game's store description would allude to, "brutal" as it's simply anti-player.
* Cooking food is on a timer, just short enough to have to interact with it so it won't get burned into coal that you can't do anything else but stare at it.
* Ancient individual skill leveling mechanics that even the Elder Scrolls series & World of Warcraft dropped over a decade ago: each action (run, jump, swim, punch, block, wood chopping...) has an XP bar. Want to level anything up? Grind out your literal gameplay time doing it. Want to level up blocking attacks? Aggro a mob, then put a weight on your RMB so you block every attack for an hour. Assume leveling running you can stick yourself in a corner and depress W with autorun on, or use a weighted drinking bird toy to repeatedly tap spacebar to level jumping like it was Ultima 8 circa 1994.
This method of individual skill XP bars servers to artificially gate your progress, slower than a simple single character leveling stat.
* Frequent bug where you can't pick anything up. Have to save then logout to the main menu, then reload the save to fix. (From what I've heard, that's been present since the beginning, 2 years ago now.)
* Gamepad button prompts are not present in all menus/situations. On top of that, I found often the PS5 button prompts show the Xbox ones in menus (obviously 'X' on each controller type is placed different & don't correspond.)
* No gameplay tweaks available. (...ergo the need for QoL mods to enjoy the game; not having to manually refuel all fire sources, increase drop rates, etc etc.  The updated/second ValheimPlus mod lets you configure several dozen options to your liking that the base game should have had allowed you to do natively, like Atlas does for example.)
* The expected basic hunger mechanic is even worse than other games by limiting what foodstuffs you can eat to a single item of 3 until that one wears off, then you can't consume another of that type. Apparently Valheim doesn't use a hunger meter but the machismo Vikings have a taste buds meter. (At least you don't die of starvation in this game. But if you don't eat 3 different foodstuffs at all times, you'll have the stamina of a baby.)

Summary:
Very fun game, alone or with friends, with many hours of content even if you go straight for progressing through the bosses. Robust enough building system that I can spend hours creating a small walled-in village for my friends to live in (and not get bored with it). Good survival mechanics that aren't so unforgiving that they become overly frustrating. And you get to feel like a powerful fantasy viking that slays giant monsters and mounts their heads over your mead hall.

Features I really like:
- Really clear tech progression that touches nearly every game aspect, and doesn't have useless steps.
- Lots of build possibilities.
- Skills progress as you use them.
- Food is important for the stats, but you won't starve if you don't have anything to eat.
- Large world to explore, with a lot of variety between biomes, including visuals, resources and enemies.
- Good overall visual style, but stylized in a way that's easy on hard drive space.
- You get all materials back when you destroy structures.
- Variety of weapons with pros and cons.
- Sailing.
- More than 4 or 5 people can play together at once.

Areas that could be improved:
- I wish there was more aesthetic variety in construction, like paint or stains.
- A way to recycle or destroy old armor/weapons/tools would be very useful.

I would definitely not recommend base game Valheim to anybody. It's extremely grindy, has frequent significant setbacks, and hours and hours of repetitive farming to progress at a snail's crawl. I would strongly recommend playing it now that world modifiers are out- I play with 3x drop and being able to move all items between portals. Prior to this, it would take several hours of playing for several days straight to gear up several people. Now it only takes a few hours. World modifiers have made this game less of a masochistic slog and a lot more enjoyable to play with friends. 

If you're worried you'll miss out on base game hours and hours of grinding, don't worry, even with 3x drop it still took 4 friends and I about 10 hours to get us all geared up with silver once we hit the mountains. Much better than nearly a week without modifiers.

Valheim is a breathtaking journey through Norse mythology, offering players a captivating blend of survival, exploration, and legendary battles. The immersive open-world environment, coupled with stunning visuals and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, creates a gaming experience that is nothing short of enchanting. The game's emphasis on collaboration and strategic thinking fosters a sense of camaraderie among players, as they forge their own Viking sagas in a vast and dynamic world. Valheim seamlessly weaves together challenging gameplay with a rich narrative, delivering an inspiring adventure that beckons you to explore, build, and conquer the untamed wilderness. In the face of mythical beasts and the harsh elements, Valheim encourages resilience and teamwork, making it a truly epic odyssey that will leave you yearning for more.

I want to like this game, I really tried to like this game - the game does not want to be liked.

The game is inherently flawed from top to bottom in a vast number of ways:
- Valheim gives you solutions to biomes by way of resistance meads, but allows you to make them seemingly when you can obtain the ingredients needed reliably -- in other words: when they're obsolete.

- Valheim suffers incredibly by giving the player a bunch of different items of varying, arbitrary stack limits at certain points of progression, where the purpose (or purposes) of said items are unknown until you get all of the pieces needed to make it. I still have no idea what the point of entrails are, but I have three stacks of them next to my honey chest.

- Valheim has great base building features, all of it absolutely marred by time you kill Bonemass and your base is obliterated by flying drakes that will three shot you in your own home, and then kill your precious bees. Why do they do this? Because you wanted your base to look pretty, and not a grey VIKING DOME of stone that would absolutely keep your three stacks of entrails safe. (Still have no idea what they do)

- About 25 hours in, me and my boys had decided that Unrestricted Portals was probably a smart idea given that Bonemass was in Africa, and we were in Canada. That's a pretty large distance, and to transport 15 stacks of iron (even with carts, and belts) via boats given to us at the time (kurve), it would take multiple trips, and that's just some phone game levels of disrespecting a player's time.

- Dying in the mountains shows a horrible flaw with the game in that even with full food buffs, damage scaling makes no sense. Something is either too damaging, or too weak to make you even feel it, not even worth a screen shake like it does. If a stone golem decides to destroy rocks above you while you try to explore a stone stairwell with a chest in it, well, goodbye gear. Why? Because the stone golem is now in that hole - with your gear - and you are now naked. You will either die trying to get your gear, or die of the cold if the body is too far up the mountain.

- Exploration is inherently flawed. The bones are good, I liked wandering around early game, finding stuff. But the lack of variety in dungeons, their enemies, and their rewards (no super rare gear other than the skeleton shield? That was cool, why not more of that?) After you've seen what the game has to offer in the forest biome, you realise that every biome is basically a different hue of the same thing, but with more needless busywork attached to it.

- Needless busywork. Everything is a chore. The game feels like it's going to ask me to spend Viking Coin to speed up fermenters, or repair my whole base (which should be a thing, mass repair should be a base feature, not a mod), or skip raids.

- Lack of enemy diversity. Early game all you see are Greylings, and different Greydwarfs. They will travel 500km in the rain to come throw a rock at you. That will be your early game for at least eight hours. When you get to the swamp? Drauger archers. When you get to the mountains? Wolves. When you get to the plains? Mosquitos. There's always a really oppressively overtuned, annoying enemy that's everywhere. Because the dev team is made of sadists.

All-in-all, I really wanted to like Valheim. Early game it had me, I enjoyed myself. Then I started progressing, and the game became asking "why is this like this?" The game's difficulty is fine - it's the design and gameplay loop that's masochistic to suffer through.

TL;DR - Terraria is the best survival game there is, full stop.

Valheim is a great trip back in time with it's classic, but timeless, art style and it's Runescape like take on a levelling system. It can either be the most relaxing survival game you've ever played or the most challenging depending on how you want to play it making for a much more personalised experience that anyone can enjoy. 
 This game really feels like a standout amongst the current AAA behemoths in the gaming industry and focuses on simple pure fun as opposed to the trend-chasing cash grabs we see all too often. Every moment in this masterpiece feels handcrafted to deliver the most authentic and engaging experience on the market currently.

Valheim is a wonderful mixture that is incredibly fun to play and beautiful to look at.

The building system is well-made, featuring stability through colors from green to red. Building a longhouse was very satisfying - I had to redo the foundation multiple times and it was just plain fun. 

The combat system is well-rounded, really making you feel like a mortal and not like some demi-god that can take countless hits.

The ability to take your character with you is a huge deal for me, as playing with friends now let's them take (parts of the) progression to single player. You can teach the basics to friends directly and they are able to take that progression back to own games without any hustle. 

Summarized: I really like Valheim and I hope Iron Gate will put out Updates for a long time.

I'd like to start with how much I love the premise of this game, and it is gorgeously executed. The mechanics are excellent, and the experience is what I can only describe as joyful and deeply satisfying. 
Progression is slow, and difficulty doesn't keep up until it suddenly does and then it is super hard again...only to slowly become too easy again. Resources are hard to come by, and then suddenly abundant, and then progression catches up again and new resources are scarce and hard to acquire but necessary for survival. It ebbs and flows like this in many ways, frustration followed by boredom and perhaps a little depression. These waves are randomly peppered with moments of joy and peace. A felled tree caused another tree to fall towards me like a giant baseball bat, and was saved by another tree I was close enough to get behind. It was an indescribably thrilling moment unrivaled in my gaming lifetime. Entering the unexpected violence of the Ocean Biome was equally thrilling...and terrifying. 
However, I do have two criticisms. The first is minor: The deer are annoyingly noisy. You can't overhunt them into extinction either, which was disappointing. At least so far, I'll keep trying. 
The second is more serious. There's not much variety. As far as I can tell there are only 6 biomes maybe, each of them have maybe 5 different mobs and 7 or 8 different resources. I know it's still in early access, and they are adding 2 more biomes, eventually. Hopefully they'll pad the existing biomes in time? 
Overall, I approve.

I play a lot of open world survival games. One of the aspects I enjoy most about open world survival is the struggle to survive in early game. Typically once I am set up and powerful enough that the challenge of survival is removed I get bored of it.
Valheim certainly does not remove the struggle to survive. But perhaps shifts this a little too far in the opposite direction.
***Small Spoilers ahead.***
* Biomes - You never feel comfortable in this game. Each Biome brings new challenges that are deadly. The tech tree is clearly laid and and progression through the tree is well defined. The same cannot be said for the Biomes and which you should visit in correct order. You are free to explore but visiting the wrong biome will result in your swift death. The map is laid out in a circular fashion and the further out you go from spawn the more difficult biomes you encounter. Though, it is quite easy to locate Biomes you have no business being in early game, such as swamp, or plains biomes. I do find progression through the tech tree and equipment feels a little cheated when you kit yourself out with all iron gear, visit the wrong biome and get one shot. 
* Teleporters - With such a giant map, Teleporters are a welcome in game device to travel great distances. Though the design choice to not allow ore to be transported through teleporters is clearly designed to force the building of outposts, I find this design choice is solely forced on the player to lengthen the games hours count forcing the player to load up ships for ferrying ore vast distances. This can become tedious. Also, with how easy it is to die in this game, dropping all of your equipment forcing you to travel back to that spot to collect it, but without the ability to teleport ore means you can't teleport the material to build another ship and sale from that closer base you were forced to build. Leading to constructing a ship from your main base, and sailing it perhaps 30 minutes to attempt to collect your gear, fail, and you repeat the process. It is easy to have several ships in one place, and hours spent frustrated. Do not buy this game if your prefer one main base to operate from, or at the least, mod the game to allow ore to be teleported.
* Experience Levels - The levelling system in the game is nearly invisible and based on the skill you use most levelling up. But, I didn't find any meaningful progression through levels and no extra abilities were unlocked by gaining a level. To me the level system was largely pointless.
* Stamina/Health - Having stamina and health in the game the way it is set up, based on what food you eat and only temporarily boosted negates much of the levelling up and progression through the game. Your character does not get tougher the longer you play. The very first moments of the game your character is just as tough as in the 100th hour, based on what food they eat. Truly the only progression in this game is the gear you wear and carry. The food you eat decides the balance between hit points and stamina and it is always a balance you need to manage. Swimming I find ridiculous as your character is lucky to survive swimming across a small channel, and will commence drowning the instant they run out of stamina. Running also drains stamina leading to some harrowing battles with large enemies, as you try and balance health and stamina drain.
* Conclusion - I find Valheim hits the mark in some respects but misses in others. Players that talk about grinding would do well to avoid this one as the game is designed for the grind. The design choice to not allow ore to be teleported leads to many additional hours of grinding for grind's sake. I tend to have a lot of patience in games for grinding, but even my patience was stretched thin with this title. I found with little direction on which biome to visit next lead to some frustrating instant deaths followed by grinding to get back there and reclaim my gear. Overall, I am on the fence whether to recommend this game. If you don't mind grinding then go for it, if pointless repetition is going to turn you off I'd say avoid it, or mod the game. In the end I am not recommending this game as there is too much grinding to it, even for me.

This game has the best building mechanics I've seen in any sandbox game of its kind. Its simple to understand, and thing generally just work the way you want them to. While there are snap points, you aren't restricted to using only the provided snap points which allows for a high degree of creative freedom. Too many sandbox games have a blocky building system and valheim is FAR from that. Combat an exploration is also very good!

STUB review::: I will update this review and write a proper one when I have the time, but for the time being I at least want to give a heads up on whether it's good or not, so...

It's great! I DEFINITELY recommend it if you love survival games. It's a mixture of Dark Souls, Minecraft and Vikings. Had a LOT of fun and STILL having it playing it with friends (doing a 3rd run currently, we come back to this every few months since release). Netcode is good. No issues with desyncs so far.

Valheim is something special.
Compared to most open world survival games it feels like every hunt and every exploration has a purpose.
Building and Upgrading your camp is super fun and makes you feel rewarrding. And so 
does the kind of mysterious world and that for every piece of information collected and bringing mechanics together feels just great.

On the other hand, this can be frustrating as hell.
This one is supposed to be difficult. Thats certain.
But it is a bit on the punishing side at times.

Also it will not get easier in later stages to aquire certain materials.
The enemys might be less strong later on with gear upgraded, but the paths stay the same.
And they will get even longer since after you have depleted all the ressources in your close environment you have to go further every single time.
This can lead to time consuming expiditions just to get some pieces of ressource that you had activly needed 20 hours ago.
Alos there is no automation. Everything has to be done by players.

The cool thing though, you can play with 10 people out of the box and even more with setting up your own dedicated server and a few tweaks. This opens up a type of progression where the guys with lots of time to spare could go in and fulfill their urge while others could go in and play at their own pace all while milestones and bossfights could be done together.

I hope this receives some QoL updates with the probably final update with the Ashlands Biome.
Until then, its a supor cool game but has a bit of struggle and grind to it as well.

Sincerely Yours

All that being said, Valheim is still listed as an early access game so who knows what changes the future may bring!!

shit

I want to like this game and I did enjoy it for the first 20 hours but now it's become a chore of mining traveling, mining traveling, back and forth to my base for hours upon hours. I am at the swamp stage which I reckon is where most people quit the game because of how tedious and annoying it gets. There are so many small little nitty gritty things that tear you apart psychologically in this game, one drop after the other until you've had enough.

Here is a list:

* You constantly run out of stamina all the time. Stamina is spent when you are running, jumping, fighting, building and even sneaking. After just a few swings with your mace you will run out of stamina when fighting mobs, which basically turns your character into glue for a short moment.

There are a lot of mobs that spawn everywhere in this game as well, and you have to walk away from these mobs since you can't run when your stamina is depleted, which makes it so that you get hit from the back while trying to escape.

This happens all the time and it's so annoying to the point where I just wanna quit the game. In order to fix this you have to download third party mods which is kinda sketchy. Just make it an option to turn off stamina in-game.



* The AI in this game is weird. Most mobs seems to be following a pattern of hitting you once then running away from you in an 8 pattern circle and then hitting you once again. The boss fights are not very exciting either. The bosses that I have fought mostly just stand still and walk around a little bit whilst shooting things at you, except for Eikthyr.



* Monsters keep interupting you as you fight bosses. I was fighting The Elder and half of the fight was me and my friend trying to deal with random mobs coming out of nowhere.



* It feels like you're being punished for progressing in the game. I have finally acquired a full set of iron armour after long hours of grinding and now I get slapped with a -5% movement speed for every armour piece except for the helmet, along with my iron axe which gives me an additional -5% movement speed. In total I have now -15% movement speed in combination with the horrible stamina system.



* Your baseline HP is set at 25. You would think that you could gain some HP points if you leveled up or defeated some bosses but no, you have to be constantly eating if you want your HP to be higher than this. Maybe it's just me but I find it pretty annoying.

I know it's a survival game and all but it'd be way nicer if my baseline HP could be a little bit higher. It would be better if they made food a nice and helpful addition instead of making it mandatory to eat 3 different meat variants every 15 minutes.



* Troll raids destroying your base defenses as if your walls was made out of nothing but paper. It doesn't matter if you are using wood materials or stone materials, it's all made out of paper to the giant trolls. The only way to circumvent your base being smashed is by using a tool to raise the ground in order to make the AI obsolete.



* Way too few inventory slots and too little max weight allowed. My inventory gets filled up in no time, and at least 1/3 of the space is already taken up by all the gear that I need to survive the swamp biome.

Your max weight is 450kg, and 1 iron ore weighs 10kg. Around 100kg will be taken up from before because of all your gear so you can only bring home about 35 iron ores and then you need to travel back again. Keep in mind that traveling is very time consuming in this game, it starts becoming as boring as watching paint dry after your first 20 hours.



* When you die you drop all your items which is completely fine with me, but the problem is that the mobs and even bosses that kill you stay on your corpse instead of despawning. I have been exposed to situations where i have died over 5 times when trying to retrieve my items.



* You need to place a workbench in order to build and do anything at all. You can't even place a simple campfire without having placed a workbench first. It's such a small little thing but it gets rather annoying when you have to deal with this feature whilst out on your adventures. Just let me build.


Overall it feels like the whole world is against you in this game and not in a good way. The developers have put certain features in Valheim supposedly to make this game more difficult, but they are just making the game more annoying. I very much enjoy overcoming difficult games but there is nothing to overcome here, the game design itself is rigged against you.

You would think that the game developers could fix their game and come with regular updates to add more content, especially when you consider the fact that they've sold millions of copies and made many many millions of dollars, but no. Valheim feels very much like an unfinished product, and how long will they have this game in early access? 5 years? 10 years?

Maybe this game is just not for me, but then again this is one of my favorite game genres so I should like it, and to some extent I do, but it feels like I am being fucked over by the game it self over and over again.

At a glance, Valheim is beautiful and seemingly pristine and pretty fun. However, once you get into the "meat" of it all, Valheim becomes one of the most ruthless types of games out there. The art style will deceive you, and you'll find yourself wandering around at first like pff this is easy. You're wrong, very very wrong. From little tree men to the trolls, to draugr (zombies). Once you set off from the meadows, you will encounter more and more dangerous creatures than you did before. Whether you're a new or existing player, there is an affect that Valheim will instill upon you. Inspired by Norse Mythology, they take a little bit of those myths and combine them with their own innovations and ideas, making for a game that won't just make you sit in awe of it's beauty, but fear the dangers from every corner and every sound from the environment that even begins to seem like another being is near you.

For those who cannot handle battle intensive games, you can still get something from this game. You can build bases, you can fish, you can do all the survivaly things and buildy things you could imagine. They recently updated it with the ability to lower the difficulty for those like myself who have a harder time reacting to things. I'm very awful at parrying enemies, so I use a larger shield. I also do use the lower difficulty settings, or even turn it all off if I just want to focus on building stuff. There's all kinds of ways to enjoy this game. Whether that's the battling monsters, or the building, fishing, and very chill moments of Valheim. What ever you decide to do in Valheim, you will most likely be drawn in by its beauty and sense of nostalgic it brings from the art style they chose to go with. It's one of the most unique styles out there, and in my opinion one of the best. 

So if you have been debating on getting this game, just get it, adjust the settings however you want, and try to explore and see the world of Valheim for yourself. You'll most likely enjoy it as I do, and I'm not a very battle intensive person when it comes to games. So just give it a shot. Nevermind the difficulty you might of heard from some people, with the new settings for adjustments, anyone can play and enjoy this game. As an avid lover of Norse Mythology too, I find myself immersed in a magical and mysterious world that has yet to reveal more secrets as time goes on.

This game is fun to play with several motivated friends for some time but usually the motivation does not last long. At some point you realize how sketchy the game still is. Starting with the tiny number of different building blocks to the variation of monsters to the game mechanics and the gameplay in general. So classifying this game as early access is a good choice. After not playing for a year on my first login my charater learns new crafting recipes - a new door and a stationary torch.

If I had the choice again I would put my time in a different game, wait five years and check if they have bothered to slightly finish this game.

This game is AWFUL...LOUSY TARGETING, LOW RESPONSE TIME, NO INSTRUCTIONS EXCEPT THOSE YOU MIGHT FIND ON INTERNET, NO ICON IDENTIFICATION WHEN HOVERING OR RIGHT CLICKING...JUST ALL AROUND ONE OF THE MOST UNFRIENDLY, UNINTUITIVE GAMES I HAVE EVER PLAYED IN FORTY PLUS YEARS OF BETA TESTING.  I paid about twelve bucks and it wasn' t even worth that.  It is a shame too, cause the game has potential, it is just crappily written and whoever beta tested it must have had their eyes CLOSED.  It is a real shame cause it could have been a good game.  Instead they rushed it out...I mean auto targeting and decent building abilities would have improved it enough to make it playable.  The development team needs to play Grounded, Stray Blade and Smalland and get some pointers on targeting and building and try to fix it...but I don't know if it is even possible.  Good concept but rotten, rotten execution.  I rarely pan a game but this one gets the skillet:).

OK...after about 350 more hours (I always give even the worst games in beta at least 500 hours before deleting it entirely) I have an update on my review.  IF you turn the mouse to its highest reaction time, you can target a bit more effectively but still cannot isolate an individual out of a group or concentrate on a particular foe.  The game has potential but the fact that you have to build a worktable to do anything and not just a worktable but one with a roof and walls makes building a quickie place to respawn while exploring very annoying.  A base camp is needed every day's walk...one with workbench, walls, roof, bed, campfire, at least one chest to hold items while you are out exploring and items to resupply if you die so you can go get the rest of your stuff is best, especially for new players.  There should be at least two more full sets of quick spaces to facilitate weapons, food, etc without having to open the inventory would be nice.  The developers really need to play Grounded for basic ideas on camps and immediate inventory.  One thing that drives me nuts is ending up naked and weaponless if you die.  Practically, it makes no sense.  I mean really, when you die...do your clothes fall off?  Having studied basic history I am certain Vikings were sent into the afterlife with full armor and weapons so historically, one should keep their armor and weapon they had in hand at death when they respawn. 

 https://thevikingsway.com/viking-burial-rituals-and-funerary-practices/#aioseo-2-grave-goods-wealth-for-the-journey-beyond

This site describes some of the rituals and as it states, like most societies of that time, particularly those frequently known as conquerors weapons and armor were sent with the deceased into the afterlife.
The game can be addictive but it is a hard, arduous slough so far...so if you don't mind a lot of dying and running to get the basics back, it has possibilities.  I like Grounded a whole lot better for game play but this one has its upside as well.  One other suggestion would be an option to enlarge the map inset.  Not everyone who plays these games is 15 with perfect eyesight.  In a game with modifiers, they should think about the entire demographic...those over fifty too.  The game should pause action or at least have the option to pause action while the map and inventory are opened.  The more options available, the more expansive the game playing demographic and that means more sales, better game enjoyment and better reviews.

The game is good, and I wish we could leave a neutral review. The first ~80 hours of the game were great and I felt that it was very much worth the money.

I was amazed at the first 2 biomes and the various discoveries, the 3rd biome is okay not great, the 4th biome is interesting, and the 5th biome feels rushed: the creatures, resources and armors all feels unpolished and a bit out of place. It lacks a bit of coherency in my opinion and that's when the game starts to be repetitive without adding new mechanics. For example you get the core metal by just farming monsters while you needed to find the resources with special mechanics in the previous biomes. It was a chore to go through it because I started to feel bored/uninterested to the point where I didn't want to log in the game anymore. 
Everything I built suddenly felt a bit worthless and I had no desire to keep building on it. It left me with a bad feeling despite having enjoyed it so much up to this point.

Unfortunately, updates are very slow and communication from the team is not reassuring. The next biome does not seems to be coming anytime soon and there is no plan to rework this 5th biome as far as I'm aware.
Because the game was such a success commercially, I expected the studio to hire developers and turn a good game into a true gem, instead of doing the bare minimum.

Edit: the 6th biome is out and there is new mechanics, however it reuse some assets from previous biomes / NPC and don't have a strong feeling of novelty. The progression is getting repetitive I think. Maybe 4 biomes were enough, if they were a bit more varied?

Game crashes have been fixed but it seems that there are some core issues to how the game systems work. Combat is pretty bare bones and your character cannot aim up or down for some reason, meaning you must always fight on level ground in order to hit an enemy; however, enemies can hit you at an angle so you are at a disadvantage. I don't think it would be insanely difficult for your character to actually swing where your cursor is... but here we are. 

Combat is largely one dimensional with the core loop being, parry -> attack -> repeat. There are no incentives to fight in any other way and towards the higher enemy types this pattern is mandatory to kill enemies quickly. All weapons have a simple 2 or 3 attack animation cycle that repeats over and over, there is no switching this up aside from a "heavy" attack which is usually just a forward lunge. There are no real unique flavors to the weapons as they all amount to the same cycle of parry -> attack -> repeat. It would be nice if the weapons actually had character and dramatically changed the way you fought. Different move sets with actual impact like knocking enemies prone, into one another, or up into the air. They could apply different status effects like bleeding, vulnerable to certain types of damage, slowing enemy attack speed, or weakening enemy strikes.

Crafting gear, and upgrading it, in this game is incredibly grind focused with later gear sets requiring absurd amounts of materials. This seems to be tuned in a way just to pad the runtime of the game but that just forces you to repeat the dull exploration and combat cycles over and over. There are two types of armor in the game, heavy and light. Heavy armor reduces movement speed but offers a higher value of protection while light armor does not impede movement. There is essentially no late game light armor, so if you decide to run a light armor character you will inevitably get one shot by any enemy beyond a certain point in the game.

I think this game has a lot of potential but the number of systems that have been added, and lack of depth in them, hinders the game more than it helps it. If the developers focused more on making the world an interesting place, with combat that was more rewarding, and balanced weapons/armors for more diverse play styles I would recommend this game. However as it stands, I can't play more than 10 or 15 hours without getting bored of the underdeveloped systems present in the game today.

By far one of the best open world survival/craft games out there. Top tier in the genre.
4000 hours played. It's ok.

Graphics: Use upscaling and turn settings down to create runescape vibes. Turn them all the way up to max out your GPU for beautiful atmosphere.

Combat: You progress your damage/armor through gear. Food buffs HP and stamina the way leveling traditionally would. Weapons confer situational pros and cons that you can min-max to fight different enemies or suit different styles of combat. 

Building: You are heavily limited, but this grounds your creations in the world of vikings. The more fancy a thing is, the more likely its ingredients result from performing some difficult task in the game, The experience of progressing from wilderness to civilization must be felt to be understood.

Progression: You enter an environment which wants to kill you, but which offers you resources that can be used to grow stronger. You kill enemies and extract resources in order to build a supply of gear. You then kill a boss and start the progression over with a new region. Each time, your contributions from the last iteration remain relevant to the current one, creating a sense of progress that does not go away. Even your inferior gear becomes relevant when you die and respawn at your bed with only your second-strongest gear.

Conclusion: This is an excellent time vampire, and particularly one I would recommend for those who enjoy mining/farming in minecraft as well as those who like tactical first-person shooters and fromsoft games. For those playing with friends, this is an MMORPG experience which continually provides challenges to overcome with your friends.

World modifiers changed everything bad about this game. For the ultimate experience, drag every slider all the way to the easiest, but delete the world and character when you die.

Perhaps this sounds too easy, but no. Fights are now as difficult as the combat system deserves, and you cut down on grind, death loops and travel time, but everything that made this game fun still remains the same. If anything, proper preparation and decision making will be even more important than in normal playthroughs.

[strike]If you play on normal difficulty and you're expecting Minecraft, you're in for a nasty surprise.  It's more like Dark Souls.  I really really wanted to like this game, but advancing your construction methods requires killing bosses and raiding dungeons for materials that you can only get there.  Even making structures out of stone is gated behind acquiring a bunch of iron to make the workbench upgrade you need, meaning you have to kill 2 bosses, and find iron in swamp dungeons, guarded by draugr that will 2 shot you in fully upgraded bronze armor.  You can't get it anywhere else.  It's heavy, and you can't take it through portals.  All the swamps I've found are only accessible by boat.  Guess what.  If you die in a dungeon you took a boat to get to, to get back you need to build another boat.  It is exceedingly frustrating.  I bought it in late 2022, so I've had it for over a year and haven't even put 200 hours into it.  The ragequits are on another level.  I'm uninstalling.[/strike]

After a bit of venting to the community it was brought to my attention that I was making a critical gameplay error.  I had been using foods that gave large bonuses to stamina but only small bonuses to health, and in doing so I inadvertently subjected myself to the Dark Souls experience.  I had great mobility in combat at the cost of immediate, often fatal, punishment for less than perfect execution.  I have since revised my dietary guidelines and found combat to be much more forgiving.  I also want to give a shout out to the community for giving me their support when, admittedly, I didn't deserve it.  Good people all around.

First survival game in a while that I can just play to chill out and not stress about getting raided and I'm nowhere close to get bored of it.
Good stuff:
Not frustrating survival game - PvP is optional (turned off by default), destroyed buildings return 100% of resources used, no resources needed to repair tools or buildings.
PvE raids are sporadic and pretty short, what type of raid occurs is based on next boss you fight and they usually happen where you are at in the moment of a raid, no surprises when you get back home and you see a bunch of mobs chewing on your buildings. Each one gets a little harder but that's only because of types of mobs that attack you.
Amazing fight mechanic - no mindless spamming quick attack and watching health bar go down, gotta learn them patterns and block attacks, standard mobs also have patterns you can learn but are easy to deal with, except trolls, trolls are a big fun blue boys that want to party with you in Black Forrest whenever you least expect it.
Health system that requires you to eat food to have more health and stamina
Pretty neat building system
As for multiplayer I highly suggest using Dedicated server tool (located in steam tools library), you might need to find a guide on how to set it up properly but it's well worth it instead of hosting a game directly from the menus.
In conclusion, if you look for a survival game that is chill, this is the one.

Embarking on the captivating voyage that is Valheim feels akin to unlocking the door to a hidden realm, where you not only play as a Viking but release your very soul into the ancient, windswept days of Norse lore. This game is not just a journey; it's an emotional odyssey that unfurls the layers of your inner Viking.

As you step onto the rugged shores of Valheim, the untamed beauty of the landscapes mirrors the spirit of the Norsemen. The sun-kissed meadows and towering snow-capped mountains create a living, breathing canvas that beckons you to explore, just as the Vikings once did. Each sunrise and sunset feels like a chapter in an epic saga, painted with hues that ignite a fiery passion within the player.

The moments of solitude, whether traversing dense forests or sailing turbulent seas, evoke a powerful connection to the Viking spirit. The haunting echoes of the wind, the rhythmic sound of oars slicing through water – they weave a symphony that resonates with the solitude of Viking warriors, stirring a sense of longing for a bygone era.

The cooperative aspect of Valheim amplifies the emotional depth. Building mighty longhouses and fortresses with fellow Vikings creates a sense of camaraderie that transcends the digital realm. It's not just about survival; it's about forging bonds that echo the brotherhood of warriors who sailed together into the unknown.

However, as the seasons change and you face formidable adversaries, a poignant realization sets in. The melancholy of seeing your creations tested and the somber undertone of the Norse world weighing on your soul become undeniable. The laughter shared in the mead halls turns bittersweet, for you know that every saga must come to an end.

As the final credits roll, a deep sense of loss settles in. The beautiful landscapes you once traversed, the bonds forged, and the battles fought become memories etched in the digital fabric of Valheim. It's a farewell to a world that became a home, leaving a void that echoes with the poignant whisper of the Viking spirits now at rest.

Valheim is not just a game; it's a heart-wrenching journey into the heart of Viking legacy, where emotions flow as freely as the rivers that once guided their longships. It's an ode to a time lost, leaving players with a sorrowful sense of longing for a place that never truly existed but will forever remain etched in their souls.

These people are over promising and under delivering. So i will not recommend this game until they prove they are not liars.

Wise words from a Norse adventurer:

1) Always put a portal down upon arriving somewhere new— especially if you traveled far and/or to somewhere dangerous. Trust me. 😭

2) Roll gives you some invincibility frames. This helps a lot when you have no arrow and want to combat a difficult enemy at close range, or escape a near-death experience.

3) If you die in a hard time get to spot, die again in a relatively close, but safe area. Then, grab that grave stone to get the "Corpse Run" buff which heals you like 5hp/tick and significantly decreases stamina usage. Lastly, zoom over to your original grave like Hermes. Zoooomm.

Thanks for reading~

Valheim is a giant game. From meadows to mistlands, this game offers hours upon hours of entertainment. The game's progression is linear, measured in the strength of your equipment, and ability to gather new recourses and process them.

The game also offers much in terms of all survival game aspects, as theres plenty to be done for farming, cooking, building and making the world lovely.

The pacing is fantastic, played to a point where you almost start to feel overpowered, until you discover a new area, and get crushed again. Its incredibly addictive because of this, and i cant recommend it enough, as the addictive nature ensures that you will get the hours of content you paid for.

On the second side of the coin though, the game is difficult, with a learning curve like a hockey stick, and its not for those who cant push past that and get into the game. I personally recommend this game, but some simply might find it too infuriating to deal with the flaws. I myself have ragequit several times, though I've always come back. And if you are struggling, the difficulty is adjustable if necesarry

I also want to state that at the time of this review, valheim is still getting updates, and theres still lore that i am yet to read up on. The ashlands are under development, and Im sure more is to come.

In conclusion, I feel this game is worth the pricetag and rage, especially if played with friends. I want to recommend it to those who feel like a challenging survival game, riddled with bossfights and building. If you feel like a more relaxed game less about combat and more about leaning back and sighing contentedly, I say steer clear.

This game allows for great fun, but for me it was really about the people I played it with. It gives you all the tools to have a great time, but offers little direction on what to do with them. I did not enjoy this game that much solo. With my friends though I had some of the most fun I've ever heard in a game. It had been ages since we all congregated around one game, but Valheim pulled us all in and we quickly all had hundreds of hours in it. As far as survival and crafting games go this is a pretty good one, and the nordic vibe is cool and novel, but there are def better and more polished games in this genre. There's a magic to this one though, there's nothing quite like being in a longship full of your friends and suddenly being assaulted by a sea serpent. I guess what I am tryign to say is, play this if you have a good crew to do it with, don't pick it up for solo play.

10/10 - insane game

This game is a blast. I want to preface by saying I've played and been burned out of survival-crafting games for a long time, I played ARK back when it first released and was one of the suckers who bought DLC in the early access. I was terrified that this game would be like that and was reluctant to buy it despite having friends to play it with and if you find yourself in the same boat I really suggest you don't worry about whether or not it's like the other survival-crafting games you've played before - it's not.

Combat in this is fluid, very fun. It's similar to the combat you'd see in Fromsoft in a way with blocking, rolling, I-frames, different weapon types. Crafting is fun, doesn't take a ton of time, and you're encouraged not to just make boxes while in other games you're forced to for the sake of conserving materials. Hunting, foraging, all that is fun because it focuses on the combat system unless you're purposefully just picking berries and getting lucky enough not to be attacked by greylings - little dwarf monster things.

The graphics are probably the most interesting thing. They're similar to something you'd see in a late PS1 or early PS2 era game but polished heavily. The shading and style of everything is really nice and honestly helps the game a lot. It also means you don't need a god rig to run it despite the game having a lot of moving flora and lighting effects at the highest settings. It's gorgeous without being taxing on your rig or being a massive tumor on your drive.

In short this game is a blast, especially with friends, but if you like RPG games and single player experiences more you'll find this more than a match for that style of gameplay too. It's amazing and if you're scrolling through the reviews deciding whether or not to get it, just snag it and launch it up. The game's under 3 gigs too despite the amount of content in it, so don't worry about not having space for it.

Let me start out this review that I don't mind grinding. I like grind.

The building system is fantastic, the combat is punishing but you learn how to play around the slow, deliberate attacks with time. The sailing is fun, the visuals are fantastic. So why the negative review?

[b]The Plains.[/b]

The enemies are fine. The biome itself is very pretty, the little points of interest you find are well-generated and fun combat encounters to deal with, where you need to carefully approach encounters to avoid getting swarmed and overwhelmed.

What's the issue with the Plains biome, then?

[b]You can't find the boss.[/b] The materials to summon the Plains' boss are annoyingly scarce (which is in stark contrast to all prior bosses), but you genuinely have to luck-out to find the boss location of the Plains' boss.

I genuinely spent ten hours and searched no less than six plains biomes, from small itty-bitty ones to sprawling massive ones. The Plains are cool, but they are not ten-hours-of-searching-cool.

In the end, I folded and found a map generator tool that lets you look up all of the Points of Interest on your map, including boss locations (linked here for the poor souls who end up like me: https://valheim-map.world/

I could forgive the loooooooong dev cycles, the massive grind for materials, the decision to hold-fast to the no-teleportation rules. I was having a lot of fun with the game up until the point I couldn't progress because the developers didn't care to make it easy to find a boss. To clarify, you will be tripping over the 'boss location stones' for all prior bosses while rooting around in each biomes' respective dungeons. I even found a boss location stone for the boss *after* Plains in the second dungeon I visited.


Without any alternative means other than external websites, this is an unforgivable progression blocker. Looking online, every suggestion is "yeah, the search for the Plains' Boss sucks, either keep looking or just use a tool to look it up."

That's dumb. The game has a mechanic to hint to you where the boss locations are, and it should use it.

Valheim, an enchanting survival game, masterfully intertwines Norse mythology with an immersive sandbox world. Each element, from the mysterious mist-laden forests to the daunting sea voyages, is crafted with a blend of realism and myth. The game's building mechanics are not just about shelter but also about creating a legacy amidst the Nordic wilderness. Co-op gameplay adds a layer of camaraderie and epic tales worthy of a Viking saga. Valheim's true magic lies in its ability to make every axe swing, every fortress built, and every monster slain feel like a step in an ancient hero's journey, forging a unique tale for every player.

This game provides a perfect mix of hardcore survival and blissful casual gameplay. Some days I want to go hard, explore and take on tough enemies, other days (Mostly when I am hungover) I just want to build a nice house and decorate it. Small gameplay mechanics makes this game outstanding, like when you make a fire there are smoke mechanics meaning you must make a chimney - and stop it from being rained on or the fire will go out, slowering your rested bonus. Rested means you have better stamina regen ETC, therefore making fights easier... It's not just pseudo mechanics made for the sake of pretending to be useful, it actually helps. At the start enemies are tough and after a few hours they're childsplay. I can't think of a better game to play for a perfect mix of gameplay. And they're still developing it. More great gameplay to come. 10/10.

I only played for 11 hours, so this is mainly about the absolutely early game, first biome, of an early access game.

Graphics:
Simple but very nice, lighting makes all the Difference.

UI:
Its serviceable, nothing more. But even in EA it has a “take all” and “move stacks” button, something D4 doesn’t have to this day..
More/better tooltips would help.

Movement:
Good enough and reminds me of WoW. Sad though that swimming is very limited and diving is not possible. A lot of blocking clutter while chasing mobs will break movement.

Building:
Felt very natural and simple to do. But since distances are far, bags are small, I am constantly forced to build new shelters. Which quite frankly sucked after the 4th time, even if only renovating an empty shelter. A Hearthstone would work wonders.

Crafting:
Here is where it started to bother me. Mats are not pulled from chests, you need to have all mats on character for crafting.. same for Building.

Exploration:
My biggest complaint with the game.. the environment is very beautiful and atmospheric but essentially unrewarding. 
Ruins and buildings usually contain 1 chest, containing worthless crap. You fight against several hard enemies (with the equipment at hand) to get nothing in return. Dungeons are hard, unrewarding and have no dungeon map.

Conclusion:
Constant backtracking for mats and management. Exploration is essentially unrewarding.
I like that I get all recipes for a mat, as soon I get it for the first time. But I feel there should be some rng, either when crafting or trough mods to the regular items, like gems that can drop from any mob, keep things interesting and bit fresh.

Can’t recommend the early access. Will check again after full release.

Great survival game with meaningful progression. There's base building, dungeon crawling, exploration, and resource farming. Highly recommended.

I love pretty much everything about this game.

The combat is less punishing souls-like, there's a good variety of weapons, ranging from daggers to huge polearms which all have their own special attacks. The bosses are adequately challenging and fun to fight, and even the lesser creatures all have their own fighting styles and different moves that you can learn and exploit to get the upper hand.

The world is interesting and fun to explore, with a good variety of biomes (and there’s more on the way) that have a good density of points of interest sprinkled in them. There are many wild animals you can hunt and plants to harvest as you make your way around the map, so you’re always making some amount of progress even as you just wander around.

Building is very fun and has a good amount of challenge to it due to the somewhat realistic structural integrity system that doesn’t just let you build floating platforms.

Progression is well paced and feels very rewarding. The food system that dictates your max health and stamina is a little odd at first, but provides a fun extra challenge and an incentive to find and unlock better food to farm and cook as you make your way through the increasingly tougher biomes. A stable supply of high quality food and mead is just as important as getting the best armor and weapons.

Graphic fidelity is not very high, but the excellent art direction more than makes up for it, although the ability to further increase render distance for grass and trees without the use of mods would be appreciated. The textures are nice, the models are well designed and made with Blender, which is a big plus in my book :)

The sound design and the soundtrack are fantastic. Weapon blows feel impactful, creatures all sound distinct and there is beautiful unique music for every biome.

And on top of that, there’s tons of mods you can easily install that add and improve upon existing features, items, creatures, ect.

I seriously can’t recommend the game enough, it’s easily one of the best i’ve ever played.

The complexity and the details in this game prove that this game was built to be great.  I waited a long time to get this game because I was unsure if I would like it and now me and three other friends of mine are playing this game like it's the only one around.  The progression, lore and gameplay were well thought out.  This game is suspenseful and fun at the same time.  It is Minecraft, but with the lore of and RPG.  This is what a sandbox game should be.  The thought in simple things like carts and tools to dreaming are the details and effort put into this game that make it great.

First things first, the graphics are off the charts. I mean, sailing through misty fjords or going toe-to-toe with legendary creatures in thick forests? It's like the devs sprinkled magic pixels everywhere. The weather changing on the fly and the day-night cycle just adds this crazy level of realism that sucks you right into the Viking universe.

Now, let's talk teamwork. Valheim is all about it. Gathering resources, building epic longhouses, and taking down colossal bosses with your buddies? That's where the real magic happens. You'll be high-fiving your friends and screaming in victory as you carve out your Viking legacy together. It's an absolute blast.

Crafting is a game-changer too. Want a massive axe to crush enemies? You got it. Prefer to pick enemies off from a distance with a killer bow? Valheim's got your back. The game lets you go nuts with your gear, and trust me, it's addictively fun to experiment and see what works for your style.

Oh, and the music! The soundtrack is like the icing on the Viking cake. It's haunting, it's epic, and it'll stick with you even after you've put down your battle axe. It adds this whole other layer of atmosphere that's just downright awesome.

In a nutshell, Valheim isn't just a game; it's a masterpiece.  If you're after a game that transports you to a mythical Viking world, giving you endless hours of fun, Valheim is the real deal. Cheers to the devs for crafting this badass adventure – Skål!
If you've ever played terraria and enjoyed your time there, pick up this game. It is hands down the best game I've ever played besides terraria.

This game had 5 developers when it was released, and its better than every AAA survival game I've played. Valheim is a fantastic game to play with friends, however the true beauty emerges when you play solo. The driving force behind Valheims progression system is prep-work, meaning the amount of effort you as a player are willing to dedicate to prepare for your future adventures and hardships. Every problem you encounter has a short-term and long-term solution, both of which are predicated on the players prep-work. This game at several points will become VERY difficult, and really put your vikings might to his/her limit, however no challenge Valheim throws at you is impossible. I have personally put a significant amount of time into Valheim and can easily say with confidence that it was worth the $20 price point without question. Please support this team of passionate devs, they are currently working to expand the game southward with the "Hell" biome, and I have no doubt they have more ideas for the future.

It has the same survival-craft charms and frustrations of progress via exploration and grinding, but suffers from the loss of the dinosaurs and their associated skills and mechanics. [Played on recommended world settings] This game is repetitive, time consuming, has too much base management, too much inventory management + too little inventory slots. Some game mechanics are hard-impossible to figure out without google (how to breed boars, how to use harpoon etc.). If you don't like building new houses every now and then and transferring materials using ship, don't play this game. 

Exploring is initially fun, but gets stale as hours pass by because there is certain pattern you need to follow every time you find new ore. Farmed 600+ iron, just to figure out silver (next ore) is two times as strong. Maybe googling to some extent could have improved gameplay, but now it is to late :)

---- English Version below ----

Ich würde das Spiel wirklich gerne mögen, und bis zum ersten Boss war es auch wirklich cool.

Aber anders als im ersten Teil, bekommt man für den zweiten Teil überhaupt keine Hinweise wo man hin muss. Auch dieses ist noch in Ordnung.

Dann war ich geschlagene anderthalb Stunden auf See. Mir ist das Grundprinzip des gegen den Wind Segeln bekannt. Funktioniert mit dem Floß aber nicht wirklich, weil das nicht genug Trägheit hat, um über die 90° hinweg zu steuern. Schlimmer noch, wenn man einmal drin hängt und auf dem Wasser hängt, kann man nicht wirklich umdrehen. Bei aller Liebe zum Realismus, aber wenigstens Umdrehen wäre toll gewesen. (klar im Nachhinein ist man immer schlauer, jetzt wären mir schon ein paar Mechaniken klar geworden, um die Reisen wenigstens um die Hälfte zu kürzen)

Als ich es dann nachts endlich in den Dunklen Wald geschafft hatte, wurde ich von einem freundlich Pack begrüßt (9 Zwerge Wichtel, was auch immer). Die haben mich dann ins Jenseits befördert. Das Spiel war natürlich so eingestellt, dass man alles verliert.

Jetzt müsste ich wieder alles sammeln (Klamotten, Waffen, Werkzeuge, Floß ...). Darauf hatte ich am Ende einfach keine Lust mehr.

Ich hoffe andere erwischt es hierbei nicht genauso, oder haben mehr Durchhaltevermögen. Aber für über eine Stunde Floßfahrt fehlt mir (ohne die Möglichkeit meine Sachen mitzunehmen - Naja, von Hand immer hin- und herschippern) mittlerweile die Zeit und Geduld.

--------- English Version -----------

I really wanted to like the game, and it was really cool until the first boss.

But unlike in the first part, you don't get any hints at all for the second part where you have to go. This one is also still okay.

Then I was at sea for an hour and a half. I'm familiar with the basic principle of sailing against the wind. But it doesn't really work with the raft because it doesn't have enough inertia to steer through 90°. Worse still, once you're in it and hanging on the water, you can't really turn around. For all my love of realism, at least turning around would have been great. (Of course, you're always smarter with hindsight, but now I would have realized a few mechanics to shorten the trips by at least half)

When I finally made it into the Dark Forest at night, I was greeted by a friendly pack (9 dwarven gnomes, whatever). They then sent me to the afterlife. Of course, the game was set up so that you lose everything.

Now I had to collect everything again (clothes, weapons, tools, raft ...). In the end, I just didn't feel like it anymore.

I hope others don't have the same problem or have more stamina. But I don't have the time or patience for a raft trip of over an hour (without the option of taking my things with me - well, I always have to sail back and forth by hand).

Can't even imagine how this could be fixed, other than removing the biome all-together and admitting that they did a bad level design.

[h1] TL;DR: [/h1]
⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

[h2] A Nordic Survival Masterpiece [/h2]

[hr][/hr]

[h1] Detailed Review: [/h1]

[h2] 1. Narrative and Visuals (5/5): [/h2]
Valheim masterfully tackles the survival genre, offering sandbox gameplay balanced with a meaningful progression system. The unique graphical style, with low polygon counts and simple textures, creates a gorgeous world with beautiful lighting, atmospherics, and color composition.

[h2] 2. Gameplay and Unique Features (5/5): [/h2]
The game excels in gameplay mechanics, providing a rewarding building system where shelters require careful consideration of support and ventilation. The crafting, combat, and exploration elements are well-balanced, and the introduction of paired portals for fast travel adds an intriguing logistical layer to the game.

[h2] 3. Optimization Woes (5/5): [/h2]
Valheim's open-world survival and building experience stands out, minimizing routine tasks and offering a unique blend of calm ambiance and occasional stress. The game's ability to blend exploration, combat, and construction in a satisfying loop contributes to its engaging and enjoyable nature.

[h2] 4. Soundtrack and Audio Design (5/5): [/h2]
The soundtrack, described as beautiful and chill, complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. The ambient sounds, including the crackle of a fireplace, add depth to the immersive experience. The sound design enhances the overall enjoyment of the game.

[h2] 5. Bugs and Technical Issues (5/5): [/h2]
As an early access title, Valheim remarkably feels complete, with very few bugs reported. The developers' commitment to regular updates and communication about future plans adds to the overall positive experience.

[h2] 6. Replay Value and DLCs (5/5): [/h2]
Valheim's discovery feature, where picking up new items unveils associated crafting recipes, adds a compelling layer to exploration. The constantly evolving world and the promise of future updates contribute to the game's lasting appeal and replay value.

[h2] 7. Community and Modding (5/5): [/h2]
Valheim's community engagement, clear development roadmap, and commitment to addressing player feedback create a positive environment. The game's cooperative nature and flexibility in solo or multiplayer modes cater to a wide audience.

[h2] 8. Value for Money (5/5): [/h2]
With a small file size of 1GB, Valheim offers a complete and highly enjoyable experience. The game's affordability, coupled with the continuous development and addition of new content, makes it a fantastic investment.

[h1] Personal Thoughts: [/h1]

Valheim is a grindy Nordic mythology-influenced Viking survival, crafting, and exploration game that strikes a perfect balance between atmosphere and gameplay. Its unique blend of calming ambiance, challenging combat, and satisfying building mechanics creates a gaming experience that stands out in the crowded survival genre.

The discovery feature, beautiful soundtrack, and constant updates from dedicated developers keep the game fresh and exciting. The carefully designed difficulty, rewarding resource return, and easy-to-use building system contribute to the game's enduring appeal. Whether sailing through storms or exploring different biomes, Valheim provides an immersive and enjoyable escape that captures the essence of the genre's best elements.

In conclusion, Valheim is more than a game; it's a captivating journey through a Viking purgatory playhouse. From its stunning visuals to its engaging gameplay loop, this game is a testament to what an early access title can achieve. Highly recommended for both solo players and those seeking cooperative adventures with friends. Step into Valheim and experience the calm amidst the chaos of survival.
