I've loved this game for quite a long time. It was fun, it was challenging and ruthless. I can't even count how many times I died on a distant island in the middle of plains or mountains or a swamp with my teleport destroyed. I had to ask my friend for help a lot of times to recover my stuff. I almost gave up several times. And that's what was great about this game. 

It's the current state what's bothering me. Suddenly there's a save option and also a difficulty settings to make the game easier or even more challenging. I don't like that at all. I liked the fact that the experience was the same for everybody. Take it or leave it. 

Furthermore I found out that the save option is broken. I don't recommend using it. If you're lucky and find the right save there's a danger of losing your stuff. It just disappears. Teleports, upgrades, boats, even your corpse... And that is ultimately why I decided not to recommend the game. To progress in Valheim you have to invest a lot of time into it. To find stuff, mine it or transport it to your home location. Which is fine. But when some kind of bug makes you lose hours of your progress, that is really huge issue for me. My time is precious, I can't afford to do things twice !

To the devs - I know you will never read this but in the hopes that you do i want you to know we love what you have created here and there are a lot of us that understand a lot of the criticisms aren't valid or constructive. Just be careful not to shut out the people with valid critiques because most of them just care about you and your product, i can guarantee 99% of us want to see this you and this game succeed and most of the animosity is a "fearfulness"(PTSD) that comes form the early access genre and knowing what this game is capable of and being afraid for its future. but no matter what happens thanks for the great game and memories it is well worth the 20$ no matter where we go from here.

EDIT(1/2/2024): The updates have been coming in at very slow pace but that's to be expected Irongate is still the same small team even after the massive success of the game but it is a creative choice because they want to preserve their original vision and theme of the game and they feel adding on new members could cause deviation. I think that is a valid reason and even though im not enthused with the pace of release of new content i respect their decision and hope it works in their favor.

My First Playsession of this game lasted six hours. In that time, I:
1. Got dropped into the world and told to please one set of gods by killing another set. Great.
2. Punched a dwarf to death. They will continue showing up for the remainder of my playtime, and continue to get punched.
3. Built some tools and got distracted for two hours clearcutting the edge of a forest and building a little house.
4. Went exploring, found a mountain.
5. Immediately froze to death trying to leave the mountain.
6. Running back to the mountain border to get my stuff, ambushed a pig. was promptly murdered by said pig.
7, Okay, avoiding the local wildlife, now I've got my stuff back. But now I discover there's a weight-based encumbrance system, and I'm stuck in the middle of nowhere.
8. after dropping a few trees worth of wood and hoofing it through the forest, punching dwarves along the way, I get home at last. I build a barn to store my stuff in.
9. Mother nature decides to send a wildlife killteam after me, I'm cornered in the barn. After a skirmish, my nemesis, the pigs, are locked inside. I found a rock that told me I can make them pets by throwing food at them, so I throw some berries in and leave them chewing on the walls.
10. Okay, I've got some stuff lying around, not counting the stuff in the barn with the still-murderous pigs. Time to gear up. I discover the joy of Bows, Arrows, Spears, and Shields. That means I'm ready to take on the first god, yes?
11. Apparently not. God won't show up unless I give him hunted stuff. Okay, hunting expedition. 
12. Alright, I've killed deer, pigs, and angry geckos. I've discovered the joy of cooking and tripled my health with the flesh of my fallen foes. I even found a pair of antlers, and this must be what God wants as payment for his cameo. it's time.
13. God is a giant deer, and he's angry. I discover the game has dodge-rolling, and proceed to repeatedly throw my spear at him. Despite him throwing lightning back, I prevail, more easily than I did against the pigs. Such is the power of MEAT.
14. I return home in glory. The pigs in the barn are domesticated, I got the ability to channel this god to run for a long time, and with the addition of the god's crafting materials, I go to see what I can now make.
15. I discover I can craft pants. I've done all of this, without pants.

All that was basically an extended tutorial. 10/10 would kill god without pants on again.

Why is this game still in Early Access?

TL;DR: REALLY rough around the edges, and needs a TLC pass.  Suffers from similar problems to its peers, which might not be "a bug, but a feature".

Disclaimer: I have not finished the game completely; I'm 4/6 bosses through but have a pretty good handle on what to expect from here on.

6/10

Pros:
*The building system is fantastic for what it is.  The pieces look good and feel good snapping together.  Other bigger games really NEED to adopt this snap-system and simplistic design. 
*The variety in mobs and biomes.
*The variety in equipment/builds/play styles available.

Cons:
*The steep jump in difficulty from biome to biome is jarring.  You can get the best equipment for say, Biome #2 and will easily be killed by Biome #3 regular mobs.  This leads to a weird loop of:
    1) Enter Biome, find new resources
    2) Try to get best available gear with new resources, while running/screaming/avoiding mobs
    3) Have best gear, fight mobs normally and get ready for biome boss
    4) Clear biome boss, move to next biome and prepare to run/scream/avoid again.
*The bosses are lackluster BECAUSE they are easily cheesed.
*Dungeon mobs are also easily cheesed by doors/narrow passages.
*Bosses have WAY too much health.  
*Dodge needs to be it's own keybind and not "crouch plus jump"

Moving Forward:

*I would rework the bosses to all have a "dungeon arena" rather than just an altar/spawn.  With the best gear possible for a boss, they should be a very reasonable ~5-10ish minute affair. 

*Similarly, gear balancing.  If you have the best available gear/food from the last biome, you should be able to navigate the next biome pretty comfortably, and maybe the 2nd harder with caution.

I assume as the game matures, it will be improved, so the score is not as harsh as it would be a finished product.  Like some other long-term-fixer-upper games, I have hope.

This is an interesting game full of awesome ideas. Unfortunately it is unstable. I have lost ALL OF MY STUFF for the last time. I'm uninstalling this buggy game and playing something else. Don't spend money on this until they fix the crashing problem where everything you had goes back to what you had on your character at the last save point, which for me, was when i was naked right after I died, so all of my weapons, armor, and whatever valuables I had on my person do not exist now. 209 hours of gameplay thrown in the trash.

I really enjoy this game. The mix of souls-like parrying and rolling, blended with endless woodcutting, suits me perfectly. It’s the kind of game that fully absorbs me for hours, and something I return to every time I manage to convince a friend to buy it.

During my first playthrough, I remember spending an absurd amount of time obtaining fully upgraded bronze armor. I felt invincible, only to be swiftly humbled by the “YOU DIED” screen. Sailing into the plains with overconfidence, thinking “the ugly bastards ain’t got nothing on me,” ended with a frantic effort to retrieve my gear amidst a barrage of little green goblins and mosquitoes.

While I’ve heard some critique the graphics, for me, they are unique and gorgeous. However, the real standout feature of Valheim is its atmosphere. The lighting, fog, darkness, stormy oceans, or bright midday sun creates an immersive atmosphere. Each biome presents its own unique charm, making exploration continually exciting, even after extensive time spent in them.

Building is detailed and farming, rewarding. Progression can feel slow at times, and difficulty spikes damning, but when you finally parry that abomination and defeat it, the satisfaction is immense.

Valheim epitomises the survival genre’s best elements. From sailing and exploring new biomes to discovering materials, building bases, cooking, defeating bosses, and more - every aspect feels rewarding.

It’s the type of game where one second you check to see that the bees are happy, and the next, you’re dodging the club above your head. I could not love this game any more.

Review: 
On the surface, this is Dark Souls meets Minecraft, but Vikings. And I'm all on board for that. HOWEVER, Dark Souls is one of the most balanced games I've ever played. And it has to be. Every enemy is beatable at level 1. In Valheim however, the enemies are not balanced. At all. They randomly spawn, so maybe you'll get a 2 enemy challenge, maybe you'll get 4 enemies and you'll be lucky to make it out. Or... 8 enemies and you cannot survive. Dark Souls isn't random. So your experience can vary drastically. I was not often lucky. 

I played a lot because I DO like challenge. The Dark Souls Series is one of my favorite series. But when I die in Darksouls I say "Why did I fail to ______" and in Valheim I say "Why did the game ________". Where Dark Souls hid the story and relied on the internet to collectively tell its story, Valheim relies on the internet to tell its mechanics. Sometimes you'll have to go sailing to find certain biomes. And I didn't know that. So I explored my island thinking that was the whole  game. When I did go sailing, I found a Biome that was extremely punishing. Turns out, it wasn't "next". And the enemies weren't defeatable, even with expert timing and leveled up weapons and shields. 

But EVEN THAT wouldn't matter, if you kept progress life to life. Try, die, try again. Except. Not Valheim, If Roguelike was what they were going for, they also failed at that. Because dying to the 8 enemy spawn once will cost you 5% of your skill. If you leveled up your spears to 50. You're a pretty good spear fighter. But when you wind up in the plains when you should be in the swamp (as I did), you get a roaming band of 5 enemies that your shield doesn't block. Also they throw stuff. And your first death drops you to 47.5 in spears. Die again and you're at 45. My third death took me to 42. And my fourth took me to 40. I lost so many levels on things because the game isn't balanced. 

PROS:
1) Early stages are very fun. 
2) The Building mechanics are great. I loved making structures.
3) Multiplayer is awesome for this type of game. Glad it's possible.
4) Setting and scale are huge and engaging. 

CONS:
1) Uses roguelike elements poorly. Your deaths don't let you keep your progress, and will penalize you for failure much more heavily than expected.
2) Uses procedural generation elements poorly. Unfair situations arise regularly. Map can be unfair.
3) Multiplayer can be straight up required if your RNG is bad enough. Ultimately I stopped because I met a challenge I couldn't take on alone, and didn't have anyone playing with me at the time.
4) The Crafting system is garbage. Which is odd considering the building system is great. Making a tool is awful. Making a house is fantastic. 
5) Travel by water is not a question of frustration, but HOW frustrating. 

It's so weird how I can want everything a game offers, but they do it so poorly that I dislike the game. My "Base" looked amazing with an area for pigs, and farmland and a surprisingly large Bee  hive area. A two story warehouse with throne room on the second floor. But... accidentally having a boss right next to an area that's too hard to survive means that boss can't be encountered alone. I want someone to make a good version of this game. Because this version isn't it.

I was able to host a server with friends with relative ease. It's like minecraft with a more realized direction. The many systems and mechanics of the game will keep you busy and interested in the world. The developers have kept their word and have supported the game immensely. Strongly recommend.

The combat is simple, unforgiving and really satisfying. The monsters/bosses are varied and really fun to fight. BE PREPARED TO DIE. Even if you ARE fully prepared, YOU WILL DIE!

[b]Odin's Necktales[/b]

[b]short review[/b]
After dozens of over politically correct AAA games, it is so refreshing to see a game, which couldn't care less and is advertised by Scandinavian Death Metal.
It is in an early state, but still runs surprisingly bug-free and plays on Linux - upvote!

[b]long review[/b] Update 2024
It is a bit unfair comparing the game to Rust or 7d2d, since those two had years of development and are still unfinished products. This review might be subject to change, but in the current state, the following is worth a mention:
[list]
[*]First of all, it is not that forgiving as people claim: Dying, even though being already dead, has dire consequences. You loose a lot of skill points, which needs a good bit of grinding, especially on skills like blocking or swimming, you don't do that often. [i]Update: This has been mitigated by the introduction of the "world modifiers" in the settings. But you cannot turn it off completely.[/i]
[*]You don't die of hunger, like in 7d2d, but you are only on roughly 30 percent of your stats w/o eating. So in a sense the same, if not even more micro-management.
[*]You can progress to a certain extend until you have to fight a boss in order to unlock new skills. You don't have invisible walls, but very challenging opponents if you travel to the higher level biomes too early.
[*]The boss fights can be done in an honest fight or a more cheesy way. I like it being the players choice.
[*]The upgrade system of the work stations takes a lot of space and there is weather degradation on the outside.
[*]That being said, repairs of buildings and gear don't consume resources.
[*]Generally the building system is intuitive and splitting stacks of goods with a slider is a good idea.
[*]As with the work stations, storing items consumes way too much space, because the chests have limited slots for items and stacking them, you need floor plates to build a sort of rack.
[*]Fast travelling as in portals is a good idea in this particular game.
[*] Mistlands: Great biome, the Feather Cape is priceless, given how often I died from fall damage falling off my roof. Introducing this magic build that late in the game is kinda awkward though.
[/list]

[b]Current verdict[/b]
Currently not on par with 7d2d or Rust, but has its own charm. Bought it, because many friends have it and is surely fun in co-op, but you can go PvP, if you feel like. The boss fight progression makes it interesting on the first playthrough, but could potentially hamper replayability. Interesting to see, how this evolves.

TLDR:
After coming back this game year after year. Playing through its content updates I still recommend Valheim as one of the ultimate and challenging survival/building games on the market. Best Viking game there is and we as players were blessed with its release those years ago. 


You set up the pace and way you play this game, there is never a feeling of rush apart from when swarmed by enemies. It's is a combination of challenging yet very chilled out and laid back game play. In the beginning there is a lot of preparations for bosses and biomes. The progress is stuck behind recipes you unlock on your way and I couldn't think of better guided and beginner friendly way for this type of game. You kinda feel lost and mesmerised at the beginning but you don't feel unwelcome in this world but rather observed and studied. Meadows,  Dark Forest and even Swamps are one of the best biomes I had pleasure exploring.

The building itself is so satisfying and I come to this game whenever I'm really stress with personal life to unwind, listen to some podcast or music and build away in creative mode.

The content slow at first but very meaningful and every one of big content drops expand the universe and add to its already strong foundation. 

The only thing that will require looking into in the future is Combat mechanics while they are not too frustrating and give the core gameplay loop a steady flow it requires a lot of polishing eventually. It gets the job done for now and it's not a big of an issue apart from maybe a little bit of mountains and mistlands. They pose the land elevation challenge which are not suited too well for current combat system. Can't really hit some one underneath or over my head with a sword/spear etc. Combat feels too directional in those instances and while you do have bows they are single target which are useless in close quarter/many mobs encounters. 


Hope for many many more years and content in the future. And I shall update this review when times come. Good luck Vikings and your Valheim worlds be full of happy bees.

This game Is amazing

I am now 12 hours in as of this writing, and am nearing the end of the bronze age. So far, love the game.

The building system is great with many angular pieces to work with. (Although limited material types so far). It takes physics and material strengths into account, so you'll actually NEED to use support beams and such to build structures. The task of building a long, tall bridge took over an hour even with all of the materials on hand.

The combat is fun, intuitive and can demand skill at times. There are different weapon types for different situations, keeping you on your toes when you haven't come to an area fully equipped for it's enemies.

There is a skill system that rewards you for every task you do, similar to runescape's.

Menial tasks such as chopping down trees, mining & hunting are made fun with satisfying mechanics. You can fell a tree just to have it knock down 3 more and save you a few minutes! 

There is a food system, but you cannot starve. You simply become a meek little baby-armed man without consuming good, quality foods.

The art direction is very retro, reminds me of old WoW.

Overall 9/10 so far for me, and I haven't even gotten past the general area of spawn!

I made a review a while back and I still hold true to getting this game. It is very fun, especially with friends. The only issues I see with the game is the development time. Anyways the game right now is still very fun and playable, but if you've already committed of waiting this long I'd say wait till the next update.

Great blend of challenging gameplay, engaging building system, and open world exploration. It's like the midway point between a souls game and minecraft.

Valheim is a game other games should learn from, especially in the survival/crafting/building genres. 

The versatile building that allows reasonable amounts of clipping gives players the freedom to get inspired and build truly unique bases. Though many agree it could use just MORE build pieces, what you can do with what he have is stunning.

The combat is weighty, skill-based, and deep. With versatile options for every scenario, stealth mechanics that allow for minimal-engagement playstyles, strengths and weaknesses of different weapons and enemies, meaningful and engaging gear tiers... 

The overall experience is well intertwined within itself. You need to beat bosses to progress the game, to beat the boss you need better equipment, for better equipment you need to conquer the biome and collect resources, to process the resources you need new crafting stations which need to be "indoors" which encourages base-building which is reinforced by the enemy-raid system. No corner left untouched as even the oceans are fun to sail but contain their own threats and treasures. And more content coming semi-regularly (the new biomes are getting more content heavy as they introduce new weapon classes or combat types and then need to support progressing new stuff as well as everything you already have with each new biome) means there is always something new to explore and start your adventure all over again.

Oh, Valheim, a game that falls into the "pretty decent" category for me. Would I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone? Probably not. While the game certainly has its charms, it may not appeal to everyone. However, if you have at least one friend willing to join you on this Viking adventure, it's definitely worth giving it a shot.

The gameplay loop follows a straightforward pattern: gather resources, utilize them to craft food, construct a base (though building can be a bit challenging), fashion weapons and equipment, and then upgrade everything to its maximum potential before taking on the bosses. While this progression may sound simple, executing it is easier said than done, especially considering the ruthlessness of the enemies you'll encounter. The combat, while acceptable, could use more diversity in my opinion.

My primary qualm with the game revolves around the grind. For the majority of my playthrough, I followed the intended path, but the relentless grind eventually wore me down. In the interest  of finishing the game in a fast manner I resorted to  cheating in equipment for the final boss. Despite this shortcut, the overall experience remained a blast.

Valheim truly shines when experienced with a friend or a group. The camaraderie and shared challenges elevate the gameplay to new heights, making the grind more bearable and the victories more rewarding (It can also make for some pretty funny moments). So, if you have a solid friend group ready for the journey, I would wholeheartedly recommend diving into the world of Valheim.

When I first started to play Valheim, I played it with a group of friends.
We all liked and enjoyed the game and had a lot of fun.
However, as time passed we all abandoned it for not a specific reason, and the desire to continue just faded away.
Months later, I checked into it again, and I have to say I think I'm about to complete it this time, but in this playthrough I'm solo.
[h3]!Spoilers ahead![/h3]
I recently defeated Moder, the fourth boss of the game in the mountain biome and shortly after, I arrived at the plains.
While I did not complete Valheim yet, I think I gathered the most aspects of it, and I think I'm safe to write this.
I want to mention that this won't be a structured text, I just throw in my opinion. 
As you might have noticed, I do recommend Valheim.
The game is a lot of fun, and it maybe is one of my favourite games.
The building and crafting have a lot of variety, the exploring is fun, the sounddesign is amazing, the art style is kind of unique etc...
I lost a couple of hours building and exploring, so yeah, a definite recommendation from me.

However, I kinda want to point out things that annoy me while I play.
And oh boy, these are some pretty annoying things, let me tell ya.

The first thing and probably the worst aspect in this whole game is the stamina and everything it is related to.
By god (and I don't even believe in one) this stamina system is a creation of the most ugly, nasty and deepest pit of hell you could ever imagine.
Every time I run out of stamina while a group of high levelled enemies like draugr, or fucking wolves are basically jumping me, this stupid stamina bar won't recover. 
It may even get worse when you're in the swamp, or you have to fight while it's dark and your character is cold (or even both).
It gets even worse.
If you ever come in a situation where you are out of stamina, wet AND cold all together (most likely in the swamp) while also being chased by enemies that are twice as fast as you, (most likely in the mountains) it is certain to say that you will most likely not recover a tiny bit of your stamina because if you try to block something, the bit of that stamina will be wiped out immediately.
To be fair, there are a couple of ways to prevent this from happening, and you can also speed up your stamina recovery.
But even when you are well rested, not freezing and not wet, the stamina still feels too slow in my opinion.
So Iron Gate, please change that.

The following arguments are rather minor complaints that I like to be fixed or changed:

- Make the character attack where the player is pointing at: it's kind of like in the FromSoftware games (like 
   Dark Souls)
   In FromSoft games, the character hits there depending on whether the player is looking down or up.
   This is helpful if an enemy is higher up or below the player.
   I wish that they would implement this feature in Valheim because sometimes enemies won't get damaged just 
   because they are a little too high or down.
   Maybe implement some sort of target lock in too.

-  The spear animation and moveset: 
    I personally like to use a spear in videogames, however not in Valheim.
    Normally, a spear provides a longer distance from the opponent and has a longer reach than a sword for 
    example.
    In Valheim the spear does not have these characteristics and feels actually too short mainly because the 
    character holds it kind of weird.
    I would like a rework of the whole animation and moveset.

-  More normal armour:
    It feels like there are too few armour sets to craft.
    I think that the armour that are already in the games look pretty solid and some give nice buffs.
    But I feel like there are too few normal armour sets, there could be some more.

-  Flesh Ripper animation rework:

I wrote this response to someone and thought it would serve as my Valheim review. My response in Discord when asked if I'd really played a 16 hour Valheim session. "ah yeah I um left it paused and fell asleep, that's what happened. Yeah, Valheim is the first game I've played for a few years that I'd give a 10/10. I've always had that fantasy of leaving civilisation behind and living off the land, building a cabin, hunting, fishing, farming like people did in the middle ages. But the reality of that is that hunting is very difficult, crops fail, sickness, disease, starvation, predation.. It's brutal out there without civilisation. But this game scratches that itch perfectly and I dont have to drink creek water and die from malnutrition. love it!"

This game exceeded my expectations. At first I was hesitant to even try this game but now, I'm actually enjoying every second of playing it. If you are like me who love this kind of game, JUST TRY IT. You wont forget it i promise.

Do not invest your time into this game. Combat mechanics are annoying and don't get better over your progression and at times will be up to random chance. Difficulty progression is inconsistent going from very boring easy difficulty to times where you're just trying to stall for several seconds to get one hit in then stall again. The random world generation and spacing of identical islands also doesn't make getting further in the game better for the player. I will give the looks, colors, and creatures you find to be cool but completely is not worth the bs of the entirety of the game. Also the building is good if you're into that but can also be annoying in survival. Overall, not a fun game and other survival games out there a more fun with difficulty that makes sense and isn't there to waste the player's time.

The only thing I dislike about the game is the 3 vision blocking mechanics: night, fog, and mist. I might have to download a mod to remove these 3 things, because without them the game is nearly perfect. Going to sleep to skip the night time so I can see is like a mandatory 30 second ad break in the middle of a really good show. 9/10, with night/fog/mist sliders in settings would be 10/10.

Honestly I do no recommend this game. It's so close to being fun, but the sheer amount of pointless time wasting grinding is really the fun killer.

Be ready for the fact that this game needs you to devote some time to it in order to gather equipment, experience, and supplies to advance from boss fight to boss fight as well as learn how to build portals to manage getting across the large map more quickly. However the developers have put so much effort into the environment and the crafting aspects that the time you devote passes quickly with much to see and do. After 90h I've only killed the first boss, albeit have probably over prepared my armour and weapons for the second boss. I've got a boar farm running with breeding animals, vegetable garden, cooking and fermentation tanks, and a bunch of safe 'home bases' behind solid wooden fences to hide away inside. 

The lack of high resolution character models allows for processing power to be devoted to the forests, weather systems, animals roaming around, light shining through fog, etc - creating what I find an immersive gameplay experience. 

The combination of goals to aim for re the bosses but your choice about how fast you get there means its easy to pick up and play when you have a spare 30 minutes or equally if you are devoting a couple of hours to it. The game works great on the Steam Deck (first gen) also, with at least 2-3h battery life with the graphic settings turned up as far as possible on that platform.

I've not tried the teamplay aspect to it yet, but from what I've seen it looks to work well. 

If you enjoy base-building/crafting/survival games then this will be a winner for  you -- just try to stay away from the trolls :)

I can no longer recommend you play this game. It does not respect your time, in exploration, gathering resources or building and defending your base. Mining is the worst part of gathering resources, while I understand that metals are game changing resources, it takes hours to mine enough to really accomplish anything. Mind you, there isn't just one type of metal to acquire either, there are two main ones that each have their own difficulties in obtaining, both which take hours to explore and find and then hours to collect. The map seeds are way too big! These worlds are absolutely massive and it could take you probably 3+ hours to sails from one side to the other. Honestly playing without using the Valheim map generator website, that lets you see your entire map, or using the dev command to reveal the map, is no longer viable. If you don't wish to waste time, then you need to know where you are going. Base building is probably the best any sandbox game has ever done tbh. However the raid mechanics comepletey ruin this especially the new raid. I Mistlands they added a new raid for those who completed the plains boss, your base will now be attacked by giant bugs from the sky who will literally BOMBARD your base and blow everything up. Just like that the base you spent possibly hundreds of hours working on, is just gone. Sometimes you get the troll raids that will do exactly the same thing, they will pummel your walls and smash everything, and the only way to stop them is to cheese the AI. This means the game is broken imo. Don't buy this, I know it looks super cool and fun but it will just waste your time.

EDIT: I have since returned to this game but in a modded state. I found many of the mods change the gameplay enough to make it enjoyable. Along with the new world modifiers included in a recent update, gathering resources no longer has to take hours irl just to progress even a little. Mistlands is still absolutely horrendous but the rest of the game can be enjoyable with the right settings and right mods imo.

I bought this a long time ago, but i waited until more of the game was complete before I tried it out. Started playing co-op on a world last weekend and now i cant stop playing.

Every survival game should take a page out of this game. 

In my opinion, a good game is a game that has good progression. Obvious goals to achieve and shows the player that there are far things in the future that they have to do, but also gives you a direction to work towards and a sense of increasing power the more you play. And thats what this game does with hardly any interaction with the player besides a tutorial bird that lets you know about things in the game when you do something new.

It looks beautiful, there is definitely challenges to overcome with boss fights and gathering of materials that steadily increases with difficulty, the crafting and upgrading is great, the land bioms are great with pleanty of stuff to find and explore...

The only con's i would give the game is the amount of time it takes to get resources with the default settings. The default settings are not good for solo players, or even 2 people. Put 2x resourses on and portal items or else you game is going to be very tedious considering you are going to be doing ALL the work over huge distances.

This is how every survival game should be made in my opinion. Collect resources to get stronger, to overcome the new area to beat the boss and then keep doing that as the difficulty keeps going up.

Valheim is an excellent Viking-themed survival game that is best enjoyed with friends. The game is challenging but rewarding, and the constant updates and new content keep it fresh.

PROS
• Fun and challenging survival gameplay
• Great cooperative experience
• Large and diverse world to explore
• Lots of different biomes and creatures to encounter
• Regular updates and new content
• Building a viking base is very fun

CONS
• Can be difficult to learn for new players
• Some bugs and glitches
• Can be grindy at times

OVERALL
Valheim is a great game for anyone looking for a challenging and rewarding survival game. The game is best enjoyed with friends, as working together to survive and build a base is a lot of fun. The game is constantly being updated with new content, so there's always something new to do.

MY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE
I've been playing Valheim since it was released in early access in 2021, and I've had a great time with it. The game is challenging but rewarding, and I love the sense of progression as I explore the world, build a base, and defeat new enemies. I've also had a lot of fun playing the game with friends. Working together to survive and build a base is a lot of fun, and it's a great way to bond with friends.

RECOMMENDATION
If you're looking for a challenging and rewarding survival game, I highly recommend Valheim. It's a great game to play solo, but it's even better with friends.

If only the made it in unreal engine 5.  A lot of potential but very very poorly executed. I really really wanted to enjoy this game but after 180 hours on my first world I am done and I didn't even get to mist lands yet. The only thing this massive empty game has going for it is the mods. I needed about 30 quality of life mods and a new game model, my god that's the dumbest looking player character I've seen since the 90's and the fact that I was using a high poly vrm model with full hair and body physics there is no excuse to have such a poorly made character. you could have downloaded a free one for fuck sake ANYTHING would have been better, so meanwhile I spent about since hour 2 of game play not experiencing the gear visual progression because I could not stand to look at the player model with 3 chromosomes for a second longer. 

The game Progression is so linear for solo players you literally have to do exactly the same thing every time with no variation or you cant progress, collect this for way too long, walk here that's too long, wait for this to finish for way too long,  kill boss by cheesing the bow and arrow because that's the only way its possible to kill the boss's or you die in one hit or at least take enough damage in one hit to make you run away, go to next area do so same thing with different names. 

when I first started a game I opened the map and the size made me so excited to find out whats out there... Whats out there is exactly the same fucking thing that is here already Karen! 8 zones sounds like a lot but when 2 of them are not even finished so completely empty and serve no purpose one is the ocean that has a whole of 1 fucking enemy.... really 1. OK.  that leaves 5 different types of areas that look exactly the same no matter where in the world you are, to fill the entire planet... Its got stuff there so I guess but the stuff 3 hours away is exactly the same as the stuff that's on the ground right next to you right now. so there is no point at all, might as well just be a single island. 34,000 copper nodes generated. you will mine all of 2 maybe. 

Can we just talk about the combat, HOLY GAWD DAM WTF REEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE....... To who ever though that amount of knock back from either side during combat was a good idea, please fill your pockets with rocks and walk into the ocean, you single handedly ruined this game for me to the point I wont even play it as intended anymore. I like to play games with no guide and to work things out myself but by the time I finished mountains with max gear for that area I thought obviously plains was the next port of call, I went, got absolutely fucking steam rolled by a Lox or what ever the fuck its called. you cant run you just run into more things that have no stamina bar meanwhile you're on borrowed time because you got stamina to worry about, Jump up on a high rock to take refuge, 40 tone animal can walk up vertical walls without missing a step and then proceed to hit you for 70% health and knock you back 300 meters into a mosquito that hits your for 10000 billions points and yeets you too the next island, meanwhile if you want to attack them back go fuck yourself that's not going to happen you are too far away from the knock back of the last hit. Imagine getting stun locked by an enemy AI well that's every fucking creature in the end part of the game. For a game that focuses on melee combat its pathetically garbage for players that use melee weapons. 

Max armour for area, max weapons for area, max food for area, max potions for area, you're still dying in 2 hits on normal even if you block who cares your getting stunned for 2 seconds so 8 other enemies can show up and shove there weapons in your ass. Not being able to override an attack with a block is actually retarded for a game that rely soley on you timing your block to stay alive.

OMG THE STAMINA, what the actual, really come on dude, who thought that making someone not be able to move or attack right in the middle of combat was a good idea is a dipshit. "Oh you just have to manage your stamina better", you mean like eating the equivalent of 3 whole deer then taking 4 steps and swinging my arms 3 times means I'm so tired I might not even move when this enemy smashes my head in with a rock, I would rather stand here and DIE then exert one more ounce of effort. Have you ever, you know, see that thing, REALITY! I don't care how frigging "tired" you are if you are in the middle of combat you WILL find the energy to do SOMETHING about ANYTHING then just be more tired afterwards, your not going to stand there and just die, though at this point I wish who ever made these decisions just would.

Overall I feel this game is designed to waste as much of your time as possible, from the ridiculously and unnecessarily small inventory and chests systems, to the have to wait 30 seconds for every cook or craft to the obnoxious items weights and stack sizes to the obscenely long distances between places, All the way down to the fact that if you die, you're screwed.. good luck getting your stuff back the enemies that chased you across the map for 15 minutes are NEVER leaving your grave.

TL;DR: GAY ASS GAME SUCKS FAT DICKS.

Okay, so if you're a patient person, that loves puttering about exploring, crafting and building - this is kind of like a Viking minecraft. There is a dash of mythology thrown in but amazingly great physics worked into the game - aiming bows depending on what type of ground you are, building more sturdy constructions, needing to figure out how to redirect smoke in your house so you don't suffocate, but stay warm and keep the rain out of the campfire.  Now, if you're like me and don't have endless amount of time or penchant for masochism (I realized this after dying 3 times trying to recover items from my corpse in a dungeon) you can change your game settings  to casual / easy mode to make it a little less intense and unforgiving. Its an awesome game and while the graphics don't knock your socks off, the fun timez will.  5/5 coffee rating!

With over 900+ hours logged in Valheim, I can vouch for the sheer gaming nirvana it offers. Dive into the fray by crafting your own epic Viking stronghold, ride the tumultuous waves of the vast seas, face off against mythical foes, and unravel the secrets woven into a dynamically generated world. Valheim isn't your typical game; it's a rollercoaster of survival, exploration, and the unmatched joy of sculpting your Viking legacy. What sets it apart? The freedom to build, shape, and customize – turn your dreams into pixelated reality in a world where every structure tells your unique story.

[h1]Frightening Lack of QoL [/h1]
I do enjoy the game but it's lacking basic QoL features. Some examples: limited inventory slots, armor is a part of your inventory space(no separate armor slots), [strike]for some reason quick bar slots are a part of inventory[/strike] (subjective but I prefer it to be a separate entities), can't move chests with loot (destroy it, grab loot, build chest, insert loot in it), limited stack options (resulting in overabundance of loot), no quick sorting (insert loot into every chest manually or by holding E), potions doesn't work during the effect (if poisoned drinking anti poison potion doesn't help you cure it). 

Content is important but after that I recommend developers to focus on QoL. Great game examples in that sense are Terraria and V Rising. 

Expect for future updates and to change my review into positive one. Until then it remains as it is.

I've played The Forest, Sons Of The Forest, ARK, Conan Exiles, Don't Starve Together, Green Hell, Subnautica, Terraria, Minecraft, 7 Days to Die (briefly), Satisfactory, Valheim, and probably some others which I couldn't find in my Steam library, but Valheim is my favourite survival game by far.

Here are a few things I want to highlight:

The building system is one of my favourite aspects of most survival games, and Valheim does it best. This game's building system is very versatile and its strong point. Some games of the same genre made me feel like there wasn't really a point to settling down and building a base (e.g. The Forest / Sons Of The Forest), but in Valheim, there absolutely is. You need different kinds of workbenches to craft certain items to progress in the game, and eventually beat the boss in the next biome, and you need a place to put them in, where they are safe from being destroyed in raids. This means walling off your base or building it in places not easily reachable by mobs is highly recommended. You can, however, cheese most types of raids by exploiting the terraforming tool to build walls out of dirt, that are completely indestructible. I've never employed this strategy, because I feel as though it ruins some of the fun. Everything you build also has a stability level. A structure that isn't supported well enough (e.g. by pillars connected to the ground) will break. Certain structures, like wood, that are exposed to the rain for extended periods of time will also lose up to 50% of their stability. Structures which haven't yet broken can be repaired at any time with the hammer.

The gameplay is pretty fun and challenging at times. For me, most of it consists of gathering resources for the next building project. Some of said resources can only be acquired in specific biomes and sometimes require sifting through dungeons. There are numerous types of dungeons spread across different biomes that differ in size, loot, and enemies you encounter within them. The resources you loot in dungeons will have to be brought back home to refine them. The map is quite sizeable and usually divided into islands by an ocean biome, so you will want to have other means of transportation than walking available, such as carts or boats. The easiest way of transportation is portals, but there are some restrictions on which materials you're allowed to carry through them. In my opinion, the game is infinitely more fun with friends, but it can be played in single-player as well. The damage and HP of enemies scales according to the amount of players on a map, and the difficulty settings can be customised.

There seems to be some controversy regarding Valheim's graphics. I think it is beautiful. Yes, the textures are pixelated, but the lighting makes it look gorgeous (and there are mods that replace the textures with higher resolution ones, if you so wish). It's a great vibe, especially combined with its relaxed ambient music, that changes depending on the biome you're in. Although the soundtrack does get a little bit repetitive after the 400 hours I've spent in the game. Also, everyone I've played this game with has praised how good the water looks. Especially the ocean during storms. This is a big plus point, since you will probably travel by boat very often.

I can highly recommend the game. You can get it for very cheap, and the value for money is insane. Ashlands, a new biome for Valheim, is currently in the works at the time of this review, and will presumably add a large amount of content to the game, completely for free.

I'm convinced Valheim is trying it's hardest to be a fun yet challenging survival game. 
And while it succeeds at being challenging, it's at the cost of the fun.

Building a base is hard, filled with questionnable design choices such as "smoke from campfires can kill you if your house isn't open enough" but at the same time wood simply doesn't burn, rain damages structures up to 50% of their health, stamina is a BITCH, ...

The game is fun when everything goes as you wish it does but unfortunately in the early game it's a very rare occurence, and while it does get better when you figure out how to obtain better gear, I still feel like this game punishes the player for enjoying it.

It's as if someone was slapping me in the face everytime I have mild fun, it's just unfair.

So yea I knew it would be hard but there are a lot of things that are either not fun or not making sense, and on top of that the map is GIGANTIC and takes ages to go through to find the slightest thing, and while I know it does get better with portals and such.. it's still a pain.

And don't get me started on the way boats work.

Valheim is so good, I'm actually amazed how a Indie company did this game

pros:

- the visuals are also quite beautiful, although not "2021 graphics", you can clearly see the character model is a bit bad, few polygons and all, but the landscapes, the sky, the weather etc are on point

cons:

It's good because it's hard. While the best experience is multiplayer, single player is good fun too. One can indulge in multiple urges: building a nice home and workshop, managing resources, fishing, exploring the land, beating difficult monsters. All that with moderate resource requirements, it runs well in old computers, which allows me to play multiplayer on LAN. I have re-started the game each time a new biome is released, and playing again is still quite good because there are different strategies to try, new architecture stiles, new terrain modifications to defeat bosses, etc.

Remembering that this is still a pre-release, there are some problems:

I find that multiplayer is still a bit buggy, with multiple unexplained missed connections. I can't make my Steam Deck to connect to a PC game in the same LAN, where other PCs can play on the same game without problems. 

Development has been slow, the game still doesn't have all the biomes that were planned. 

While exploring is encouraged by the game mechanics, there are few unique things to find other than more land biome combinations. I wish there were more surprises, treasures and unique items or beasts in the map.

Many small bugs like fish on the air, birds flying through water, floating items. etc.

A game where so much is possible yet very little of it is actually fun. Feels like it has never been play tested. Abilities? Sure but they do very little. Exploration? Dull wiki checklisting. Combat? Clunky and animations freeze you. Building? Feels horrible.

I am currently playing Lethal Company right now and I can't help but notice how one of these games has a lot of game, but very little fun, while the other has very little game, but heaps of fun. These games are in no way connected or similar to each other, but their philosophies are night and day.

More players does equal more enjoyment in Valheim, 2 isn't enough for me to enjoy this game, but I could imagine 5+ being a worthwhile experience. I don't recommend this game for smaller groups.

I have spent a lot of time on this game and I do not regret a second of it. I wish I could leave a neutral review but unfortunately I feel a "do not recommend" is more appropriate. 

The good parts of this game will keep you hooked. Exploring, crafting, building, O.K. combat, and sailing. Its very satisfying to build your way up and get to the largest boat and sail across "oceans", rivers, and up streams. It is also very punishing when you die very far from your "camp". Over all I had tons of fun playing with friends and getting into new areas through the power of teams work.

AAANNNDDD now the bad. Just like everyone else, I am also disappointed with the lack of content over the past two years. An early warning sign that this was going to happen was the dev team removing the road map not too long after launch. It is also fair to say that recent patches have comments disabled, most likely due to amount of people wanting/demanding content. A lot of players constantly asking where the promised content is, is not a bad thing, it shows that the community is still invested. BUT when the devs disable comments because the invested community wants meaningful updates on content... THAT looks bad. 

The way I see it, I spent $20, and got 257+ hours of enjoyment out of this game. I won. If the devs kill the game now and never fulfill their promises, they can only hurt themselves, tarnish their company name, and lose what trust the community has left. They can't take back the hours of fun I have had and the memories I have made with friends.

TLDR: For the low cost, its a lot of fun. Don't expect any more content, its probably never coming.

Years Later: Devs are still trash. Barely put out anything new/good. Old problems still exist, and Mods are beating the SHIT out of the Devs for improvements. Sad really, but sucks to suck.

I was really excited about this game and was expecting to absolutely love it. But I hate it, there is not a single thing in this game that I like. Let me put it this way, when I was 6 my parents took me on a vacation and we went to a restaurant and I ordered fish. It was really good, but unfortunately, the next day I kept throwing up and had a really strong diarrhea for the next couple of days. Now that dinner cost like 10 euros. Even though I literally shit my pants because of it, I can still say, I had one hell of a tasty dinner. With Valheim, I spent 20 euros and there was not a single moment of joy. No tasty treat, just me and my destroyed anus. I'd return it but unfortunately I played more than 2 hours, and you can't really get to know this game in less than 2 hours. At first I was confused by some mechanics but I thought this was just the beginning of the game and everything will fall in its place and the game will be good...but the game just kept adding more bullshit. Let me break it down.

Nice try Minecraft...

Lets start with the visuals, the biomes and the weather are beautiful. The forests are really nice, the fog, the weather and sunsets are really pretty. But this game still has minecraft graphics. You can polish it with pretty lighting, sprinkle glitter all over it, this game still has minecraft graphics, that's not a good thing. But ok, on this scale I guess you have to sacrifice something, especially if you're an indie developer.

Gameplay? Slow, tedious, repetitive...

By far the biggest disappointment is combat. I have nothing against skill-based combat, nothing against stamina mechanics (Conan Exiles after the Age of War update has excellent stamina-based combat) but there is something about overdependence on stamina in this game that makes you want to kill yourself. It takes a couple of swings to run out of stamina, that's fine you should plan your attacks, but it takes SUPER INCREDIBLY LONG to actually recharge. I have never seen such a slow stamina recharge. This absolutely destroys the fluidity of combat and it feels like a turn-based RPG, except enemies keep swinging at you while you can barely move. Moreover, the enemies keep swarming you everywhere you go and it doesn't matter if you kill one wave, the next one comes like 10 seconds after that. WHY??? The combat is cumbersome, clunky to say the least and the garbage AI is not making it any better. Enemies mostly just spam you with attacks, rarely block and instead, when you manage to hit them they just start running around, and you have to chase them. Because of the dumb stamina mechanics, imagine you want to run to relocate, then you stop to attack and nothing happens. Why? You're out of stamina. Imagine you are losing the fight, so you decide to run, but there's a bunch of obstacles that you have to jump over in order to escape, you press jump, nothing happens. Why? Because You're out of stamina.

You might have noticed me dropping subtle hints that I'm not a big fan of stamina in the game. So let's talk about it some more. It's not just combat. You can't get up  slightly steep inclines without holding a sprint button, you can't jump without stamina, which, as I mentioned, runs out immediately. So basically, without stamina you just can't get around even minor obstacles. Imagine that when running away from battle, the AI will follow you for a very long time and you will run out of stamina after a few meters and if you find yourself underneath a hill? You're dead. Now imagine you are sliding off a slightly steep hill and into the water. You've used all of your stamina. If you are in water you have to swim, but if you don't have stamina, you start to lose health. So you slide into water which kills you, because you have no stamina and you can't get out, because you have no stamina.

The amount of stamina as well as health depend on what you've eaten. Now here is a mechanic that whoever came up with needs to stop making videogames and requalify as an electrician or something. In Valheim your base health and stamina are very low and you have eat food to get a temporary buff. After 20 minutes have passed, you either have to eat more food or go back to so little base health that even the weakest enemies kill you in a few hits. Now combine low stamina when not having eaten with the stamina regen and regen delay and you can barely move around. I think this is why I went 19 hours instead of 30 minutes before getting absolutely sick of this game. Also did I mention that you need to eat three different kinds of food to get a decent buff? Yeah, each of the three gives only one third to your "full" health and stamina. You can't stack effects of just one food, you need to eat three different kinds. So if you can only find one kind of food? Too bad, you can only eat that once every 15 minutes. Yes, 15 minutes, remember how I said the buff lasts 20 minutes? Well after 15 minutes the buff reduces by one half. So even though, technically the HUD says the food lasts you 20 minutes, it's actually 15. To say this mechanic is very stupid would be an understatement as this goes way beyond the level of mental retardation.

And basebuilding, my favorite part in RPG's and survival games. Valheim presents a more advanced system of building with a lot of freedom. However, the system is so chaotic and random, that you build a big house only to have random pieces of it lose health or just burst alltogether. Combine this with the necessity of being within the range of a workshop in order to build anything at all, and the relatively small range of the workshop, the game punishes you for trying to build something bigger. Also having to nail the right angle with laser accuracy to snap objects where you actually want them, completely ruin basebuilding.

Crafting...dear lord...so you need to refine ore, right? Ok, well the smelter doesn't have a UI or a menu. You need to load ore from one side, and coal from the other side. One coal is not enough to make one ignot, you need two. And the smelter has a maximum capacity of 10 ore and 20 coal, so you can make 10 ignots. So in order to make just 10 ignots you need to load up the smelter and then wait like an idiot, because it takes a long time but not long enough to do something else, also the ignots don't stay in the smelter, remember, I said it doesn't have a UI, so the ignots fall on the ground, if during that time you decided to venture on one of the painful journeys that the game offers, you would risk losing them.

Verdict: I WANT MY MONEY BACK!!!

This is arguably one of the most tedious and brutal games on the market with "features" that are arbitrary limits to make it even harder. 

For instance: you cannot teleport metals. That sounds fne until you realize that biomes can be 15-20 real world minutes of walking away and are the only place to get the metal. But you can just make the trip and gather all the ore you want right? WRONG becuase everything weighs a metric ton and you cannot even carry a full stack of ore, So you get a ship to move some of the items, only it can only hold 4 stacks. So you now can spend all that time sailing back only to realise you cant craft anything with it.

Lets talk about dying. If you die in the wrong area, prepare to spend the next 45 minutes to an hour TRYING to get it back. You drop all of your items when you die and loose skill points that you train by using your weapons and tools. Is that fair? Arguably you need a punishment when you die to prevent suicide runs to beat the game. The BS is when a enemy appears out of no where and two shots you with the best armor for the area. So you get to run and get your stuff, only to have to die to the freezing of the mountains or the poison of the Swamps. Wolves will spawn out of nowhere and charge off a cliff face to kill you. 

Yes, I understand you need to be punished for dying, but when everything can two-tap you if you accidently try to run up a small hill becuase you ran out of stamina. Not to menton a good majority of the enemies are faster than you when sprinting and have unlimited stamina. 

In short, if you are masochistic you will love this tedious, slogfest of a game.

Valheim do have charm in it and the game work with co-op. It's workable sandbox game with liner progression, RPG element and its own unique. But very bare bone of everything and I mean it. You can spend lot of time worth its price because it force you to play that way.

I.... didn't hate Valhelm but I hate lot of thing that didn't translate well in Survival game are cram in this one. I do recommend to try it, but be prepare to waste a lot of your time since Valhaim grinding is garbage tier like MMO mobile without automode. THAT much.

Imagine playing Minecraft but you can carry only 32 iron and your sword need 64 to craft and 32 each to upgrade with 1 point of damage 4 times. Include armor, Iron deposit is 5-10min to travel back cuz no teleport allow with those ore.

Sandbox element is VERY limit. You don't have much to choose and those rain / roof mechanic force it more. You can try to be creative, but earth is limited.

Combat is ..... wonky. You feel OP and strong because of GEAR, not your 'player' skill. Much like those MMO mobile. While game allow to dodge, parry. It's still tie directly to gear and food buff. So you are not Viking try to reach Valhalla. But sick monkey pretend to be one. 
Weapon reach is short and slow. Stamina drain is huge. Monster run around toying with your office syndrome monkey. Some are just unfair to create FAKE challenge. No git gud or skill issue white knight magic can save your sorry dev a*s. but pure DEV issue again. It's complete lazy and childish design.

One thing I don't like but it work as game progression is design monster and biome with intent you have xxx buff with you. Instead of make it somehow hard but you can workaround or use those option to make it easier. Cuz its mean you have to grind for it - again. Waste your time to do a chore in game to actually progress.

Some said like it create realistic element... no, it's not. Realistic are not going along with RPG and lot of sandbox game mechanic with enemy advantage. If you said Valhaim is hard because you are sickly salary man try to survive in savanna then I'll agree with you.

Random event raid your base is another one that put ultimate cheap spawn from 7 Days to Die to shame due to combat / respawn mechanic. It's happen randomly (20% each 46 min.) and suddenly. Stronger with each boss killed. So you are force to active like Don't Starved all the time in this grinding MMO mobile - like game?

Remember that your power come from gear and food buff so if you die once, it's a slog death loop until it's stop. That not include some enemy destroy your chest or obliterate your farm. Good thing is destroyed item drop their material.... well, exclude you beloved farm/tame animal. And you only lose hard earn grinding skill once in a while :v

Also darkness is far more worst of all game out here. No brightness option, your torch is a matchstick. Other light is box of matchstick. Fog block everything like London smog. Okay, this is good point of Valhelm that light radius is VERY realistic ...... that don't translate well in game with heavy combat and RPG like this.

Dev force disadvantage on everything and I mean everything.

I .... like to say about good thing in Valhelm but I can't find strong point of it. Only unique point that each other game have so it's don't count. Everything else is working and bare bone. So.... Valhelm is "Working sandbox game with co-op" You have lot of thing to do, but not much deep each. You spend lot of time because it force you to grind. So it's worth a price if you want to spend your time to farm something and play with your friend or love doing slowly while solo it.

I highly recommend MOD Valheim for EXTREME FAR BETTER experience. That why I recommend it.

::Original Review after some hours after release::

So I JUST played an hour and want to share my experience.

Started the Game and laughed on the animation... bla bla story bla bla ...30 fps with ultra settings okay... 
Changing everything and only play on 2k instead of 4k (I do not have the best gaming pc)

Now I got like 70 fps, perfect for me. I do my first steps and listen to the crow, I should search for stones and harvest wood.. Oh Berrys! yum yum... oh cool you can replenish HP with Food and you NEED to eat a variety of foods so you don´t get bored (not the typical Instant Ramen Student I see..) 

where is the stone? *Hits stone with fists* - Skill Level Up 1 unarmed. Wait what? You NEED to actually use the skills to improve in those fields? (Dungeon Siege <3) 

Okay so I found some stones near the beach and hit a tree with my fists (yes yes every minecraft veteran knows the deal)

Wait... you can build in this game TOO?! I build a workbench and from there I saw how much new recipes got into my book. Nah I don´t want to build here... running further into the forest... an abondened house? Wait... theres a door... okay seems pretty empty... a chest! Just a torch with some "coins"? I wonder why I need coins later in this game are there traders?

Okay in this house the roof is broken but no problem with my new recipes, I build a campfire, a cooking station, found out that you can Sit to "rest" and gain HP and Stamina back. Wait... do I enjoy this game?...

Just a little bit more... Okay I got 1 hour and 30 Minutes left so I can still refund If I want to...

a boar! I attack him with my self made club from Wood & Stone, haha drop that juicy raw meat and give me that leather! Oh new recipes... Wait Shields are in this game too and I could dodge roll the incoming attacks If I want to? (Dark Souls fan bois) 

Okay time to step up my game... I need those trousers so I get a little bit more armor... Oh its nighttime... okay well I guess I head back to my cabin and build a sleeping spot... wait a moment I need to lit the fire in front of the entrance in case some wild animals want to sneek up on me.... 

I got a "dream" which told me that I saw the rivers flow upright and something bad is about to happen... some sort of God? just send out his animal forest squad to give me the creeps... So I need to defend my new home from those strange animals.. Done.... THIS IS MY HOOD!!! ah I lost a lot of HP wait... I still got the raw meat... I just need to cook It over the fire *PING* Oh I think its ready or Is it? .... oh wait.. nice now I got coal in my hands .... again .... okay thats It! (Ever played Monster Hunter and loved the cooking? you will do here too)

After I made myself a shield and a bow with some arrows I get confident and run into the forest... some sort of shamans are attacking me... okay thats why Its called the black forest... I barely survived and took myself into my warm cabin once again with freshly cooked meat and something that sparks my hearth with joy ... yes It feels like I play those games again that I already played as a kid and had SO much fun with... I´m speaking of a game that will give you vibes like: Dungeon Siege | Monster Hunter | Dark Souls | open world building Games | retro style graphics.

Of course that is only my first Hour into the game but at this point I will not refund It at all, just for this little hour were I forgot all of the trouble that is in the worlds right now... the dev deserved my money. Thank you!

The game play loop is really fun, and the best part is you can chart your own course and never feel bored. I find myself oscillating between exploration, base building, hunting, sailing, and transporting materials. I've only just hit the iron age at around the 50 hour mark (~100 in game days).

Bought this game on a whim with my cousin, and over time it became one of my favorite games of all time, and I have convinced a couple other people to buy it and they have also sunk tons of hours into it.

Each world you create is a ton of fun to slowly explore and map out, the progression is satisfying, and difficulty scaling is just right, with enemies from harder areas not just leveling up with your gear, but requiring you to use that gear more effectively.

Building is limited but you can still create beautiful structures if you are creative. The only problem with building is that raids limit what can practically be built. A cozy forest village will be a lot harder to keep intact than a stone castle built in a flat clearing.

Bossfights are fun and definitely test your mastery of combat. Combat itself is a pretty simple parry and punish system, but it feels good to do so. Each enemy has different parry timings, so you will have to learn how to handle each enemy differently.

Visuals are great, the low resolution textures combined with the extremely dynamic lighting system make a very distinct art style that works extremely well with the environments of the game.

Overall a ton of fun, even after many full playthroughs. As you learn more about the progression, you learn more ways to sequence break and progress faster on your next playthrough. For example [spoiler]Using trolls to break copper/tin deposits, venturing into frost caves and breaking doors to get iron, using a big hammer to dowse for silver[/spoiler]. Highly recommend to anyone even remotely interested in open world survival games.

I was not a fan of this game at all.  I found the graphics to be chunky and ugly, the world felt very empty and there wasn't a whole lot to do except run around and dispel the fog of war.  I was soooooo bored.

I've only played for 80 hours or so as a single player.  It is clear playing with a group would be easier.  However I think I have a good handle on the game, at least so far, so here is what you need to know:

Overall, I'm liking the game a lot. 

1. You will die, a fair bit. Happily all your stuff stays at your death spot, for apparently forever.  Unhappily, all your stuff stays at your death spot until you retrieve it, which can be challenging.  Or you can get the materials back together to make new stuff. 

2. Food is literally life/health.  You have a base 25 hit points.  That's ok in a safe area in the Meadows but not for much else.   You have 3 and only 3 food slots which you can fill with different types of food.  Food gives you both hitpoints (Health) and stamina.  Stamina is what lets you swing an axe, run or even swim.  no stamina, no doing anything except walking SLOOOOWLY.   Health and Stamina regen at a rate and to a level that depends on how long ago you last ate.  Eventually you can craft things that will help that. 

3. You Know Nothing.  The only way you learn about things you can craft or build, is by finding the related materials.  Literally, you pick up a piece of flint, now you know how to make a flint axe!  Same with basically everything. You get very minor tutoring at the beginning but not much.  I think you may start by knowing how to make a stone axe.  You then need some wood and stone to make a hammer.  The hammer is what lets you build stuff in the wild, and make the first crafting station.  Crafting stations let you craft good things like bows and armor etc. Note, you need a bed, covered by  a roof and claimed by you, in order to have it be a re spawn point.   Add a campfire and you can sleep the night there nicely too. 

4. The map is divided into different biomes.  Meadows, Swamp, Mountains etc.  Each biome has a different difficulty,  different enemies and most importantly, different materials.  Progression is based off of new materials, but also off of killing the Biome Boss which usually provides an item you need to get new materials in the next biome. 

5.  The play:  You gather materials, learn to craft new things or food or both, craft better stuff.  Venture into tougher biome to get better materials, die.  go back to get your stuff... die.   go back again, maybe get your stuff and run away or die and decide to make new stuff... Finally clear enough of the next biome to get to the better materials.  Make better stuff.  Find the boss area.  Summon the boss.  Kill the boss, get new item needed to get better materials in next biome, rinse and repeat.  (NOTE:  I have only just made it into the 3rd biome so the "die.  go back to get your stuff... die. " part is very much my experience. :D )

6. Building and fortification:  Reasonable options here and I highly recommend building a very defensible, forward base close to the next biome you are headed for.  So far I've been able to build in the Meadows (easiest biome), close to places like the Mountains or the Swamp etc.   

7. Except, perhaps the Meadows, Do what the game says, Don't travel at night if you can avoid it.  Everything comes out at night in considerably larger numbers to hunt you down in the dark. 

8. You will eventually be able to plant and grow things.  Apparently you can also raise some livestock though I've not been able to myself yet. 

9. Aside from the rather challenging critters in each biome, there are also Crypts and things which are basically small dungeons, which usually have special stuff you need or want.  

Ok, that should at least get you going reasonably well.   So far I highly recommend it. :-D

Valheim, the game that's like building IKEA furniture with your friends – sometimes things don't quite fit, but the end result is still a blast! It's like the developers handed us a toolbox full of fun, and occasionally, a rogue hammer flies across the room (metaphorically speaking).

Picture this: you're chopping wood with your buddies, and suddenly your character decides to breakdance with the axe. It's not a feature; it's a surprise dance party! Valheim – where even the glitches have style.

And when your friend accidentally builds a ladder to nowhere because they misplaced a floorboard? Well, that's just Valheim saying, "Who needs logic when you can have a stairway to the sky?"

In this game, we're not just vikings; we're Viking interior decorators. "Is this longhouse feng shui enough? How about we add more deer trophies for that rustic ambiance?"

So, while Valheim might be in early access, it's basically the video game equivalent of a charming fixer-upper – glitches and all. Grab your hammer, tighten those screws, and let's keep building ridiculous memories together! Skål to the chaos! 🍻

Base game is alright, but do not buy this game with the expectation of consistent updates.

Devs, on multiple occasions, have broken promises and scaled back their scope, all while ignoring requests for basic features such as QoL and Keybinds. 

Take the 2021 Roadmap for example, 4 Major updates by the end of 2021. We've gotten 2. In late 2023.

Devs, essentially, got a bunch of money and ironically slowed DOWN on development, seemingly investing zero profit back into their "early access" game.

I support Indie Devs, and I understand how difficult game development is, but for god's sake don't just start breaking promises and scaling back once your game gets successful. These actions have left a lot of players in the dust, and actually made a lot of the playerbase quit. 

An example of this is Modifiers. Highly requested, easy to add (I hope), and beneficial to the game. Modifiers weren't added until late 2023.
Until now, you had to deal with Portal Restrictions, mind numbing resource rates, and unforgiving gameplay, assuming you didn't want to mod.

This long delay absolutely butchered the target audience. People who didn't want to grind that long dropped the game, and people who didn't want the game to be so unforgiving also just dropped the game.

This game is labelled as "early access", making players expect a finished product in a reasonable amount of time. It's been 3 years, and with only 2 updates, "early access" has become downright misleading on this game. It's currently half baked, missing a lot of features a lot of other games have, but fanboys will say it's okay because the Devs ticked the "early access" box.

All of these decisions actually hurt the longevity of the game.


Even though this game had a lot of potential, most of it was crushed by the Dev's inability to follow through with a success. If you have 1+ friends, and have the ability to mod the game, I'd say give it a go. 

Otherwise, don't buy this game expecting content expansions within reasonable periods of time. Game may be fun for 1-2 playthroughs, but there's virtually no replayability aside from waiting for content drops.
