Amazing game, but Mistlands really ruined it for me. Aiming was never great (elevation differences often result in misses) and the Mistlands is all sheer cliffs. Also, there's a flying gatling gun of hellfire that is just never fun (even with an arbalest). Oh, if something can't fly, it can knock you back 20ft off those sheer cliffs into the water. Where it will continue to hit you as you waste stamina swimming back and trying to jump back out of the water (which you'll likely just get punted back out into the water during). Also, those guys like to attack at the same time as the fire airship, which is continuing to pelt you as you try to swim back to land. And no, none of these things are addressed by the featherfall cape.

Dear hardcore fan of survival-craft games,

I suggest you don't spend your time on this game. As this game is highly overrated. Moreover, I strongly believe that it doesn't respect your, player's, time. The game might be bigger than sum of its components. However, this is not about Valheim. Here are 10 facts that I came across:
1) Combat is not fluid enough, hitboxes are very wacky, sometimes you can't hit enemies 1 centimeter above/below you. There are some types of enemies even designed to exploit that (hello ticks from Mistlands). Additionally you can complete the whole game with one type of weapon because all the enemies are basically bullet sponges and if you use wrong type of damage you still use the same tactics to kill an enemy, it will just take you much more time to do so. Rolls and blocks are not essential to the combat, they are quite inconvenient, waste a lot of stamina and you will be better off with hit and run anyway.
2) Movement in vanilla game is quite bad in some use cases, you will be climbing the hills a lot and that doesn't feel good since you don't have any mechanics that help you (grabbing the ledge, etc.). Eventually this becomes a Skyrim mountain goat simulator. Swimming is awful because enemies can hit you in you water, while you are totally helpless. You run out of stamina very fast and when you are out of stamin in the water you literally die. Beware that some locations are based around water inside them (Swamp, Mistlands). Stamina in the vanilla games feels like an obstacle to artificially extend the game time instead of a fun mechanic.
3) Building is okay but nothing outstanding, you can't terraform as much as you can in Minecraft but that's not an issue. Sticking structures can sometime be a problem because of height differences though. Your best bet is to look for another flatter place then. However, I don't find much pleasure or incentive to build in Valheim but maybe that's just me personally.
4) Survival aspect is once again okay, but can be a bit grindy at times but more on that below. I can't say that survival is the main mechanic of the game, it is just there to be there.
5) Crafting is very primitive, no complex pipelines for crafting advanced stuff, no multi-structure buildings, the formulae is very simple. You build a work station, you build addons to the work station, you build a work station for the next tier of items, you build addons, rinse and repeat. No ingenuity or planning required.
6) UI is very poor (in vanilla game, somewhat fixed in mods). You have very limited inventory space in your own inventory and chests, stack sizes are very small. Managing your inventory and chests is very annoying since even the most fundamental things like moving in stacks or sorting is missing. And that's not the only concern about the UI. I spent most of my time in a modded playthough and QoL changes are so massive that you remember vanilla UI as a nightmare.
7) Progression feels forced, you level up in multiple stats but you don't gain new skills/play styles/traits, you don't feel more powerful, instead you like hit 10% harder when you've leveled 10 levels in some skill, you don't even feel that you've progressed.
8) Automation is absent in vanilla game. Want to craft new armor? Good for you, just remeber to spend around an hour close to your refineries even if you already have all the necessary resources. And you will do it very often since the game is so GRINDY...
9) Grind is a synonym to this game, if you go vanilla route, prepare hundreds of hours to complete the game. You will encounter grind in every aspect of the game. Gathering resources - check, refining resources - check, moving resources - check, killing mobs - check, inventory management - check, running from point A to point B - check. But this is for the greater good of an epic adventure, right? Right?!
10) Adventure - You kill your first boss Eikthyr in an hour, that was quite fun and new, you go for your second boss - the Elder, you find new resource types, you prepare your gear, you search the dungeon for the mark to the boss spawner, you bring the sacrifice, boom... you got him, well done. And... you do the same for every other remaining boss in the game but it gets progressively more grindy. The formulae gets stale after the 3rd boss. The bosses themselves aren't unique, some just have fire effects, other frost effects, etc; boss fights are very easy to figure out and solve, no challenge here, 1-2 attack patterns and that's it, just quintessential 'hit them until they die'. Finding bosses is not exciting or story driven, you explore the same dungeons until you get lucky to find a hint to their locations. Dungeons are very similar even across different bosses. And finally, once you defeat the boss, the reward is just miserable compared to the grind you did to overcome them. 
What can I say to conclude? Yes, Valheim has some redeeming qualities, the graphics and aesthetics feel nice, you can sometimes encounter some beautiful scenery and take a screenshot, viking lore can be fun. Despite that, essentially, all the game mechanics are already present in other survival-craft games and each one of them is done better in most of them. Valheim is a kind of 'jack-of-all-trades but master of none', you get a lot of very shallow features to work with. I can't recommend this game to anyone who has already been exposed to the games like Rust, Minecraft, Terraria, Don't Starve, etc. as you will be spending 90% of your time in an endless loop of grind being constantly frustrated to have that sweet 10% of fun.

P.S. mod support is not top-tier in this game either, a lot of really useful mods are outdated, installing and managing mod versions across the client and server can be painful and I haven't seen any major game-overhaul Minecraft or Skyrim level mods, just small improvement.

Valheim is one of those rare games that has a unique feel and gameplay despite a zillion similar type games out there.. 
 It seems to try to capture some of the experiences we felt with games from 20-30+ years ago but provide some modern conveniences. 

There's both extremely easy and very challenging components to the game.  It has an interesting mix of challenge and ease both for single player and for specific amounts of players... where with single certain fights and situations can be harder, but overall the food and resource situation is much easier, where with 2 it's pretty balanced overall, but 3+ you have to have more specific farming or gathering folks to sustain a constant explore and conquer playstyle. 

One thing that was great from old school RPG's was the ability to just walk somewhere and die, where most games keep you sort of noobishly "hemmed in".  I like that you can RNG mountain super close to the starting point and unknowingly get one shot by a wolf on the edge and have to strategize sometimes how to even get your items back.  I also like the daunting oceans for the first times, not really sure how it's going to go.. and unsure what awaits when you do find land.

The music is quite good, not quite as insane as 7 days to die but really good and helps keep you enraptured in the game.  This game is easy to forget you need to stretch, drink water, eat food :D 

Overall I'd give this game a 9.5/10 because it does have some issues that can be improved on but overall it's absolutely worth the money.  Even with a basic base building functions available, you can create some incredibly cool bases :)

Disikes - Lots of darkness, especially in the swamps and mistlands. Not being able to see for what feels most of the time is frustrating and really makes me want to move on.
Fog - Way to much fog that hangs around for way to long. This can bring gameplay to a screaming halt for up to 10 min. Boring.
Unclear tech tree. I gave up trying to figure out the tech tree. I just google it all now.
Stamina. Does this game understand that the Norsemen depicted had stamina beyond that of a morbidly obese 6 year old?

Likes - The idea of conquering each area, while wildly unbalanced at times, is a good idea and fun to play. Being able to go back and conquer once deadly enemies with ease is a nice way to show progression.
Co-op. Without this I would not have played as long as I have.
Setup options. The range is adequate and can sightly affect gameplay.

An unassuming title that entered early access with a staggering amount of content so early. Can be quite beautiful and at the same time be quite not. Pixel textures look better from a distance. Lighting is fantastic. 
Music is also great but does not fit the viking theme.  

I would put this game in the same category as 7d2d in so far as to say that it has a good core game loop with many strange and badly informed game design choices that dont get fixed while the developers add small amounts of content instead. 

For now its not an ideal game, but its getting there and much like 7d2d the hope is that it will someday become a great and finished game. Obviously theres more chance of that happening with a new title like Valheim and less chance for its counterpart. Open world crafting can be really fun if given the attention from developer and player alike. 

Building is the best part of Valheim, and could be better with some tweaks. What the modding community has wrought hopefully will also lend its quality of life improvements to the ideas the developers implement in the future.

Valheim is an excellent open world pseudo rpg. It falls somewhere between minecraft and monster hunter and somehow manages to land in the sweet spot. 
I expect active development to continue for a long time and the game to age like fine wine.
Additionally, the devs seem to care about building a player base and have elected (so far) not to charge extra for any dlc content meaning the whole game is a one time purchase only. And a reasonably priced one at that. 
My personal favorite part is the building system which has the oh so popular snap-to construction but also a physics engine and realistic stability mechanics.

Basically everything you have ever wanted to happen after you die. It's like Dick Proenneke Simulator, if he was a viking. You want to be able to just run around and forage stuff without ever needing to piss, inexplicably, so you also don't need to worry about building a bathroom. Imagine Minecraft, but it had marginally reasonable demands of physics and a subjectively cooler base game surrounding it. No shade, but damn dude, I would much rather be running around and dunking on asshole monsters in this weird viking halfway-house world than hitting green dicks that explode.

Anyways, play the game, it absolutely rocks, I'm 40+ hours in an barely just learned how to tootle around on a fucking raft, and also just started getting into log cabin building. Also, I went to the library and got a baller book called "The Family Cabin" (not the horror thriller, just a big ol' coffee table book of cabins) that gave me some awesome building ideas, that's something I've never done, so that's pretty cool, gotten this involved in a game's building mechanics that I started in on real world examples, but then again one of my life goals is to live in a camper a billion miles from any other breathing human except for the times I have to go into town to get supplies then I go to the pub all bearded and grunt and nod when the waitress asks me if I'd like something to drink, honey, and I ask for a shot and a beer, and keep 'em coming then after I'm tapped, I go back to the trunk and go back into the wild places and live out my life.

But yeah, worth the bucks, definitely a must play unless you're a nerd then enjoy living in a completely rational world with no wonder or joy there Neil De Grasse Tyson.

Great game! The combat is great, reminds me a little of the Dark Souls games. You can parry, dodge, sneak attack, etc. Most of the game is very realistic, like building. You have to build pillars to support your roof if it is high enough, you have to make a fire and ventilate the smoke, you get debuffs if you are cold, wet, etc, and you get buffs for being rested and stuff like that. If you have a home, it will protect you from the rain and other outside things, but you must protect it. Depending on the bosses you have killed, different things will raid to your home. The bosses themselves are great, they are very different for one another so you need different stuff and strategies. The progression is good and bad imo. Going from the Swamp to the Mountains was a pain, trying to not freeze while getting hunted by wolves/drakes and treasure hunting for silver. Going from the meadows to black forest was great though. This game will take time to progress through, so don't expect getting through it in a week or two. Also, if you can, BRING FRIENDS! It is much more fun and chaotic. Overall, Valheim is a great game! Had some very great times in it, and looking forward to more! I would definitely recommend Valheim to people seeking a great survival game. I cannot remember if it costs anything, but if it does, IT IS WORTH IT! Hope my review gets more players to play this awesome game!

A cozy game for people who think minecraft was way too easy, Souls games had the right idea punishing malfeasance, and appreciate an austere environment sometimes literally out for blood.

It's an absolute blast but in the calmest way possible.  You slowly pick up rocks and sticks, punching trees or picking up branches, make a safe spot... and then the game says nothing else to you.  Occasionally there's a raven that comes down and gives you tutorial hints and that's about it.  There *is* an overarching goal to eliminate a variety of 'Forsaken' (from Odin) creatures spread out through the world, but there's no real time or method constraint for eliminating them other than how you'll get there and if you can beat it with your gear  It has a calming atmosphere that's brimming with points of interest, familiar environments of the northern hemisphere, and a healthy dose of danger coupled with a real sense of surviving and the urge to explore.  You'll gradually breeze into the bronze age and take to the seas, process scrap iron, and meet monsters and men who act more like they're defending their home than trying to erase you from existence.

The game has several things really going for it even in early access;

-  The boat and ocean physics have no reason to slap this hard for an early access game.  I've never seen anything better.
-  Combat is straightforward, gear upgrading as well.  If you're not smart about what you're doing or when to run from a fight, you're gonna die.  Watch your stamina!
-  A robust food system that, again, has no reason to be as thought out as it is for being early access.  
-  It feels so open, pristine, thoughtful, and dangerous.  It's really got the *feeling* of being placed in a magical new land to explore almost as good as BotW did.  
-  The world is big, and each world unique, but they give you lots of means to get around including travel gates and ships you can build.  The first power you get will be a stamina boost to running/jumping as well, which is great for sprinting to a copper deposit and back during the day to avoid night creatures.
-  You can accurately describe it as "Breath of the Minecraft-Souls" and genuinely mean it in the best of ways for those games.

There *are* some points though that do make it through as a bit rough:

-  The research tree is 100% discovered by either picking up or using items for the first time, meaning that if you forget to harvest a tree type or don't make everything for your first base camp you're going to miss out on it with little warning.  Quite realistic, really, but in the gameplay sense there's little guidance to focus on this.  It should be in the back of your mind to use new tools and build new things as able.  

-  The cost of some items makes it incredibly disproportionate to your time/efforts when dying; if you take a ship somewhere and die you're not only out on your gear, but you also need to make a new ship to go to that old one and retrieve your body.  The game gives you unlimited stamina for a minute when you grab your body, which is nice to GTFO once you grab your stuff, but bronze and other materials can only be gathered with certain tools and items.  If you don't have spares back home, you may be starting from almost-scratch.

-  It has a wonky mouse button setup that's a bit weird to get used to, using the press of the middle scroll wheel to block and in construction an accidental right click will destroy what you were looking at (but refund the materials).  

Overall, however, this game strikes me as something special.  It's a cozy game that treats the pain of the world with reverence, but provides you the means to shelter from it and enact all sorts of building and travel fantasies of a medieval magical viking fantasy.  It'll hug you farming honey and berries for mead and that will help you with potions/food making the struggles of the world easier to handle... and it'll ramp it up as you go along.  I find myself almost in love with where this game seems to be heading and heartily recommend it to anyone looking for a challenge and an adventure wrapped together in an exploration game.

Top 5 game of all time for me.  This game is unmatched when it comes to value for money.  A very cheap game, but a very rich experience.  Valheim is an amazing survival/building game with incredible music and atmosphere.  The game is soooo clearly made with love and passion by real gamers, its a breath of fresh air compared to the industry standards now a days.  No additional costs - but the devs just keep adding content to this amazing game.  New zones and endgame content being added in feels like straight charity to the Valheim community that got a great game on launch, and continue to get a better and better experience every update.  A HUGE POSITIVE of this game is also that it supports robust modding...and the mods for it are fantastic.  I recommend you use the R2Modman program to manage your mods.  There's almost nothing the mods can't fix, or enhance or tweak to your liking.  Especially for those who have already played through the base game once - try the mods!  It will add so much to your experience. (diablo style random loot and effects, new spells and entire new classes, mass farming and building improvements, little cosmetic changes, more bag space or more building pieces and so much more - it truly shows that people love this game and have put in so much work and creativity into the mods of the game they love).  And now with the new difficulty settings, you can play Valheim super chill, atmospheric building sim - all the way to thrilling hardcore survival.  10/10 would recommend to all.

EDIT: See my original review below for initial thoughts for the record. However in recent months the company running it has lost my respect and seems to have lost its way. Game is decent value but not going to have an in depth future as things seem to me, unless the Developers pull their finger out and actually develop at a decent pace again - or you elect to play modded.

Valheim was a lucky discovery for me. Somehow they Team has created a game that ticks all my personal boxes! 
It has a lore based plot, but not one you have to stay slaved to if you just wish to explore and learn. You are not bound by an artificial time constraint. Play at whatever speed you feel comfortable with.

It scales the more checkpoints you do elect to pass (in the form of section Bosses defeated) the harder the games in built challenges scale. But only when you want them to.

Its visually a feast, while the resolution of the graphics is low for a modern game the combination of advanced effects make it visually stunning. I particularly enjoy the detailed physics shown in sailing the oceans and waters of the Worlds. My only grumble here is that they yet to have introduced any ability to dive under water, but I hope that will come in time.

Overall its hard to fault as the 6 MILLION (at time of review) or so downloads kinda indicated with no help from me!

As an early access game yes it does have a few things like the diving in water etc that I feel do detract from the otherwise amazingly immersive experiance. I hope in time they can at least double the resolution of the game to get the best of detail when zoomed tightly in. The main downcheck is after you have gotten the gist of how it plays its a little repetative, though this may be be design to encourage you to attempt the next Boss and thus unlock the next Tech Teir. I would like to see more rare objects and items to be discoverable by those that love the infinite explorabilty the games engine allows for.

But these are very minor niggles. For the very modest fee (at time of review) you'd be mad not to give Valheim a try. 

I am excited and looking forward to the next rounds of expansion and updates almost as much as just going out and raiding for more materials! Over all a very satisfying blend of challenge simple mechanics and excellent visuals. A must buy.

First and foremost, the level of challenge in Valheim is nothing short of exhilarating. From fending off ferocious creatures to conquering daunting bosses, every step in this expansive world feels like a triumph. The game strikes a perfect balance between difficulty and enjoyment, making each victory all the more satisfying.

The Viking thematic is executed flawlessly, transporting players to a mythical realm where they can truly embrace their inner warrior. The attention to detail in the world design, character customization, and weapon crafting is commendable. Valheim has succeeded in creating a universe that feels both historically grounded and fantastically immersive.

Speaking of immersion, Valheim excels in pulling players into its rich tapestry of exploration and adventure. The dynamic weather, day-night cycles, and ever-changing landscapes contribute to an experience that feels alive and constantly evolving. Whether sailing treacherous seas or exploring dense forests, I found myself completely engrossed in the world of Valheim.

One of the most remarkable aspects of this game is its therapeutic quality. During challenging times, Valheim served as my digital sanctuary—a place where I could escape, unwind, and find solace. The calming ambiance, coupled with the joy of conquering in-game challenges, provided a much-needed reprieve, and I am genuinely grateful for the emotional refuge Valheim offered me.

The multiplayer aspect of Valheim is where the game truly shines. Sharing the Viking experience with friends has been an absolute blast. Building fortresses together, embarking on epic journeys, and facing off against formidable foes as a team created unforgettable moments that will be cherished for a long time.

In conclusion, I can't help but express my genuine admiration for Valheim. It has become more than just a game; it's a source of joy, camaraderie, and relaxation. I eagerly anticipate the prospect of more content in the future, as the developers have crafted a masterpiece that deserves to be expanded upon. Valheim has undoubtedly left an indelible mark on my gaming journey, and I can't recommend it enough to fellow adventurers seeking a truly exceptional experience. Skål to Valheim, and may its legacy endure for many sagas to come!

Game feels the same as when it came out, maybe even worse. Mindless grinding running back and forth through areas for 10 minutes to get a portion of the materials you need, and then doing it again fifteen times makes it nothing but tedious. Oh, but they have portals, just build portals. NO, the most crucial part of the game after you kill the first boss, that is mining for copper and tin, cannot be done with the help of portals because they do not allow said materials to go through portals. Cool. I could go on and on about plenty of other negatives, such as the immense difficulty spike after you kill the second boss, the brain-fuck of a boring sailing system, and so, SO much more. Sure, it's fun for the first 10 hours, but for a game that is meant to be played for far, far more than 10 hours, it is one of the biggest examples of wasted potential in recent video game releases.

This game is a lot of fun, it has flaws but so many more qualities. I spent hundreds of hours playing it and I recommended it to everybody I know.

And then the Mistlands update was released, and you guys dropped the ball, hard ! It is simply Not Fun !

In every biome the biggest danger is a creature, Troll, Oozer, Serpent, Golem, Berserker.. in the Mistlands you are fighting your stamina bar 90 % of the time. Stamina management is by far the most annoying thing about Valheim but in almost every biome, it's tolerable... In the Mistlands, it is Not ! 

This is due to the terrain being so hard to traverse. It is almost never flat. The Mistlands will have you jump constantly to climb the rocky terrain. And in turn, this makes one of Valheim most glaring issues ten times worse : Combat.

With the vast majority of weapons, you Cannot hit an enemy that is below or above you. In the Mistlands, this happens constantly. Add to that the behaviour of the ai, which sometimes makes it run around in circles instead of trying to fight you, and you end up with an overall frustrating experience.

This is not my only complaint. In no particular order, here are some of the problems with the Mistlands :

- the mist, remove it, it's a bad mechanic that ruins an otherwise beautiful biome. I get it you want mist in the mistlands, but take it from someone who has put over 1k hour in the game. I dread having to go in the mistlands because I know I'm gonna be struggling to just walk through the biome, simply because : I Cannot See ! The lantern you gave us is a joke, it barely clears the mist 5 meters around your character and doesn't even do it consistently.
- why are there 2 types of terrain, one of which cannot be cultivated (but can still be flattened with the hoe) 
- why are there so many 1 star seekers (not one other enemy in the game has such a large proportion of 1 stars)
- why do seekers resist all types of physical damage
- [strike]the boss sometimes spawns outside of its lair (saying "sometimes" is an understatement)[/strike] (fixed)
- the carapace armour looks awful, the bronze armour looks better than it
- no tower shield in the carapace tier 
- the roots are supposed to be roots of freakin Yggdrasil, why are they running after you harvest 10 cups of sap
- gjalls hit way too hard and absolutely destroy your buildings, forcing you to run outside every time they show up because you don't want to spend 15 minutes fixing your house
- the Eitr foods don't give enough hp and stamina
- too many giant skeletons spawn without a head
- not enough decorations

Now for things that need to change before the game goes 1.0 (I will keep adding things to this list as I keep playing because I know this game has insane potential)

- trophies and other useless loot still drop too often (which wouldn't be a problem if all of them could be used in a recipe)
- tons of basic building pieces are still missing at every tier
- the tar pits force you to absolutely destroy the landscape to harvest tar
- food shouldn't decay in half the time indicated on the tooltip
- the harpoon is useless, collecting serpent scales only works by jumping in the water at the same time you finish off the serpent
It's a LOT better than I expected.

"Endless possibilities for ways to build your way across the world. Great atmosphere, great music, great gameplay, and a rewarding progression system. 1000+ hours in and I'm still finding new experiences and new ways to overcome challenges; and this game isn't even finished yet."

At least, that's what I would have said a couple of years ago.  This game's developers move at a glacier's pace; they make Mojang look fast by comparison.  The game is still riddled with the problems that people were willing to overlook when it seemed like this game had potential, but  this pile of hot garbage has been in pre-release for years now and it probably will never actually be finished at this rate.  Screw these guys, go spend your money on BG3. Now THAT is a game. a damn good game, a finished game; unlike Valheim. Larian understand what it means to care about the people he's making a game for. These little shit fucks narrowly didn't just take the money and run a few years ago.

I play this with friends and I got to say on a positive note the atmosphere is nice and building is fun, but the game is painfully slow something alot of people seem to agree on. Grinding through the stone age takes a bit of time, trying to get through the bronze age though is like watching paint dry, I don't mind running back to the black forest to get materials but upkeeping coal for smelting is a hassle because it depletes very quickly and the payoff for getting copper is not much. The food system is cool at first but overall redundant and tedious once you realize you'll be dealing with it for the rest of the game, your base health is 25, you'd figure that defeating a boss would raise your hp but it doesn't.

Secondly is dock building, trying to build a dock that reaches out into the water is a ridiculous time consuming process that takes for ever to accomplish because you can't build while swimming so you have to wait for a storm to take the tide back multiple times, run out go build, wait for it to lower, repeat, then your dock requires daily maintenance because the wood takes water damage. Why the need for a dock? because in the case your ship is to close to shore during a storm it will get slammed and beaten to where I have had to build 3 ships again because of this.

lastly would be the community, It's not what I would call toxic but there's this weird overly protective passive aggressive attitude towards anyone suggesting helpful changes, and it becomes a real turn off. 
Example: Gee dock building is really difficult I think they should implement a system to where it would be easier to accomplish.
Responses usually go something like this: Ever tried building a dock irl because that's pretty hard.
Example 2: Hey I think that when some defeats the first boss they should get a health and stamina increase, that way we aren't relying on food forever and food instead gives us passive buffs.
Response: Ever tried surviving without food irl because that's pretty hard.

I've never fought an undead skeleton irl but I'd imagine that would be pretty hard, I've never fought a troll irl but I'd imagine that would be pretty hard.

There are people suggesting really helpful, creative, and detailed ideas that could definitely help the game, then there are those so reluctant to change and I don't see the validity as to why that is when presented.

Overall the game is only fun at first but after awhile you feel like progression becomes more punishing than it does become rewarding and at certain points feels like it hits stagnation for long periods. I would probably recommend this game when/if it actually becomes more accessible for others. Other than that I would tell inquiring buyers you're not missing out on much.

Game is a banger, exactly the kind of game I've always wanted – a survival game where base building actually matters, and where every item serves a purpose. Often, base building systems in games are just for show, but here, it's like real life – you need your base to survive, craft, cook, breed animals, and do a thousand other things. And the best part is the realistic physics system; you can't build too high or everything collapses, and you can't have smoke inside buildings, for instance.

I really dig the simple yet beautiful pixel art style of the game. It reminds me of older PS1 games but with a modern touch. The setting is fantastic and fits perfectly into the gameplay loop. A fantasy-infused Viking world, rich with Nordic mythology—it's just spot on.

Too grindy. Played with four friends and the grind was insane. So many trips just to get ores and smelt etc. They said there are supposed to be ten bosses? Each boss unlocks materials, so that's insane. It's like terraria but half your time is mining mindlessly.
Honestly I just don't like this game. The building is weird, and the movement feels bad to me. I've never been able to get into this game. It seems like a good game if you can get past those quirks.

My friend and I were sitting on discord, trying to decide on a game to play together. As fans of FPS and Tactical Shooting games, we were looking at Six Days in Fallujah, and were very tempted to play that. Until, we found this game. We are not normally huge Survival Game fans, we're the kind of people to pick up a survival game and throw it to the side a couple days later because the progression was too slow. 

Luckily, we bit the bullet and decided to pick up Valheim. We are now 22 hours in, sailing the seas and creating one of the coolest villages ever. This games building mechanics are absolutely incredible. As someone who loves building in Minecraft, this game has an incredible amount of depth and possibilities when it comes to building structures. 

The combat, while slightly clunky, feels like a dumbed down version of Dark Souls combat, and it's a ton of fun.

Seriously, give this game a chance. You will love it.

A phenomenal and extremely entertaining open-world survival game. It is filled with enough content to keep you occupied for 100+ hours. The game also looks absolutely stunning despite low texture resolution of the models in the game. Truly shows how much depth and beauty a good lighting system can add.

This game is excellent and gorgeous.  Easily the best environmental graphics I've seen.  I don't think this game would run well if the textures weren't potato just because the environment alone is so incredibly well done and would use up all your resources.  Pacing solo can get a bit tough and grindy, especially as some updates encourage a world restart.  It gets harder and harder solo - at some point I'm afraid it just won't be realistic.  You can still retrieve your stuff from previous worlds (your char is persistent) but building up your bases then finding and getting through the bosses again is time consuming.  This is ok though, the long-haul pacing is much appreciated.

Addition 12/2023 -  Absolutely love that they added difficulty options for servers.  My daughter has always wanted to play this but it was too hard for her.  Now we have been having a blast hanging out on Casual+, building beehives, thrones, and coin piles everywhere.

A true masterpiece. Doesn't hold your hand but gives you enough to run with to figure it out, ignore anyone who says it doesn't.

You'll spend hours building your home, fine tuning everything and then coming under attack by a group of trolls and deal with damage control. You'll fight dragons, skeletons, mythological creatures in land, sea and dungeons and you'll feel an overwhelming sense of achievement when you beat that next boss.

Fair warning, the difficulty does go up and steeply. Once you beat the black forest boss you're in the big leagues, Mistlands is a massive 'fuck you for getting this far, forget everything you know'.

The only thing I hate about the game is the Mistlands. It's ridiculously hard to navigate and the mobs are so out to get you.

Pick it up, you'll love it. Playing with friends is also great although the difficulty scales with the number of players so keep that in mind.

If you wanted a survival builder game, this is it. Significantly more fun with company. but still satisfying solo. Equal parts meditative beauty and brain-breaking stress. Average play time is about a billion hours per player, and that speaks volumes.

I adore this title and I am exited to see what happens to it in the years to come.
The atmosphere and graphics are gorgeous and the building is mostly great.

As of now the worlds feel rather barren and the game is very frustrating in singleplayer,
due to the amount of chores when building a home for yourself.
Valheim plays best together with a friend, though currently the server infrastructure is lacking.

There are a couple of issues and a few things is heavily dislike, such as the leveldrain on death and the overpowered Corpse Run effect.
The ability to use one character on several worlds and cheating equipment without any consequences is also a point that might need some addressing at some point.

Valheim is a charming RPG with a lot to offer.

I had the pleasure of starting this game completely blind with a group of friends. I will never forget feeling invincible after we entered the [spoiler]"bronze age"[/spoiler] and met familiar foes wielding an arsenal of shiny new weapons and cut through them like a knife cuts cheese, only to be quickly humbled by the massive difficulty spike from advancing to the next biome. The combat is "Souls-like" in the sense that stamina management, i-frames from dodging, and timed parries is crucial to surviving difficult encounters. This game fantastic at balancing every element of a survival crafting game, whether it's progression, combat, base building, farm simulating, resource gathering, exploring, you won't run short of things to do. 

I had just as much fun playing through the game solo. However, like most games, it becomes a bit sterile once you've run out of things to discover and/or run out of friends to play the game with. Which leads me to my only major complaint; the dreadfully slow pace for new content development. This is a common sentiment among the community. However, it is easily resolved with the application of mods. If you're left feeling like you want more, Thunderstore is a very user-friendly mod manager and you can double the game's content with a few clicks. But be warned, if you're like me and you enjoy a challenge, with every mod you add that gives you an extra edge, your experience will grow stale without adding difficulty to bring balance to the game's intention to be a "hardcore" experience.

I haven't had a game draw me in so fast in quite a long time, I have only progressed pass the first boss and still see myself putting probably at least 20 hours in before I want to take on the next boss, I feel like I can really take it at my own pace. Great immersion and gorgeous landscapes that I could sit and stare at for days.

Preface:
I have some hours in the game (although a lot was spent afk) and do enjoy it, but ONLY with extensive use of mods. I consider the game unplayable without mods and I can't recommend a game purely for the mods other people create for it. Even less so when the developers seem to consider their vision for the game the only acceptable one, dislike mod(der)s and break mods repeatedly for very minor bugfixes.

* Content development has come to a virtual halt after the initial commercial success. A very common phenomenon in the indie dev world, unfortunately.
* Walking Simulator: There's what I would call a medium amount of content stretched veeeery wide by forcing the player to walk around A LOT. Getting the necessary equipment of a tier needs a lot of resources and even if you change the config to get maximum resource yields, you will still make a lot of trips, because of weight and inventory and stack limits. Also, there are always resources you can only get in one biome, but need throughout the game, making you run between biomes, which takes several minutes each time. Pure busy-work, annoying, boring and honestly, insulting.
* Extremely railroaded: The world claims to be open, but actually, there's only one way to be played, the way the dev intended. It is basically impossible to do anything in a biome without "completing" the previous biome before.
* Because of the long travel times, you are more or less forced to create dozens of outposts along your travels, which quickly becomes very tedious and boring.
* Breaks mods that keep the game alive constantly with minor fixes that are probably there to simulate bigger development proceedings.
* Community management acts toxic, deleting helpful posts on how to revert game versions. (https://www.makeuseof.com/how-to-downgrade-steam-games/)

Gameplay is not enjoyable without the use of mods and the developer seems hell-bent to both keep it that way and annoy modders as much as possible.

Annoying physics, not fun to play and very grindy. If you as much as touch a log laying on the ground, chances are you are gonna launch it up a slope, it will slowly roll back and kill you. Movement feels clunky, hitting an enemy on a slope is down to luck, enemies move erratically, making it impossible to anticipate things. I wouldn't mind and play this game as a crafting game, if that was possible. But while the developer made world options available, even on the easiest death setting, you still lose your inventory and some skills, Not offering a lossless death option, when you could have done so without additional effort, is maximum asshole behaviour.
